scenario: A soccer club introduces a new high-press coaching system mid-season. Analysts compare match outcomes after the change to outcomes before the change and conclude the new system improved performance because the team’s points-per-game increased. The coach notes that several starters also returned from injury around the same time, and the team’s fixture difficulty eased in the following month.
claim: Implementing the high-press system (X) caused the increase in points-per-game (Y).

variables.X: Adoption of a high-press coaching system (tactical intervention) starting from a specific matchweek
variables.Y: Team performance measured by points-per-game (or win rate) in subsequent matches
variables.Z: Time-varying team strength and context: player availability/fitness, opponent strength (fixture difficulty), and morale, which both influence the decision to adopt X and affect Y

annotations.causal_structure: Z(t) affects both the probability of adopting X at time t (coach changes tactics when injuries resolve, morale shifts, or fixtures soften) and the outcome Y(t+1). Past outcomes Y(t-1) also influence future Z(t) (morale/selection) and future X(t) (reactive tactical changes), creating treatment-confounder feedback over time.
annotations.key_insight: Because Z changes over time and is itself influenced by prior outcomes, a simple before/after or naive regression adjustment can attribute to X what is actually due to evolving squad health and schedule; identifying the causal effect requires methods that handle time-varying confounding (e.g., g-methods) and clear measurement of Z.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Y(t-1) (recent poor results) -> increases probability of X(t) (tactical overhaul). Meanwhile Z(t) (injury recoveries, fixture difficulty) -> affects both X(t) and Y(t+1). Also Y(t-1) -> Z(t) (morale, lineup choices) -> Y(t+1), creating a feedback loop between outcomes, confounders, and treatment over matchweeks.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous as stated. If, conditional on a sufficiently rich set of time-varying covariates Z (player availability, opponent strength, home/away, rest days, morale proxies) and appropriate longitudinal causal methods, the estimated effect of X remains positive and robust, then the claim becomes more credible. If the effect disappears after properly accounting for Z and pre-trends (e.g., improvement already underway due to returning starters and easier fixtures), then the claim is likely false.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is a Pearl L2 question because the claim is about the effect of intervening to set X (adopting the high-press system) on Y (points-per-game). However, the observed post-change improvement does not identify the causal effect do(X) because the intervention timing is not randomized and is entangled with time-varying confounding Z. Z(t) (injury recovery, fixture difficulty, morale/selection) causally affects Y(t+1) and also causally affects the coach’s decision to implement X(t). Additionally, prior outcomes Y(t-1) can influence both Z(t) (morale, lineup stability) and X(t) (reactive tactical changes), creating treatment–confounder feedback. In such settings, naive before/after comparisons or standard regression can produce biased estimates because they fail to block all backdoor paths from X to Y across time and may inappropriately condition on variables affected by prior Y. Without a design or model that measures Z over time and properly accounts for its evolution (e.g., marginal structural models, g-formula, or a credible quasi-experiment like an exogenous coaching change date unrelated to Z), we cannot determine whether do(X) would have increased Y. Therefore the causal conclusion is not justified from the described evidence, but it is not disproven either; the correct label is Ambiguous.

scenario: A soccer club wants to reduce hamstring injuries. The head coach proposes an intervention: cap each player’s weekly high-speed running (HSR) distance in training (measured by GPS) at a fixed threshold. After implementing the cap for 8 weeks, the club compares injury rates to the prior 8 weeks and observes fewer hamstring injuries. The coach concludes the cap caused the reduction.
claim: Imposing a weekly high-speed running cap in training reduces hamstring injuries.

variables.X: Intervention: enforce a weekly cap on each player’s high-speed running distance in training (GPS-based limit).
variables.Y: Outcome: hamstring injury incidence over the following weeks (games + training).
variables.Z: Confounder: concurrent reduction in match congestion (fewer matches per week) that lowers total sprint exposure and fatigue.

annotations.causal_structure: Z affects both X and Y over time: when match congestion drops (Z), coaches are more able/willing to enforce training HSR caps (X) and players have lower fatigue/total sprint load, reducing hamstring injuries (Y). A naive before-after comparison attributes Z-driven improvements to X.
annotations.key_insight: A before-after evaluation of an intervention is not causal when a time-varying factor shifts at the same time and influences both treatment assignment and the outcome.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: schedule congestion changes (Z). t1: staff implements/enforces HSR cap (X) partly because congestion is lower. t2: injury risk (Y) changes due to both altered total load/fatigue from Z and any true effect of X.
conditional_answers: If match congestion (Z) is held constant (e.g., by comparing to a matched period with identical match frequency or using teams/players with similar congestion), the estimated effect of the HSR cap on injuries could be isolated; without that, the observed reduction may be partly or wholly due to Z.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: The claim is valid as a causal statement about an intervention (L2): it asserts that doing X would change Y. The causal trap is that the observed pre/post association is not, by itself, sufficient to justify the claim because a time-varying confounder Z (match congestion) changes around the same time and causally influences both the likelihood/intensity of enforcing X and the injury outcome Y. In a causal graph, Z -> X and Z -> Y creates an open backdoor path X <- Z -> Y, so the raw comparison mixes the effect of X with the effect of Z. However, the claim itself can still be true in the underlying data-generating process; the correct causal conclusion is that to support the claim one must estimate the effect of do(X) on Y by blocking the backdoor via controlling for Z (or using a design that holds Z fixed), rather than relying on the before-after injury decline.

scenario: A soccer club introduces a new high-press training block during mid-season. Coaches decide who fully participates based on recent match fitness and minor knock history. Analysts compare the next 6 matches and find that players who received the high-press block show higher total distance covered and more high-intensity sprints, but they also show a higher rate of soft-tissue injuries. The performance staff proposes scaling back the block, claiming the block causes injuries.
claim: Implementing the high-press training block (X) increases soft-tissue injury risk (Y), so reducing the block will reduce injuries.

variables.X: Assignment to (or dosage of) the high-press training block during the mid-season microcycle
variables.Y: Soft-tissue injury occurrence over the subsequent 6-match window (e.g., hamstring/calf strain)
variables.Z: Recent match fitness / latent fragility and load tolerance (including prior minor knocks), which influences both assignment to the block and injury risk

annotations.causal_structure: Z (time-varying fitness/fragility) affects X (training block dosage) and Y (injury). Past Y-like signals (minor knocks, soreness) update Z, which then changes future X; additionally, X changes future Z via adaptation/fatigue, which then affects Y.
annotations.key_insight: Because fitness/fragility evolves over time and is influenced by prior training and prior knock signals, naive comparisons of injury rates by training dosage can mix causal effects with time-varying confounding; the direction of bias is not identifiable without stronger design/assumptions.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: prior microcycles produce soreness/knock signals and current fitness (Z0). t1: coaches set high-press block dosage (X1) based on Z0. t2: X1 changes fatigue/adaptation (Z1). t3: injury occurs (Y) depending on Z1 and other shocks. Meanwhile, early symptoms before t3 can also feed back to future training decisions (X2) if the window is extended.
conditional_answers: Answer if the club randomized (or quasi-randomized) who receives the block conditional on baseline fitness/knock history: the causal effect of X on Y could be estimated, and the claim might become Yes or No depending on the estimated effect. Answer if assignment is purely coach-driven using evolving fitness/knock signals: the claim remains Ambiguous because observed injury differences could be due to Z rather than X.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is an L2 (interventional) question: it asks what would happen to Y under an intervention do(X=reduce high-press block). The observed association between X and Y is not sufficient because Z is a time-varying common cause of both X and Y. Coaches set X using current Z (match fitness, prior knocks, perceived robustness), and Z also directly affects injury propensity. Moreover, X changes future Z through fatigue/adaptation, so Z is simultaneously a confounder (for later X) and a mediator-like mechanism (from earlier X to Y). If we adjust for the wrong version of Z (e.g., post-X fatigue markers), we risk blocking part of the causal pathway (confounder–mediator entanglement); if we do not adjust for evolving Z, we leave backdoor paths open (unblocked backdoor). Without a design that breaks the dependence of X on Z over time (e.g., randomization, valid instrument, or a correctly specified longitudinal causal model such as a marginal structural model with appropriate weighting), the direction and magnitude of the causal effect of reducing X on Y are not identifiable from the described comparison. Therefore, the claim that reducing the block will reduce injuries is not validated nor refuted by the given evidence, making the correct label Ambiguous.

scenario: A soccer club pilots an AI-driven training plan that prescribes higher weekly high-speed running (HSR) volume for attackers. Coaches partially follow the plan: they increase HSR volume when the model flags a player as 'low injury risk' and hold back when it flags 'high risk'. The performance staff then runs an analysis to estimate the causal effect of increasing HSR volume on next-match sprint output, using observational training logs. They correctly decide to adjust for pre-week risk score and recent acute workload history, but they also (incorrectly) consider adjusting for 'midweek muscle soreness' measured two days after the HSR sessions. After consulting a causal diagram, they exclude soreness from adjustment, block the backdoor path via risk/fitness, and estimate that increasing HSR volume causally increases next-match sprint output for attackers.
claim: If the club intervenes to increase an attacker’s weekly HSR volume (X), their next-match sprint output (Y) will increase, provided we adjust for pre-week injury-risk/fitness indicators (Z) and do not adjust for post-session soreness.

variables.X: Intervention: Increase weekly high-speed running (HSR) training volume for an attacker during the week (e.g., +15% HSR meters vs the planned baseline).
variables.Y: Outcome: Next-match sprint output (e.g., total sprint meters or number of sprints above a speed threshold).
variables.Z: Time-varying confounding set: Pre-week injury-risk/fitness state summarized by the AI risk score and recent acute:chronic workload ratio (these influence both the coach’s decision to increase HSR and the player’s next-match sprint output).

annotations.causal_structure: Z (pre-week risk/fitness and recent workload) affects both X (coach’s HSR increase decision) and Y (next-match sprint output). X affects midweek soreness (a post-treatment mediator) which also affects Y. Conditioning on soreness would induce a confounder–mediator error; correct identification uses adjustment for pre-treatment Z only, leaving mediators unadjusted.
annotations.key_insight: At L2 we need the effect of do(X). Because training assignment responds to evolving risk/fitness (time-varying confounding), we must block the backdoor through pre-treatment state Z. But we must not adjust for post-treatment variables like soreness that lie on the causal pathway from X to Y (or act as post-treatment colliders), or we would bias the estimated total causal effect.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t-14d to t0: recent acute/chronic workload and fitness form Z; t0: coaches choose whether to increase HSR (X) based on Z; t0 to t+2d: higher HSR increases soreness; t+3d to t+6d: recovery/training continuation; t+7d: match occurs and sprint output Y is realized.
conditional_answers: Answer if the analyst adjusts only for pre-week Z (risk score and recent workload) and avoids conditioning on post-session soreness: the claim is supported (Yes). If the analyst also conditions on midweek soreness (post-treatment), the estimated effect may be biased toward zero or even flip sign, so the claim would no longer be justified from that analysis.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning:
We are asked about an interventional claim: the effect of do(X=Increase HSR) on Y (next-match sprint output). In the data-generating process, coaches do not assign X randomly; they choose X in response to the player’s evolving pre-week state Z (risk/fitness and recent workload). Z is a common cause of X and Y, creating an open backdoor path X <- Z -> Y. Therefore, without adjustment, the association between X and Y mixes the causal effect of X with selection effects driven by Z (time-varying confounding).

However, Z is measured prior to the week’s HSR decision, so conditioning on Z blocks the backdoor path and yields exchangeability with respect to Z: within strata of Z, the remaining variation in X can be treated as-if randomized for identifying the total effect of do(X) on Y (assuming no additional unmeasured confounders and correct temporal ordering).

Crucially, midweek muscle soreness occurs after X and is downstream of X on a causal path X -> soreness -> Y. Conditioning on soreness would remove part of the causal effect (blocking a mediator) and can also introduce post-treatment bias if soreness is influenced by other factors that also affect Y. Since the target estimand is the total causal effect of increasing HSR on sprint output, the correct adjustment set includes pre-treatment Z but excludes post-treatment soreness.

Given this causal structure, the claim is valid: intervening to increase weekly HSR volume will increase next-match sprint output, and the appropriate identification strategy is to adjust for pre-week Z (to block time-varying confounding) while not adjusting for post-treatment soreness.

scenario: An NBA analytics staffer reviews a star guard who played through a minor ankle sprain. The team’s internal report notes that in games where the guard received a pregame painkiller injection, he finished with higher points per possession and the team won more often. The staffer then makes a counterfactual claim: 'If we had given him the injection in the games we didn’t, he would have performed just as well as in the injection games, without increasing reinjury risk, because the injection only changes pain and pain doesn’t change tissue healing.' The medical staff objects that the injection changes how he moves, how much he plays, and what the coach asks him to do, and that these downstream changes interact with the injury’s latent severity and the game context.
claim: Counterfactually, if the player had received the painkiller injection in the games he did not receive it, his performance (points per possession) would have increased to the level observed in injection games, while reinjury risk would have stayed the same, because the injection only affects pain and not the underlying ankle damage.

variables.X: Receiving a pregame painkiller injection (vs. not) for the ankle sprain
variables.Y: Game performance (points per possession) and short-horizon reinjury occurrence in/after the game
variables.Z: Latent ankle injury severity and game/usage context (coach minutes/role decisions, defensive attention, pace), which jointly influence both injection decision and outcomes

annotations.causal_structure: Z (latent severity + context) affects X (injection decision) and affects Y (performance and reinjury). X affects pain and perceived readiness, which affects minutes/role and movement patterns (mediators), which then affect Y. The claim implicitly holds the underlying damage/healing pathway fixed while changing X, ignoring that X changes mediators that are part of the causal pathway to both performance and reinjury.
annotations.key_insight: The counterfactual compares worlds while illegitimately 'freezing' mediators (movement, minutes, role) and even aspects of the injury trajectory; changing X changes the downstream behavior and exposure that determine both performance and reinjury, so you cannot assert 'same risk' or 'same underlying state' without specifying and modeling those mediator changes.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Z (true sprain severity + opponent/context) realized. t1: Decision X (inject or not) made based on Z and expected usage. t2: Injection changes pain perception and perceived readiness. t3: Coach adjusts minutes/role; player alters movement aggressiveness. t4: Y1 performance realized during game; t5: Y2 reinjury/flare-up risk realized postgame.
conditional_answers: Answer if you instead ask: 'What is the effect of a policy that assigns injections randomly at t1 (regardless of Z) on performance and reinjury?': It would still require modeling mediators (minutes/movement) because the injection changes them; you cannot claim 'no change in reinjury' unless you also specify the induced change in playing intensity and exposure. Answer if you ask: 'What is the effect of injection while holding minutes fixed by design (e.g., strict minutes cap)?': That becomes a different intervention (do(X) plus do(minutes=cap)) and could have different effects; the original claim does not distinguish these interventions.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it asserts a Level-3 counterfactual while implicitly performing an impossible cross-world operation: it changes X (injection) but assumes away the mediator pathways by which X would alter the player’s behavior and exposure (minutes, aggressiveness, movement mechanics), and then concludes reinjury risk is unchanged. Formally, the observed association between X and Y is compatible with a causal graph where Z (latent severity and context) is a common cause of both X and Y, and where X also causally affects mediators M (pain, perceived readiness, coach usage, movement) that in turn affect Y. The counterfactual quantity needed is Y_{x=1} for games where X=0, but the claim substitutes an intuition closer to 'Y_{x=1, M=M_{x=0}}' (changing injection while fixing downstream behavior/usage as if the player would have played the same way), which is a mediator-fixing error and generally not identifiable or even well-defined without a structural model. Moreover, because Z influences both the decision to inject and the baseline risk/performance, the injection games are not exchangeable with non-injection games; the higher performance in injection games could reflect easier contexts or strategic deployment rather than the injection’s effect. Therefore, from the given information, one cannot validly conclude that injecting in the non-injection games would have raised performance to the observed injection level while leaving reinjury risk unchanged; the counterfactual claim overreaches by ignoring both confounding by Z and the fact that intervening on X changes mediators that drive Y.

scenario: In professional tennis, players are allowed to take a Medical Timeout (MTO) for injury treatment. Data shows that players who take an MTO lose the match 70% of the time. A pundit claims MTOs break a player's own rhythm and should be avoided.
claim: Taking a Medical Timeout (X) causes a player to lose the match (Y).

variables.X: Taking a Medical Timeout
variables.Y: Losing the match
variables.Z: Underlying injury or physical distress

annotations.causal_structure: Z (Injury) causes X (Need for MTO) and Z causes Y (Poor performance/Loss). The observed relationship is spurious.
annotations.key_insight: Players take MTOs because they are hurt. Being hurt causes losing. The MTO is a symptom of the confounder, not the cause of the loss.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z occurs at t0. X happens at t1. Y happens at t2.
conditional_answers: No. If a healthy player took an MTO strategically (intervention without Z), they might actually gain an advantage (rest). The data reflects Z, not X.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The association between X and Y is driven by the common cause Z (injury). Players do not take MTOs randomly; they take them when Z is present. Z reduces the probability of winning. Therefore, X is a marker for Z, not a cause of Y. Asserting a causal link ignores the confounding by indication.

scenario: An NBA team rolls out a new 'momentum timeout' policy: whenever the opponent makes two straight 3-pointers, the coach immediately calls a timeout. Midseason, analysts compare games where the coach used the momentum timeout versus games where he did not, and they find that games with a momentum timeout have a higher probability of losing. Some staff argue the policy is harmful and should be scrapped; others argue the policy is being deployed only when the game is already slipping away.
claim: Calling a momentum timeout (after two straight opponent threes) increases the chance the team loses, so the coach should stop using it.

variables.X: Coach calls an immediate 'momentum timeout' after the opponent hits two consecutive 3-pointers (policy intervention)
variables.Y: Game outcome (probability of losing / win-loss)
variables.Z: In-game adverse momentum state that triggers the timeout (e.g., opponent hot shooting, defensive breakdowns, fatigue, lineup mismatch, score run severity)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (adverse momentum) increases both the likelihood of X (timeout is called) and Y (loss). The observed association X–Y is therefore partly/mostly driven by Z. The intended causal arrow is X -> Y, but the policy is triggered by Z which is already on a path to Y.
annotations.key_insight: Because the timeout is a reactive response to worsening game state, comparing games with vs without the timeout conflates the effect of the timeout with the effect of the underlying momentum shock that caused it.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Z (opponent run / hot shooting / mismatch) begins. t1: Z triggers X (timeout called). t2: Y (final result) is realized; Z continues to influence Y regardless of X.
conditional_answers: If the analysis can isolate exogenous variation in timeouts (e.g., random coach absence, a pre-committed rule applied regardless of severity, or an instrument like a broadcast-mandated timeout that occurs right after the second three independent of the coach), then the causal effect of X on Y could be estimated; otherwise the observed higher loss rate in timeout games is not interpretable as the effect of the timeout.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: At Pearl Level 2 we ask an interventional query: what would Y be under do(X=1) versus do(X=0). The empirical comparison P(Y|X=1) vs P(Y|X=0) is not equal to the causal effect because X is not assigned independently; it is triggered by Z, an adverse momentum state. Z is a common cause of X and Y (a backdoor path X <- Z -> Y), so the association can be negative even if the timeout is beneficial, neutral, or harmful. Without a valid strategy to block the backdoor (e.g., measuring and adjusting for the full relevant Z, or using quasi-random variation in X), the sign and magnitude of the causal effect of calling the timeout remain unidentified. Therefore the claim that the timeout increases losing is not justified from the observed comparison, but we also cannot conclude the timeout helps; the correct label is Ambiguous.

scenario: An NBA team’s analytics group evaluates whether a late-game timeout by the coach prevented a loss. In the actual game, with 18 seconds left, the team was down 1, looked disorganized, and the coach called a timeout (X=1). Out of the timeout they ran a clean set, got a good shot, and won by 1 (Y=Win). A commentator claims: “If the coach hadn’t called the timeout, they still would have won, because the star guard was already ‘locked in’ and would have created a good shot anyway.” The team wants a counterfactual judgment about that single play, not an average effect across games.
claim: In this specific game, had the coach not called the timeout, the team would still have won because the star guard’s late-game focus would have produced an equally good possession.

variables.X: Calling a timeout with 18 seconds left (vs not calling it)
variables.Y: Game outcome: team wins vs loses
variables.Z: Set quality/possession organization (play call, spacing, matchup targeting) as a mediator generated by the timeout; also partially driven by in-the-moment defensive alignment

annotations.causal_structure: X (timeout) causes Z (organized set quality), which causes Y (win). A backup cause B (star guard improvisation under chaos) could also cause Y if X were absent, but in the actual world X occurs and produces Y first, preempting the backup pathway.
annotations.key_insight: Counterfactual credit in a single event depends on whether the observed cause preempted a plausible alternative cause; the existence of a backup plan does not negate the causal role of the actual intervention when it changed the causal route to the outcome.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: coach observes disorganization/defense; t1: timeout called (X); t2: set is installed and spacing/mismatch created (Z); t3: shot quality increases; t4: made basket and defensive stop; t5: win (Y). In the no-timeout world, the possession evolves differently and may or may not reach a comparable shot via improvisation.
conditional_answers: Answer is Yes (claim is valid) if (i) the star guard’s improvisation would, in the no-timeout world, reliably generate a shot of equal or higher quality against the same defensive alignment and clock constraints, and (ii) the timeout did not materially alter the defense, matchups, or shot selection relative to the no-timeout trajectory. Otherwise the claim is not supported.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are asked a counterfactual about a single realized play: whether Y would still have occurred had X been set to 0. In the actual world, X=1 triggered Z (an organized set), and Z produced Y (a win). The claim asserts that even under do(X=0), Y would still occur due to a backup causal route (star-guard improvisation), i.e., B -> Y, that would activate only if X were absent. This is precisely a late-preemption structure: the actual cause (timeout) brings about Y, while a plausible alternative cause would have brought about Y later or under a different trajectory if the actual cause had not occurred. Under late preemption, it can be true that (a) X caused Y in the actual world and simultaneously (b) Y would still have happened under do(X=0) because the backup route would have produced Y. Therefore the counterfactual claim ‘they still would have won without the timeout’ can be valid even though the timeout was causally efficacious in the observed world. The key is that counterfactual dependence is not required for actual causation in preemption settings, and the presence of a preempted backup pathway makes the counterfactual Y_{X=0}=Win consistent with the observed Y under X=1.

scenario: An NBA team introduces a new in-game “momentum timeout” rule: whenever the opponent scores 8+ unanswered points, the head coach must call a timeout within the next dead ball. The front office wants to estimate the causal effect of enforcing this rule on win probability. Analysts compare games where the coach called a momentum timeout during an opponent run versus games where no such timeout was called, and they also adjust for the current score margin and time remaining. They find that games with momentum timeouts have lower final win probability, concluding the rule hurts performance.
claim: Enforcing the momentum-timeout rule (calling a timeout during opponent scoring runs) reduces the team’s chance of winning.

variables.X: Enforcing the momentum-timeout intervention (coach calls a timeout during an opponent 8+ point run)
variables.Y: Game outcome (final win probability / win vs loss)
variables.Z: Time-varying game state and latent team condition (e.g., opponent run severity, lineup fatigue, foul trouble, defensive breakdown intensity, and coach’s private assessment of team stability)

annotations.causal_structure: Z(t) (evolving game state and latent instability) influences both X(t) (timeout decision/enforcement at that moment) and Y (final outcome); additionally, past Y-proxy signals (earlier scoring swings) update Z(t) and change the probability of X(t), creating treatment assignment that depends on prior outcome trajectory.
annotations.key_insight: Timeouts are triggered reactively by worsening, rapidly changing game states that also predict losing; adjusting for only coarse observed state (score/time) may not block the backdoor path because unobserved and time-varying drivers of both the intervention and outcome remain, and some observed state variables can be affected by earlier (implicit) interventions and game dynamics.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: At t0 the team plays normally; between t0 and t1 an opponent run begins and Z(t1) worsens (fatigue, matchup issues). At t1 the coach decides X(t1)=1 (timeout) partly based on Z(t1) and prior scoring trajectory. Between t1 and t2, Z(t2) evolves again (lineup changes, foul trouble), affecting both subsequent timeout likelihood and the final Y at t_end.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous: If all components of Z(t) that jointly drive timeout decisions and future win probability are fully observed over time and correctly modeled (e.g., possession-level state, lineup matchups, fatigue proxies, foul risk, shot quality, and coach intent) and no post-treatment variables are inappropriately controlled for, then one could identify the causal effect of enforcing the rule; if key parts of Z(t) are unobserved or mismeasured, the observed negative association may be entirely due to reactive assignment and time-varying confounding.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: The claim attempts to move from an observational contrast to an interventional statement about do(X). In this setting, X is not assigned randomly: the coach calls a momentum timeout precisely when the evolving game state Z(t) indicates elevated risk (e.g., defensive confusion, fatigue, foul trouble, opponent hot streak, matchup exploitation). Those same components of Z(t) causally increase the probability of losing Y. Therefore there is an open backdoor path X  Z(t)  Y (time-varying confounding). Moreover, Z(t) is updated by earlier scoring trajectory (a proxy for prior outcome evolution), so treatment assignment depends on past outcome-related signals, which is the hallmark of time-varying confounding. Adjusting only for score margin and time remaining does not guarantee blocking the backdoor because (i) they may be too coarse to capture the latent instability that drives both X and Y, and (ii) some game-state variables used for adjustment may themselves be downstream of earlier strategic responses, risking bias if conditioned on incorrectly. Hence, from the information given, the negative association between calling a momentum timeout and winning cannot be interpreted as the causal effect of enforcing the rule. The effect could be harmful, beneficial, or null; identification would require either randomization (e.g., rule-enforced vs not enforced games) or a valid causal strategy that correctly handles time-varying confounding (e.g., sequential ignorability with rich Z(t), g-methods, or an instrument that shifts X without directly affecting Y).

scenario: A tennis player feels mild wrist pain the morning of a tournament match. The coach debates whether to switch from a heavy topspin forehand (high wrist load) to a flatter forehand (lower wrist load). After choosing to keep the heavy topspin style, the player’s wrist worsens mid-match and they retire. A commentator claims: “If the coach had forced the flatter forehand, the player would not have retired.”
claim: If the coach had forced the flatter forehand, the player would not have retired from the match.

variables.X: Counterfactual intervention: coach forces the player to use a flatter forehand technique (reduced wrist load) for the match
variables.Y: Match retirement due to wrist injury aggravation
variables.Z: Latent injury severity and biological fragility of the wrist that morning (e.g., micro-tear extent), affecting both technique choice feasibility and retirement risk

annotations.causal_structure: Z (true wrist damage) influences both X (whether a flatter technique is feasible/accepted without performance collapse) and Y (retirement). The counterfactual statement conditions on the realized fact that Y happened (retired), then infers what would happen under do(X), which implicitly selects a subset of worlds/players where the match is even played similarly and where retirement is comparable.
annotations.key_insight: Counterfactuals about preventing retirement are ill-posed when you condition on the observed retirement event; the set of “would-have-played” worlds under the alternative technique may differ because the injury severity that led to retirement also affects whether the alternative technique is possible and whether the player would continue playing at all.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: underlying wrist micro-damage Z exists before the match; t1: coach/player choose technique X; t2: wrist load during rallies interacts with Z; t3: injury aggravates; t4: retirement Y occurs (observed).
conditional_answers: Ambiguous unless we specify (i) the causal effect of technique change on wrist load and aggravation, (ii) whether the player would still attempt to play the full match under the alternative technique given pain/performance tradeoffs, and (iii) how Z would behave under the counterfactual (e.g., whether Z is the same micro-damage but with different load exposure).
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: The claim is a counterfactual of the form: Y_{X=flat}=0 given we observed Y=1 under X=topspin. This is not identifiable from the observation alone because conditioning on the realized retirement (Y=1) induces counterfactual selection: the observed world is one where Z was sufficiently severe (or fragile) to culminate in retirement, and that same Z also affects whether the flatter forehand would be feasible (X) and whether retirement would still occur (Y). Without a structural model linking Z, technique-induced load, and the retirement decision, we cannot infer whether, in the closest world where we intervene to force a flatter forehand, the player would (a) continue playing without retirement, (b) retire anyway due to the same underlying damage, or (c) retire for a different reason (e.g., performance collapse leading to strategic retirement). Therefore the counterfactual conclusion is not warranted from the given information; it remains ambiguous because multiple causal models consistent with the facts imply different values of Y_{X=flat}.

scenario: A soccer analytics group studies whether using a high press is linked to better match results. They compute, across a full season, the association between a team’s press intensity (measured by PPDA: passes allowed per defensive action, inverted so higher means more pressing) and match points. They find that higher press intensity is associated with more points per match. They also notice that within the subset of matches where the team trailed at any point, higher press intensity is associated with fewer points. A pundit argues this means pressing is only good when you are already winning and is harmful when you are behind. The analytics group instead claims the season-level association (pressing correlates with more points) is still valid as an observational statement about the whole dataset.
claim: In this season’s match data, teams that press more intensely tend to earn more points per match (i.e., press intensity is positively associated with points).

variables.X: Press intensity in a match (e.g., inverted PPDA; higher values indicate more aggressive pressing)
variables.Y: Match outcome measured as points earned (0/1/3) or expected points
variables.Z: Match state / game context that shapes both pressing and outcomes (e.g., whether the team is trailing, leading, red cards, opponent strength, time remaining)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (match state/opponent strength) influences both X (press intensity) and Y (points). Aggregating across heterogeneous Z strata can yield an overall X–Y association that differs in sign from within-stratum associations.
annotations.key_insight: Simpson’s paradox is about how aggregation over a context variable Z can reverse within-group associations; it does not invalidate the existence of the marginal association itself. The claim is purely associational (P(Y|X) differs with X) and can be true even if causal interpretations fail or subgroup patterns reverse.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (pre-match opponent strength, lineup quality) and Z at t1 (in-match scoreline, red cards, time remaining) affect X at t1 (pressing decision/intensity) and also affect Y at t2 (final points).
conditional_answers: Answer is Yes if the dataset indeed shows a positive marginal association between press intensity and points when not conditioning on Z. Answer could flip to No only if the empirical marginal association is not actually positive (i.e., the descriptive statistic was computed incorrectly).
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: Pearl L1 concerns associations, not interventions. The claim asserts a marginal statistical relationship: that higher X is observed alongside higher Y in the pooled season data. Simpson’s paradox (aggregation bias) warns that conditioning on a context variable Z (match state/opponent strength) can yield within-Z associations that differ from, or even reverse, the pooled association. However, the presence of a reversal after stratifying on Z does not logically contradict the existence of the pooled association; both can simultaneously be true because P(Y|X) in the aggregate is a weighted mixture over Z strata with weights that depend on X. Therefore, if the computed season-level correlation/mean difference is positive, the claim is valid as an L1 statement. What would be invalid is a causal conclusion like “pressing causes more points,” because Z is a common cause of both X and Y and can drive the observed association; but the claim deliberately stays at the associational level, so it remains correct.

scenario: A soccer club’s analysts notice that matches in which the head coach makes an early substitution (before the 30th minute) are much more likely to end in a loss. A commentator claims this proves that early subs hurt team performance and the coach should avoid them.
claim: Making an early substitution causes the team to lose more often.

variables.X: Early substitution by the coach (before the 30th minute)
variables.Y: Match outcome (probability of losing)
variables.Z: Early-match adversity (e.g., red card, key injury, or conceding an early goal) that prompts the substitution and also increases losing probability

annotations.causal_structure: Z increases the chance of an early substitution (X) and independently increases the chance of losing (Y); observed association between X and Y is driven by matches already going badly.
annotations.key_insight: Early substitutions are often reactions to a deteriorating game state; the outcome risk is already elevated before the substitution decision, so correlation does not identify a harmful effect of the substitution.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (early adversity: red card/injury/early goal) raises baseline loss risk by t90 and triggers X at t0+ (early substitution); analysts then observe X correlated with Y at t90.
conditional_answers: Answer if you only look at observational match logs without accounting for why the substitution happened: you will (incorrectly) conclude early subs cause losses. Answer if you compare similar game states (same scoreline, same red-card status, similar injury severity) at the same minute: the apparent harm should shrink or could even reverse.
label: No
correct_reasoning: At Pearl Level 1 we are only describing association, not intervention. The claim is causal but the evidence is merely correlational. The data-generating story contains a common cause Z (early-match adversity) that (i) makes an early substitution X more likely because the coach is responding to trouble, and (ii) makes losing Y more likely because the team is already disadvantaged. Therefore P(Y|X) > P(Y|not X) can hold even when X has no harmful causal effect (and could be beneficial). This is a reverse-causation/outcome-driven selection pattern: the impending bad outcome is foreshadowed by Z and induces the ‘treatment’ X. Without conditioning on (or otherwise accounting for) Z, the observed association between X and Y cannot be interpreted as X -> Y, so the causal conclusion is flawed.

scenario: Formula 1 data shows that drivers who make an 'unscheduled' pit stop (outside their planned window) finish, on average, 8 positions lower than those who stick to the schedule. Fans argue that sticking to the schedule is the key to winning.
claim: Sticking to the planned pit schedule causes better race finishes; deviating causes poor finishes.

variables.X: Making an unscheduled pit stop
variables.Y: Race finish position
variables.Z: Car damage, collision, or extreme tire degradation

annotations.causal_structure: Z (Damage/Collision) forces X (Unscheduled stop) and Z causes Y (Time loss/Retirement). The stop is a reaction to a problem, not the cause of the problem.
annotations.key_insight: Unscheduled stops are almost always reactions to adverse events (Z) that have already ruined the race strategy. The correlation is due to the adverse event.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z (crash) at Lap 20 -> X (pit stop) at Lap 21 -> Y (finish last) at Lap 50.
conditional_answers: No. If a driver randomly decided to make an extra stop (do(X)) without damage, they would lose time, but likely less than the data suggests for 'unscheduled' stops which include repair time.
label: No
correct_reasoning: This is L1 Reverse Causation/Confounding. The decision to pit early (X) is caused by Z (damage/issues), which also causes the poor result (Y). The 'unscheduled stop' group is selecting for drivers who are already in trouble. The claim incorrectly attributes the result to the strategic decision rather than the external cause.

scenario: In a tennis tournament, a star player feels mild wrist pain during the warm-up. The coach chooses to shorten the pre-match hitting session and asks the player to avoid high-pace forehand drills. The player wins the match but later aggravates the wrist in the next round and withdraws. A commentator claims the shortened warm-up 'caused' the later injury because the wrist was not fully prepared. The coach counters: if they had done the full warm-up, the wrist would have been even worse and the player might have withdrawn earlier. Analysts debate the counterfactual: what would have happened to the wrist if the warm-up had not been shortened, given the same underlying pain state.
claim: If the coach had NOT shortened the warm-up (X=0), the player would NOT have aggravated the wrist in the next round (Y=0).

variables.X: Warm-up modification decision: shortened/low-intensity warm-up vs normal full-intensity warm-up
variables.Y: Subsequent wrist aggravation leading to withdrawal in the next round
variables.Z: Latent wrist tissue fragility and pain severity at warm-up time (unobserved), which influences both the decision to shorten the warm-up and the probability of later aggravation

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y in the actual world; the counterfactual query compares Y_x=0 vs Y_x=1 but Z is not invariant across worlds because the coach's decision and the player's behavior/effort can change pain evolution and load, so the 'same Z' assumption is not justified without a structural model.
annotations.key_insight: Counterfactual claims require a model that specifies how the unobserved injury state Z and subsequent load evolve under each action; you cannot treat Z as a fixed background attribute shared across the X=0 and X=1 worlds when Z is partly latent and dynamically affected by behavior and micro-trauma.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: latent wrist fragility/pain Z present at warm-up; t0: coach chooses warm-up modification X based on observed cues of Z; t1: match load and compensatory mechanics respond to X and Z; t2: next-round cumulative load leads to aggravation/withdrawal Y.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous unless we specify (i) whether warm-up intensity causally changes micro-damage accumulation vs protective readiness, (ii) how the player would have adjusted stroke mechanics and effort under a full warm-up, and (iii) whether the same latent wrist state Z at t0 would have evolved differently under X=0 vs X=1.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: The claim is a counterfactual statement about the same player: compare Y under do(X=0) (normal warm-up) to Y under do(X=1) (shortened warm-up). However, the decision X is made in response to an underlying injury state Z that also drives Y, and Z is only partially observed and dynamically evolves with subsequent behavior. In an L3 query, we cannot identify P(Y_{x=0}=0 | observed history) from the single realized world without a structural causal model that specifies how Z and downstream match load respond to each intervention. Treating Z as a fixed 'background' attribute across the two worlds is a cross-world confounding error: the very intervention may alter pain evolution, compensatory mechanics, and load, which in turn changes effective injury risk. Therefore, from the given information, neither 'full warm-up would have prevented aggravation' nor its negation is logically entailed; the counterfactual remains underdetermined, making the correct label Ambiguous.

scenario: An NBA team pilots an in-game “momentum timeout” policy: whenever the opponent goes on a 7–0 run, the coach calls an immediate timeout (X). Analysts compare games where the coach used the momentum-timeout rule versus games where he did not, and they observe that games with momentum timeouts have worse final point differential (Y). The front office considers banning the policy, claiming it harms performance. However, the coach tends to trigger the policy precisely when the team is already spiraling (e.g., poor shot quality, defensive breakdowns, fatigue), and those same conditions also predict losing margins. Additionally, the coach sometimes deviates from the rule when he expects the run to end naturally (e.g., opponent’s hot shooter subbing out), creating further endogeneity in when the timeout is called.
claim: If the team were to enforce the momentum-timeout rule (call a timeout after every 7–0 opponent run), the final point differential would improve compared to not enforcing it.

variables.X: Calling an immediate timeout in response to an opponent 7–0 run (enforcing the momentum-timeout policy)
variables.Y: Final point differential / win probability at game end
variables.Z: Time-varying game state that both triggers the timeout decision and affects outcomes (e.g., current lineup fatigue, defensive communication quality, shot quality, opponent hot streak sustainability, foul trouble, and score/clock context)

annotations.causal_structure: Z(t) influences both X(t) (timeout called) and Y; additionally Y(t-1) (current margin and run dynamics) affects Z(t) and X(t), creating a time-varying backdoor path X(t) <- Z(t) <- Y(t-1) -> Y
annotations.key_insight: The timeout is a reactive, state-dependent intervention chosen in response to evolving in-game conditions that also causally drive the final outcome; naive comparisons (even with some controls) can misattribute the effect of the bad game state to the timeout itself, and proper identification requires modeling the longitudinal treatment assignment and history.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: prior possessions set current margin and fatigue; t1: opponent run emerges and game state Z(t1) worsens; t2: coach decides whether to call timeout X(t2) based on Z(t1) and expectations; t3: subsequent possessions determine Y(t3) (final margin).
conditional_answers: Answer is Ambiguous if we only observe that timeouts are more common in games with worse outcomes, because that association can arise from time-varying confounding. The claim becomes answerable (potentially Yes or No) if we have a valid identification strategy such as a quasi-random instrument (e.g., exogenous communication failure forcing a timeout, or a rule-enforced automatic timeout), or rich play-by-play to apply g-methods (MSMs/g-formula) with correct modeling of the full history.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: At Pearl Level 2 we ask an interventional question: what would Y be under do(X=1) versus do(X=0). The observed data are generated by a policy where X is not randomized; it is chosen as a function of the evolving game state Z(t) and prior outcomes Y(t-1) (the run itself and current margin). Z(t) is a time-varying common cause of both the decision to call a timeout and the eventual final margin, opening an unblocked backdoor path from X to Y through Z. Moreover, because Z(t) is itself affected by earlier outcomes and earlier coaching choices, naive adjustment (e.g., controlling for current score only) can fail: it may omit key components of Z (fatigue, shot quality, matchup issues) or condition on post-treatment variables if earlier timeouts already changed the state. Therefore, from the reported association alone we cannot determine the sign or magnitude of the causal effect of enforcing the momentum-timeout rule. The claim that enforcing the rule would improve Y is not identifiable without additional assumptions or a design that breaks the dependence of X on Z(t) (e.g., randomization, an instrument, or correct longitudinal causal estimation). Hence the proper label is Ambiguous.

scenario: An NBA team pilots a wearable-based 'fatigue alert' system. When the system flags a player as high-fatigue during the week, the coaching staff reduces that player's minutes in the next game (rest intervention). The analytics department wants to estimate the causal effect of reducing minutes on next-game performance (points per 36 and defensive rating impact). A naive model that adjusts for the wearable fatigue score concludes that reducing minutes has no benefit or even harms performance. A causal analyst argues that this adjustment is invalid because the fatigue score is partly caused by the rest decision itself through mid-week practice modifications and recovery protocols that are triggered once a player is flagged and slated for reduced minutes.
claim: If we intervene to reduce a player's minutes in the next game (relative to the coach's default plan), the player's next-game performance improves on average; the 'no benefit' estimate arises because the analysis incorrectly adjusts for a post-intervention mediator (wearable fatigue score and related recovery actions), blocking part of the causal pathway.

variables.X: Minutes reduction policy for the next game (coach-enforced cap vs. default minutes plan)
variables.Y: Next-game performance (e.g., points per 36, on/off defensive impact, shooting efficiency)
variables.Z: Wearable-derived fatigue score and triggered recovery/practice modifications (a mediator influenced by X and affecting Y)

annotations.causal_structure: X (minutes cap) affects Z (fatigue score and recovery/practice load changes), which affects Y (performance). Separately, latent baseline condition (e.g., minor soreness, travel load) affects both the coach's default inclination to cap minutes and Y, but the key trap is treating Z as a pre-treatment confounder and adjusting for it even though it is downstream of X once the policy is in place.
annotations.key_insight: At L2, we must estimate the effect of do(X). Conditioning on a mediator Z that is affected by X removes part of X's effect on Y and can also open spurious paths if Z is a collider for downstream processes, yielding a misleading 'no effect' estimate.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: baseline soreness/travel load exists; t1: team sets X (minutes cap for upcoming game); t2: given X, staff alters practices/recovery, changing Z (fatigue score trajectory); t3: game occurs and Y is realized.
conditional_answers: Answer if you adjust for Z: you estimate mostly the direct effect of X not mediated through fatigue/recovery, and you may conclude X has little or negative effect. Answer if you do not adjust for Z (and instead block only true pre-treatment backdoors): you recover the total causal effect of X on Y, which is positive in this scenario.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are asked about an intervention: the effect of do(X=minutes cap) on Y (next-game performance). Under the stated data-generating process, X causally influences Z (fatigue trajectory and the recovery/practice changes that occur because the staff plans reduced minutes), and Z causally influences Y. Therefore Z lies on the causal pathway X -> Z -> Y. Adjusting for Z when estimating the effect of do(X) is a mediator adjustment error: it blocks the indirect path through Z and thus does not identify the total effect of X on Y. Consequently, an analysis that conditions on Z can legitimately return a near-zero or negative estimate even when the true total effect of intervening to reduce minutes is beneficial. The correct estimand for the coaching decision is the total causal effect, which requires not conditioning on post-intervention mediators like Z; instead one should adjust only for pre-treatment confounders of X and Y (e.g., baseline soreness/travel schedule known before the minutes plan is set). Given that the claim attributes the null finding to incorrect mediator adjustment and asserts a positive total effect under proper L2 reasoning, the claim is valid.

scenario: An NBA team introduces a wearable-based 'high-intensity minutes cap' policy mid-season. Coaches are instructed to pull players once the wearable estimates they have exceeded a threshold of high-speed runs and accelerations in a game. After implementation, the team’s internal report compares players who were actually pulled early (cap-triggered) vs. players who were not pulled, and finds that the pulled-early players have a higher rate of next-game soft-tissue injuries. The performance staff concludes the cap policy is harmful and recommends abandoning it.
claim: Because players who were pulled early due to the intensity cap had more next-game soft-tissue injuries, enforcing the intensity cap increases injury risk and should be stopped.

variables.X: Enforcing the wearable-based high-intensity minutes cap in a game (player is pulled early once the cap is triggered)
variables.Y: Soft-tissue injury occurrence in the next game (e.g., hamstring/calf strain)
variables.Z: Acute fatigue/strain signals during the game (the same latent/estimated physiological stress that both triggers the cap and elevates injury risk)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (acute fatigue/strain) increases Y (next-game injury) and also increases the probability that X is applied (cap is triggered and enforced). The analysis conditions on compliance/implementation status (who actually got pulled early), which is partly determined by Z, creating a biased comparison that makes X look harmful even if it is protective or neutral.
annotations.key_insight: Being 'pulled early' is not randomly assigned; it is a downstream indicator of in-game overload. Comparing pulled vs not-pulled players conditions on a variable influenced by the same stress that causes injury, inducing collider/selection bias in the estimated effect of the policy.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Player experiences high acute fatigue/strain Z during game. t0: Z triggers cap enforcement X (coach pulls player). t1: Z (and related physiological damage) raises probability of next-game injury Y; X may reduce further load after t0 but does not erase prior strain.
conditional_answers: If cap enforcement were randomized at the player-game level (or if the analysis used an exogenous rule-based threshold with a regression discontinuity around the trigger point and did not condition on post-trigger compliance), then a causal estimate of X on Y could be identified; under the current pulled-vs-not comparison, the direction and magnitude are not trustworthy.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim treats the observed association between X (being pulled early) and Y (next-game injury) as the causal effect of enforcing the cap. But at Pearl Level 2 we must ask what would happen under an intervention do(X). Here, X is not assigned independently: the cap is enforced precisely when Z (acute fatigue/strain) is high. Z is a common cause of both X and Y (Z -> X and Z -> Y). The report effectively compares high-Z games (more likely to trigger enforcement) to lower-Z games (less likely to trigger enforcement), so the higher injury rate among the pulled group is expected even if enforcing the cap reduces incremental load after the trigger. In causal terms, the comparison conditions on a post-trigger implementation/compliance status that is itself a function of Z, producing selection/collider-type bias in the estimated effect. Therefore, the observed higher injury rate among pulled players does not imply do(X=1) increases Y; it more plausibly reflects that Z was worse in the games where X occurred. A valid causal evaluation would require blocking the backdoor path through Z (e.g., randomization, valid quasi-experiment, or appropriate causal adjustment using pre-intervention measures of strain), rather than conditioning on who ended up being pulled.

scenario: A soccer club introduces a new high-intensity press in mid-season. The coaching staff compares matches where the team 'fully implemented the press' versus matches where they did not, and finds that fully-press matches have fewer goals conceded. They conclude the press causally improves defensive performance and decide to mandate it every match going forward. However, the decision to fully press in a given match is made on game day based on opponent strength, player freshness, and whether key defenders are available.
claim: Mandating the high-intensity press (X) will reduce goals conceded (Y) because matches with full pressing had fewer goals conceded.

variables.X: Coach mandates full high-intensity pressing for the match (vs partial/no press)
variables.Y: Goals conceded by the team in the match
variables.Z: Match-specific tactical risk context (opponent strength/style, player freshness/fatigue, key defender availability) that influences whether the press is used and also affects goals conceded

annotations.causal_structure: Z (game-day context and evolving team condition) affects both X (whether the press is mandated) and Y (goals conceded). Additionally, past Y (recent defensive performance and match load) influences Z (fatigue/injury status) which then influences future X, creating time-varying confounding across matches.
annotations.key_insight: The observed association between pressing and fewer goals conceded mixes the effect of the press with the effect of match context and evolving fatigue/availability that also drives the coach's decision; without a design that blocks these backdoor paths, the interventional effect of mandating the press is not identified.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t-2 to t-1: Prior match load and prior goals conceded affect perceived defensive form and fatigue/injuries (part of Z). t0: Based on Z, coach chooses whether to mandate the press (X). t1: Match is played and goals conceded (Y) is realized. The cycle repeats with Y feeding into future Z and X.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous: If the club can credibly treat the press mandate as randomized conditional on pre-match covariates (or uses a valid quasi-experiment like an exogenous assistant-coach change that affects X but not Y except through X), then the claim could be supported. If, instead, pressing is more likely when the squad is fresher or when the opponent is weak (or less likely when defenders are missing), then the observed reduction in goals conceded may be due to Z rather than X.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is a Level-2 (interventional) question: we want the causal effect of do(X=press) on Y (goals conceded). The comparison made is observational: E[Y|X=press] vs E[Y|X=no press]. But X is not assigned independently; it is chosen as a response to Z (opponent, freshness, availability), and Z also causally affects Y. Therefore there is an open backdoor path X <- Z -> Y, so the associational difference does not equal the interventional contrast E[Y|do(X=press)] - E[Y|do(X=no press)]. Moreover, Z is time-varying: prior outcomes and match loads influence current fatigue/availability (part of Z), which then influences the coach's future X, so naive adjustment choices can also be problematic if they condition on post-treatment variables in a multi-match panel. Without additional information—e.g., a correct longitudinal causal model with appropriate adjustment/weighting for time-varying confounding, or an exogenous source of variation in X—the direction and magnitude of the true effect of mandating the press cannot be determined from the stated comparison. Hence the claim is not confirmably true or false from the provided evidence, making the conclusion ambiguous.

scenario: A soccer club rolls out a new GPS-based training program mid-season that caps each player’s weekly high-speed running distance. The performance staff then evaluates the program by comparing match availability (not missing games due to injury) between players who complied with the cap and those who did not. They find that compliant players missed fewer games and conclude the cap caused fewer injuries.
claim: Imposing the GPS high-speed running cap (X) reduces injury-related game absences (Y), because compliant players have fewer absences than non-compliant players.

variables.X: Intervention: enforce/assign a weekly cap on high-speed running distance in training (GPS-based load restriction)
variables.Y: Outcome: injury-related match absences over the next 8 weeks
variables.Z: Post-intervention selection variable: compliance with the cap (and related factors like coach trust/playing role that affect both compliance and injury risk)

annotations.causal_structure: X affects compliance Z (players are more likely to comply when the cap is enforced). Unobserved factors U (e.g., baseline injury-proneness, professionalism, coach-managed minutes/role) affect both Z (who complies) and Y (injury absences). Conditioning on Z opens a noncausal path X -> Z <- U -> Y, biasing the estimated effect of X on Y.
annotations.key_insight: Comparing only compliers vs non-compliers is not a valid estimate of the intervention effect because compliance is a post-intervention collider influenced by both the intervention and player characteristics tied to injury risk.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Club enforces cap X. t1: Players exhibit compliance level Z during training weeks. t2: Injuries accumulate and produce match absences Y in subsequent weeks.
conditional_answers: Answer if you analyze everyone assigned to the cap regardless of compliance (intention-to-treat): the estimate is closer to the causal effect of implementing the policy. Answer if you restrict to compliers: the association can be biased in either direction because conditioning on Z opens a backdoor path through unobserved traits.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim treats the observed difference in Y between compliant and non-compliant players as the causal effect of enforcing the cap X. But the analysis conditions on Z = compliance, which is downstream of X (X -> Z). Compliance is also affected by unmeasured player/coach factors U (e.g., injury-proneness, professionalism, role and minute management) that also affect injury absences Y (U -> Y). Therefore Z is a collider on the path X -> Z <- U. Conditioning on Z opens this otherwise blocked path, inducing a spurious association between X and Y even if X had no effect. Hence the comparison among compliers does not identify the causal effect of the intervention; it is a biased post-intervention selection estimate. A valid L2 estimate would avoid conditioning on Z and instead use an intention-to-treat comparison (assigned/enforced vs not) or an identification strategy that accounts for noncompliance without opening collider bias.

scenario: An NBA team’s analytics department reviews a playoff series where the coach benched a young guard (Player G) in the 4th quarter of Games 5–7. In the actual world, the team won the series. The coach argues the benching was decisive because, in the games where G stayed on the floor late during the regular season, the team often gave up leads. A counterfactual question is posed: 'If the coach had NOT benched G in those playoff 4th quarters, would the team still have won the series?' The department tries to answer by comparing late-game defensive rating only among games where G was not benched and the team kept the lead, then extrapolating that to the playoff games.
claim: Because the team’s late-game defensive rating is much worse in games where Player G plays the 4th quarter, the team would have lost the series if the coach had kept G in (i.e., benching G caused the series win).

variables.X: Benching Player G in the 4th quarter (coach decision: bench vs keep on court)
variables.Y: Winning the playoff series
variables.Z: Late-game game-state and opponent response (lead size, foul trouble, matchup targeting, and lineup adjustments) that both influence the benching decision and are affected by earlier events in the game/series

annotations.causal_structure: Dynamic series with feedback: earlier possessions and opponent adjustments affect Z (late-game state), Z influences X (benching), and both Z and X influence Y (series win). The analysis conditions on a post-treatment-like event (survival/keeping the lead) when inferring the counterfactual outcome under do(X=keep).
annotations.key_insight: You cannot answer 'Would they still win if G played?' by restricting to worlds/games where the team 'kept the lead' (a downstream consequence of many factors intertwined with X). Conditioning on survival/lead-holding induces counterfactual selection bias and breaks cross-world comparability.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Early-game performance and opponent scouting updates shift late-game state Z (lead size, foul trouble, matchup). t1: Coach chooses X (bench/keep) based on Z. t2: Late possessions (also influenced by opponent counter-adjustments triggered by X) determine game outcomes, which aggregate to Y (series win).
conditional_answers: Answer if you (incorrectly) condition on games where the team kept the lead: keeping G in appears to 'cause' losses because you select a subset of trajectories where many unobserved favorable factors are already present. Answer if you instead define the counterfactual without conditioning on post-decision survival and model the dynamic policy/response: the effect of benching is not identified from these comparisons and could even reverse depending on opponent adaptation.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it answers a counterfactual query, Y_{x=keep} vs Y_{x=bench}, using comparisons that condition on an event that is not pre-treatment and not cross-world stable. In the actual series, the decision X is made in response to Z (lead size, foul trouble, matchup targeting, and opponent adjustments). Z is itself shaped by earlier within-game and within-series dynamics, and crucially, the department’s filter 'games where G was not benched and the team kept the lead' conditions on a downstream consequence of the same causal system that produces Y. This is counterfactual conditioning: it selects trajectories where the team already survived late-game variance, and that survival is influenced by both Z and factors correlated with X (e.g., opponent choosing to hunt G on switches, foul accumulation, or the coach shortening the rotation). Conditioning on such survival/lead-holding opens selection paths that distort the relationship between X and Y across worlds, so the observed association among the selected subset does not equal the causal effect of intervening to keep G in. Formally, the comparison mixes different underlying trajectories: P(Y|X=keep, survive/keep-lead) is not a valid estimator of P(Y|do(X=keep)) nor of the counterfactual Y_{x=keep} in the specific playoff games. Therefore, the data described cannot support the conclusion that benching G caused the series win, and the claimed counterfactual is not justified.

scenario: An NBA team evaluates whether giving a star player a scheduled rest game (a 'load management' night off) prevents injury later in the season. Analysts look at games where the player was listed as 'questionable' and either played or sat. They then ask a counterfactual question: for the games the player actually sat, would he have stayed healthy over the next 10 games if he had played instead? A report claims the answer is yes because, among the 'questionable' rest games, players who sat had fewer injuries afterward than players who played.
claim: If the star had played instead of resting on his 'questionable' night, he would still have remained uninjured over the next 10 games; therefore, resting did not causally prevent injury in those cases.

variables.X: Playing the 'questionable' game (1=played, 0=rested)
variables.Y: Injury occurrence within the next 10 games (1=injured, 0=not injured)
variables.Z: Latent short-term physical fragility at t0 (e.g., micro-tears/fatigue level) that influences both the decision to rest and the chance of injury

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y, with the counterfactual query comparing Y_{X=1} vs Y_{X=0} for the same individual; but Z is not fully observed and differs across the actual world (where X=0 occurred) and the hypothetical world (where X=1 is imposed).
annotations.key_insight: The counterfactual claim implicitly assumes the same underlying fragility Z would hold under both 'rest' and 'play' worlds, yet Z is precisely what drives both the rest decision and injury risk; without a model that pins down Z across worlds, the individual-level counterfactual is not identified from the observed comparison.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: staff observes signals of fragility Z and chooses X (play vs rest). t1..t10: accumulated load plus Z determines Y (injury/no injury). The counterfactual asks about Y in t1..t10 under the alternate X at t0 while holding the same player fixed.
conditional_answers: Answer is 'No' if the rest decision is driven by unmeasured fragility (Z) that also affects subsequent injury risk; the observed post-rest injury rate cannot be interpreted as the player's counterfactual injury risk had he played. Answer could change only if Z were fully measured and a valid counterfactual model (e.g., structural equations or randomized rest assignment) justified transporting Z across worlds.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is a Level-3 statement about an individual counterfactual: it asserts a value of Y_{X=1} for cases where X=0 actually occurred. However, treatment assignment X is not exogenous: the medical/coaching staff uses information about latent fragility Z (micro-injury, fatigue) to decide rest, so Z is a common cause of X and Y. In the observed world where the player rested (X=0), we learn that staff likely perceived high Z. The report then compares those rested cases to played cases, but played cases tend to have lower Z. This mixes different underlying states and does not identify Y_{X=1} for the rested individuals. Moreover, the counterfactual requires a cross-world linkage: it assumes the same Z relevant to injury risk would persist under the hypothetical intervention X=1, yet Z is precisely the variable that is partially revealed by the actual decision and may evolve differently if the player had played (additional load could amplify the fragility state). Therefore the inference from observed associations to the stated counterfactual is invalid; the conclusion that 'resting did not causally prevent injury in those cases' is not warranted.

scenario: A rugby team notices an increase in missed tackles. The coach implements a 'remedial tackling school' (extra practice) for any player who misses more than 2 tackles in a game. At the end of the season, data shows that players who attended tackling school had a higher missed-tackle rate in subsequent games than those who never attended. The coach concludes the school is useless.
claim: Sending players to remedial tackling school (X) causes them to miss more tackles (Y).

variables.X: Assignment to Remedial Tackling School
variables.Y: Missed Tackles in subsequent games
variables.Z: Player defensive ability / poor form

annotations.causal_structure: Z (Poor ability) causes X (Assignment to school) and Z causes Y (Continued missed tackles). X is assigned based on prior Y (indication of Z).
annotations.key_insight: This is confounding by indication. The 'treatment' is assigned exclusively to the 'sick' (bad defenders). Comparing them to the 'healthy' (good defenders) will always make the treatment look bad unless you adjust for baseline ability.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Y(t-1) -> Z -> X(t) -> Y(t+1). Feedback loop.
conditional_answers: No. The players sent to school are the ones who are bad at tackling. They would likely have missed *even more* without the school. The proper comparison is their performance vs. their own baseline, or vs. bad tacklers who were NOT sent to school.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim fails due to Confounding by Indication (or Time-Varying Confounding). The assignment mechanism for X is dependent on Z (poor prior performance). Thus, the group X=1 is inherently comprised of weaker defenders than the group X=0. The observed higher error rate in Y is a reflection of Z, not the causal effect of X. To identify the effect, one must control for prior missed tackle rates.

scenario: An NBA analytics intern analyzes one season of play-by-play data and finds that in-game scoring runs (e.g., 10–0 stretches) are strongly associated with the next two minutes of improved defensive performance by the team on the run (lower opponent field-goal percentage and fewer paint touches). The intern concludes that “momentum” from a scoring run causes better defense immediately afterward.
claim: The observed link between a team going on a scoring run and better defense in the next two minutes is not necessarily causal; it can be explained by a shared underlying factor like lineup/energy changes that drive both the run and the subsequent defensive metrics.

variables.X: Occurrence of a scoring run by a team (e.g., a 10–0 run within a short window)
variables.Y: Defensive performance in the following two minutes (e.g., opponent FG% allowed, opponent paint touches, forced turnovers)
variables.Z: Lineup/energy shift (e.g., a key defensive substitution, opponent fatigue, or a tactical change) that affects both the chance of a run and subsequent defense

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y, creating an association between X and Y even if X has no direct causal effect on Y.
annotations.key_insight: At Pearl L1, association alone cannot distinguish 'momentum causes defense' from a backdoor path where a hidden tactical/lineup factor causes both the run and better defense.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (substitution/tactical adjustment/opponent fatigue) increases the probability of X during t0–t1 (scoring run) and also improves Y during t1–t2 (next two minutes defense).
conditional_answers: Answer if the analyst only has observational play-by-play and does not measure lineup/tactics/fatigue: treat the claim as valid skepticism about causation at L1 due to omitted-variable confounding.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are at Pearl Level 1 (association), so we are only licensed to talk about statistical dependence, not effects of interventions. The data show an association between X (a scoring run) and Y (better defense afterward). However, a plausible causal graph is Z -> X and Z -> Y, where Z is an omitted factor such as a defensive lineup change, a timeout adjustment, or opponent fatigue. Under this structure, the X–Y association can arise entirely from the open backdoor path X <- Z -> Y, even if there is no direct causal arrow X -> Y. Therefore, the intern’s causal story ('momentum causes better defense') is not justified from association alone, and it is valid to conclude that the observed relationship is not necessarily causal and may be confounded by Z.

scenario: An NBA team pilots a new 'high-intensity closeout' defensive scheme for part of the season. The coaching staff evaluates the scheme by comparing opponents' 3-point percentage in games where the scheme was used versus games where it was not. They then run a regression that also controls for the team's recorded 'defensive effort score' (a wearable/vision-based metric capturing sprint distance, closeout speed, and contest frequency during the game). The regression shows the scheme has no effect (or even a slightly harmful effect) on opponents' 3P%, so the staff concludes the scheme doesn't work.
claim: Because the scheme's coefficient becomes near zero (or positive) after controlling for defensive effort score, implementing the high-intensity closeout scheme does not reduce opponents' 3-point percentage.

variables.X: Implementing the high-intensity closeout defensive scheme in a game (yes/no)
variables.Y: Opponents' 3-point shooting percentage in that game
variables.Z: Defensive effort score during the game (wearable/vision-based intensity metric)

annotations.causal_structure: X affects Z (scheme increases defensive effort/closeout intensity), and Z affects Y (higher effort reduces opponents' 3P%). There may also be additional backdoor paths into X (e.g., opponent strength or schedule), but the key mistake is conditioning on Z, a mediator on the causal path from X to Y.
