annotations.key_insight: Controlling for a mediator (defensive effort) blocks part (or all) of the causal effect of the scheme, so the adjusted regression estimates a 'direct effect' that is not the total effect and can be misleading.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Coach chooses scheme X for the game plan. t1: Scheme changes in-game behavior and intensity Z (more closeouts/contests). t2: Opponent shot quality and makes change, producing Y (3P%).
conditional_answers: Answer if the goal is the total effect of adopting the scheme in real games: do NOT adjust for Z; instead adjust for true pre-treatment confounders (e.g., opponent shooting quality, lineup health, rest, home/away). Answer if the goal is the controlled direct effect of the scheme holding effort fixed: then adjusting for Z is relevant, but that is a different estimand than 'does the scheme work overall?'.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it treats an estimate conditioned on Z as evidence about the causal effect of X on Y. In the assumed data-generating process, Z is downstream of X: the scheme X is designed precisely to increase closeout intensity and contest frequency Z, which in turn reduces opponents' 3P% Y. Conditioning on Z blocks the mediated pathway X -> Z -> Y, removing the very mechanism through which X is expected to work. Therefore, the regression coefficient of X after adjusting for Z does not identify the total causal effect of intervening on X; it targets a direct effect of X not through Z (and may even flip sign depending on residual pathways and measurement noise). To evaluate whether implementing the scheme reduces opponents' 3P% in practice, one must estimate the total effect of do(X), which requires avoiding mediator adjustment and instead blocking only pre-treatment backdoor confounding into X and Y. Hence, concluding 'the scheme doesn't work' from a model that controls for defensive effort is a mediator adjustment error at Pearl Level 2.

scenario: A professional soccer club considers introducing a high-intensity interval training (HIIT) block during preseason. Analysts compare players who were assigned to HIIT versus those kept on a moderate conditioning plan and find that HIIT-assigned players have higher in-season injury rates. The head coach concludes HIIT causes injuries and wants to ban it. However, the club’s performance staff note that assignment to HIIT was not random: players with lower baseline aerobic fitness and higher body-fat percentage were preferentially assigned to HIIT to catch them up.
claim: If the club intervenes to assign all players to the HIIT preseason block (instead of the moderate plan), the injury rate will increase.

variables.X: Preseason conditioning assignment (HIIT block vs moderate conditioning plan)
variables.Y: In-season soft-tissue injury incidence (e.g., hamstring/groin strains within first 12 matchweeks)
variables.Z: Baseline fitness/risk profile used for assignment (e.g., VO2max, body-fat %, prior soft-tissue injury history)

annotations.causal_structure: Z affects both X and Y: baseline fitness/risk (Z) influences assignment to HIIT (X) and independently increases injury risk (Y). There may also be a direct effect X->Y, but the observational association is biased unless the backdoor path X<-Z->Y is blocked.
annotations.key_insight: The observed higher injury rate among HIIT-assigned players is driven by their worse baseline risk profile; after blocking the backdoor via Z, the causal effect of assigning HIIT to everyone can be estimated and need not be harmful.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z measured at t0 (start of preseason) influences X at t1 (conditioning assignment). X at t1 affects load exposure through t2 (preseason). Y realized at t3 (in-season weeks 1–12).
conditional_answers: Answer is Yes if Z is fully measured and adjusted (or assignment is randomized) such that the backdoor path X<-Z->Y is blocked; otherwise the causal claim cannot be supported from the raw association.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are asked about an intervention: do(X=HIIT for all) versus do(X=moderate). The naive comparison P(Y|X=HIIT) vs P(Y|X=moderate) is not causal because X is confounded by Z: players with poorer baseline fitness and higher prior-injury risk are more likely to be assigned HIIT (X<-Z), and the same Z increases injury risk (Z->Y). This opens an unblocked backdoor path X<-Z->Y, so the observational association can show higher injuries under HIIT even if HIIT is neutral or beneficial. Under Pearl Level 2, the causal estimand is P(Y|do(X=x)), which can be identified by blocking the backdoor with Z (assuming Z is pre-treatment and sufficiently captures the assignment drivers): P(Y|do(X=x)) = sum_z P(Y|X=x, Z=z)P(Z=z). If, after proper adjustment for Z (or randomization), the estimated interventional risk is higher under HIIT for the same Z-distribution, then the claim 'assigning HIIT to all increases injuries' is valid. Thus the correct causal reasoning supports the claim under the stated backdoor-blocking condition, making the claim a valid L2 intervention statement rather than an association-based mistake.

scenario: An NBA analytics staff evaluates a new in-game “momentum timeout” rule: whenever the opponent goes on an 8–0 run, the coach must call a timeout immediately. The team piloted this rule for half a season. In retrospective data, games in which the coach called a momentum timeout show worse point differential over the next 5 possessions than games with no momentum timeout. The staff concludes the rule is harmful and recommends abandoning it.
claim: Calling a momentum timeout (X) causes the team to perform worse in the next 5 possessions (Y), so the momentum-timeout rule should be scrapped.

variables.X: Calling a momentum timeout immediately after an opponent 8–0 run (pilot rule applied in-game)
variables.Y: Team point differential over the next 5 possessions after the run/timeout window
variables.Z: Severity of the negative game state that triggers the timeout: underlying opponent surge intensity (e.g., defensive breakdowns, fatigue, foul trouble, hot shooting) that both prompts the timeout and predicts continued short-term underperformance

annotations.causal_structure: Z (surge severity) increases the likelihood of X (timeout is called) and independently worsens Y (next-possessions differential). Observed association between X and Y is driven by the fact that X is deployed in response to deteriorating outcomes already in motion (incipient Y).
annotations.key_insight: The timeout is not assigned exogenously; it is a reactive intervention triggered by an ongoing collapse. Without modeling the trigger process (Z) and the pre-timeout trajectory, the post-timeout comparison conflates the effect of the timeout with the effect of the underlying surge that caused it.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Opponent run begins and underlying surge severity Z intensifies; t1: Coach calls momentum timeout X because the run is occurring; t2: Next 5 possessions outcome Y reflects both the lingering effect of Z and any true causal effect of X.
conditional_answers: If timeouts were randomly mandated at the same game states (same score margin, time, lineup, foul trouble, and pre-run trajectory) regardless of surge severity, then a causal estimate of X on Y could be identified; under the observational pilot, the negative association is not evidence of harm.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim treats the observed post-timeout underperformance as the causal effect of calling the timeout. But X is a reactive intervention: it is triggered by an adverse, fast-moving game process. Formally, the trigger severity Z is a common cause of both X and Y: Z -> X (coaches call timeouts when the run is severe) and Z -> Y (severe runs tend to persist because they reflect fatigue, matchup problems, foul trouble, or opponent hot shooting). Therefore the backdoor path X <- Z -> Y is open, so P(Y|do(X)) is not identified by P(Y|X) in the pilot data. Moreover, because the run is already underway at t0, part of what is measured in Y is the continuation of that same deterioration that caused X, making the naive comparison especially biased against timeouts. The correct conclusion is only that timeouts are more likely to be called in situations that are already going badly, not that calling a timeout causes worse subsequent performance.

scenario: A basketball analytics blog analyzes 200 NBA games and reports that teams that call an early timeout (within the first 6 minutes) have a higher probability of winning than teams that do not. The blog concludes that taking an early timeout is a winning strategy and recommends coaches “burn one early” after any small run by the opponent.
claim: Calling an early timeout increases a team's chance of winning the game.

variables.X: Calling an early timeout within the first 6 minutes of the game
variables.Y: Winning the game (binary win/loss)
variables.Z: Early-game latent game state (e.g., unexpected opponent run, foul trouble, injury scare, matchup exploit discovered, pregame plan mismatch) that both triggers the timeout decision and predicts eventual win probability

annotations.causal_structure: Z (early latent game state) influences X (early timeout) and also influences Y (win probability); additionally, coaches' expectations about Y based on early signals feed into the decision to call X, creating outcome-driven selection into the 'early timeout' group.
annotations.key_insight: The timeout is not randomly assigned; it is chosen in response to early signals that already change the expected likelihood of winning, so the observed association X–Y can reflect reactive decision-making rather than a causal effect of timeouts.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (first few minutes: runs, foul trouble, matchup reads) affects X at t0 (timeout called) and also affects Y at t1 (final result). Coaches also form an updated belief about Y at t0 from Z, and that belief helps determine X at t0.
conditional_answers: If early timeouts were effectively randomized conditional on the early-game state Z (or if Z were fully measured and adjusted for), then a remaining positive association could support the claim. If Z is unmeasured or only partially captured (score margin alone), the association is consistent with reverse causation/outcome-driven selection and does not identify a causal effect.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: At Pearl Level 1 we are only given an association between X (early timeout) and Y (winning). The claim is causal, but the observed correlation can be generated by a reverse-causation/selection story: coaches call X because early information Z makes them update expectations about Y (e.g., they see a dangerous mismatch, foul trouble, or a tactical error) and react. Since Z also affects Y directly (those early conditions change win probability), the group with X=1 is not comparable to the group with X=0. Without knowing whether Z is fully observed and whether the comparison is made within levels of Z (or a valid design that breaks the dependence between X and Z), the direction and magnitude of the causal effect of X on Y are not identifiable from the association alone. Therefore the causal conclusion may be true or false, but the evidence described is insufficient, so the correct label is Ambiguous.

scenario: A soccer club pilots an AI-driven training-load system. The system flags players as 'high risk' based on recent fatigue markers and micro-injury reports, and the coaching staff responds by reducing those players' weekly high-intensity running (HIR) volume and giving them extra recovery sessions. At season’s end, the performance department compares injury rates between players who received load reductions versus those who did not, and finds the load-reduction group had more soft-tissue injuries. The club concludes the AI load-reduction policy causes injuries and considers abandoning it.
claim: Reducing high-intensity running volume for flagged players (X) increases the probability of soft-tissue injury (Y), so the AI-driven load-reduction policy is harmful.

variables.X: Intervention: coach-imposed reduction in weekly high-intensity running volume / extra recovery assigned after the AI flags a player
variables.Y: Outcome: subsequent soft-tissue injury incidence over the next 4–8 weeks (e.g., hamstring strain)
variables.Z: Time-varying confounder: evolving latent injury risk/fatigue status (captured partially by soreness, prior minor strains, sleep debt, match congestion) that both triggers load reduction and independently increases injury risk

annotations.causal_structure: Z(t) (fatigue/latent injury risk) influences both X(t) (load reduction decision) and Y(t+1) (injury). Past Y(t) and micro-injuries feed into future Z(t+1) and also into future X(t+1). Thus treatment assignment is reactive to a time-evolving state that is itself affected by prior outcomes and prior training exposure.
annotations.key_insight: Because coaches intervene more when risk is already high, naive comparisons of treated vs untreated conflate the effect of the intervention with the underlying escalating risk process; standard adjustment can also fail if it conditions on post-treatment risk states affected by earlier treatment.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: baseline fitness/history -> Z0. t1: match congestion/soreness updates Z1; staff applies X1 (reduce HIR) in response to Z1. t2: micro-injury or recovery updates Z2 (partly affected by X1); staff applies X2 based on Z2. t3: injury Y3 occurs depending on Z2, X1, X2, and exposures.
conditional_answers: Answer if you (incorrectly) treat the observed treated-vs-untreated difference as causal: you would say X increases Y. Answer if you properly account for time-varying confounding (e.g., with a marginal structural model / g-formula using correct treatment and censoring models): the harmful conclusion is not supported; the direction could reverse or become null once Z(t) is handled appropriately.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it treats an observed association under a reactive policy as the causal effect of an intervention. Here X is not randomly assigned: coaches reduce load precisely when Z is high. Z is a time-varying confounder that both (i) causes X at each decision point (high-risk players are more likely to be assigned load reduction) and (ii) causes Y (high-risk players are more likely to be injured regardless of what the staff does). Therefore the backdoor path X <- Z -> Y is open, and the treated group is selected to be intrinsically higher risk even before considering any effect of X. Moreover, Z evolves over time and is itself influenced by prior training and minor injury events; past outcomes and exposures affect future treatment decisions, creating treatment-confounder feedback. Naively comparing injury rates between those who received load reduction and those who did not estimates a mixture of (a) baseline and evolving risk differences and (b) any causal effect of X, so the sign of the difference cannot be interpreted as the sign of the causal effect. To identify the causal effect of implementing the load-reduction policy, one must model the sequential decision process and appropriately adjust for Z(t) without inducing bias from conditioning on post-treatment variables (e.g., via g-methods). Hence the conclusion that the policy is harmful does not follow from the reported comparison.

scenario: An NBA team pilots an AI-driven in-game substitution policy. The model recommends earlier substitutions (shorter stints) when a player’s real-time fatigue score crosses a threshold. Coaches follow the policy, and the analytics department reports that games with earlier substitutions have a lower late-game defensive rating (better defense) than games with longer stints. A skeptic argues this is just because coaches substitute early when the opponent is weaker or when the team is already controlling the game. The team proposes a causal estimate: what would happen to late-game defense if they intervened to enforce earlier substitutions, regardless of game context?
claim: If the team intervenes to enforce earlier substitutions (shorter stints) for starters, late-game defensive performance will improve on average, even after properly adjusting for pre-substitution game state and player quality.

variables.X: Intervention: enforce earlier substitutions / shorter stints for starters (e.g., cap continuous minutes per stint, triggered by fatigue threshold) during the first three quarters
variables.Y: Outcome: late-game defensive performance (e.g., opponent points per 100 possessions in the last 6 minutes, or late-game defensive rating)
variables.Z: Pre-intervention confounders: baseline defender quality and matchup difficulty; plus time-varying game state measured before the substitution decision (score margin, opponent lineup strength, pace, foul trouble, and pre-substitution fatigue score)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (player quality, matchup difficulty, and pre-substitution game state/fatigue) affects both X (coach chooses earlier substitutions) and Y (late-game defense). Additionally, past fatigue and game state influence substitution timing, and substitution timing influences subsequent fatigue and later game state, creating time-varying confounding that must be handled with a sequential (g-formula / MSM) adjustment rather than a single regression.
annotations.key_insight: The causal effect of enforcing earlier substitutions is identifiable at L2 if we adjust only for pre-decision (history) variables that jointly drive substitution choices and late-game defense, using a longitudinal causal approach that respects time order; doing so blocks the backdoor paths without conditioning on post-treatment variables.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: baseline player quality/matchup difficulty set; t1: early-game possessions generate fatigue and game state; t2: substitution decision X made using fatigue/game state history; t3: substitution changes subsequent fatigue and lineup continuity; t4: late-game defense Y realized.
conditional_answers: Answer is Yes if the analysis uses only pre-substitution history (including time-varying fatigue and score/matchup before each decision) and applies an appropriate longitudinal adjustment (e.g., g-computation or marginal structural models) to address time-varying confounding; the claim would become Ambiguous/No if it instead controls for post-substitution mediators like minutes played after the decision, fourth-quarter fatigue after the policy, or lineup continuity that are themselves affected by X.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are asked about an L2 interventional quantity: the average change in late-game defense Y under an enforced substitution policy do(X=earlier stints) versus do(X=longer stints). In the observational data, X is not randomized: coaches choose substitution timing based on a history of variables Z that include baseline defender quality/matchup difficulty and time-varying pre-decision game state and fatigue. Those same Z variables also causally influence Y, so the naive association between X and Y mixes the causal effect with backdoor paths X <- Z -> Y. However, the claim is that the causal effect remains after properly adjusting for pre-decision Z. Under the stated causal structure, if we condition (sequentially) on the full pre-substitution history at each decision point—i.e., the variables that the coach used and that also predict late-game defense—then the backdoor paths from X to Y are blocked without conditioning on variables caused by X. Because fatigue and game state are time-varying confounders affected by earlier play and affecting later substitution decisions, a single cross-sectional adjustment can be biased; but a longitudinal identification strategy (g-formula/MSM with inverse probability weights) correctly accounts for this time-varying confounding. Given that the claim explicitly requires such proper adjustment and respects temporal ordering (only pre-decision Z), the interventional effect of enforcing earlier substitutions is identifiable and the conclusion that do(X) improves Y is a valid causal claim in this setup.

scenario: A baseball team instructs hitters to increase their 'launch angle' (swing uppercut) to hit more home runs. Analytics compares hitters who adopted the new swing vs. those who didn't. They run a regression controlling for 'Exit Velocity' (how hard the ball is hit) to isolate the effect of the angle. They find that after controlling for Exit Velocity, the new swing results in *fewer* hits. They recommend scrapping the swing change.
claim: Increasing launch angle (X) causes worse batting performance (Y) because the effect is negative when controlling for Exit Velocity (Z).

variables.X: Adopting High Launch Angle Swing
variables.Y: Batting Performance (Home Runs/Hits)
variables.Z: Exit Velocity (Speed of ball off bat)

annotations.causal_structure: X (Swing change) -> Z (Exit Velocity) -> Y (Home Runs). Mechanics changes often sacrifice contact quality (Z) to get angle (X). Z is a mediator.
annotations.key_insight: If the new swing causes players to hit the ball softer (lowers Z), that is part of the causal effect. Controlling for Z asks 'What is the effect of the angle if they hit it just as hard?', which ignores the trade-off inherent in the mechanics.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: X adopted t0 -> Z observed on hits -> Y recorded.
conditional_answers: No. The total effect of X on Y must allow Z to vary. If X lowers Z, and low Z lowers Y, then X lowers Y *through* Z. Controlling for Z blocks the mechanism.
label: No
correct_reasoning: This is a Mediator Adjustment Error. The swing change (X) likely affects how hard the ball is hit (Z). Z is on the causal path X -> Z -> Y. By controlling for Z, the analysts are estimating the Direct Effect (effect of angle holding power constant). However, if the new swing mechanically reduces power, the Total Effect (which includes the loss of power) is the relevant metric for the policy decision. The analysis blocks the negative pathway, potentially misrepresenting the real-world outcome, or finding a 'direct' effect that doesn't matter if the power loss is inevitable.

scenario: A tennis player develops mild wrist soreness during a tournament week. The coach decides to skip the optional pre-match heavy topspin practice session and instead does only light hitting and mobility work. The player wins the match but later that night the wrist pain flares and the player withdraws from the next round. A commentator claims the coach's decision to skip heavy topspin practice caused the withdrawal because the wrist 'was going to flare anyway' and the player 'should have kept the usual routine' to maintain match sharpness. The team asks a performance analyst a counterfactual question: for this specific player and week, would the player still have withdrawn if the coach had not skipped the heavy topspin practice session?
claim: If the coach had not skipped heavy topspin practice (X=1 instead of X=0), the player would not have withdrawn the next day (Y would have been 0).

variables.X: Coach decision to skip heavy topspin practice before the match (X=0 skip; X=1 do the session as usual)
variables.Y: Player withdraws from the next-round match due to wrist pain flare (Y=1 withdraw; Y=0 does not withdraw)
variables.Z: Latent wrist tissue vulnerability/inflammation trajectory and pain tolerance that week (unobserved, affects both the coach's decision and the probability of next-day flare/withdrawal)

annotations.causal_structure: Z influences X (coach reacts to perceived soreness/vulnerability) and Z influences Y (underlying inflammation drives flare/withdrawal). The counterfactual query compares Y under X=1 vs X=0 for the same individual, but Z is not held fixed across worlds because Z itself is partially inferred/selected based on observed actions and symptoms.
annotations.key_insight: For an individual-level counterfactual, you cannot conclude the effect of changing X without a model of how the unobserved vulnerability Z would have been in the alternative world; using observed soreness/decision as evidence about Z creates cross-world confounding.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: underlying wrist vulnerability/inflammation Z develops and is partially observed as soreness; t1: coach chooses X (skip or not) based on perceived risk; t2: player competes; t3: wrist flare evolves overnight; t4: withdrawal Y is decided next day.
conditional_answers: Answer is identifiable only if (i) Z is measured well enough (e.g., imaging/biomarkers + standardized pain reports) to be conditioned on, or (ii) there is a credible exogenous source of variation in X (e.g., random assignment of practice protocol, or a scheduling shock unrelated to Z), or (iii) a validated structural model links practice load to next-day flare while specifying how Z evolves under each X.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: The claim is a counterfactual statement about the same player in two possible worlds: one where X=0 (skip practice, observed) and one where X=1 (do practice, unobserved). The problem is that the coach's action X is not assigned independently; it is chosen in response to perceived soreness and risk, which are manifestations of an underlying vulnerability Z. That same Z also causally increases the probability of a next-day flare and withdrawal Y. Therefore, observing X=0 provides evidence that Z was high in the actual world (the coach skipped because risk seemed elevated). When we ask what would have happened under X=1, we implicitly need to know what Z would have been in that alternative world, but Z is unobserved and also partly 'diagnosed' from the very decision X and symptoms that occurred. This is cross-world confounding: the distribution of Z relevant to the counterfactual world cannot be recovered from the factual world without additional assumptions or measurements. Consequently, we cannot logically determine whether Y would have been 0 under X=1; it could be that doing heavy topspin practice would have worsened the flare (increasing Y), or that maintaining routine would have reduced stiffness and prevented withdrawal (decreasing Y), or that Z was so severe that Y would occur regardless. Without identifiability conditions (measured Z, exogenous variation in X, or a structural model), the counterfactual claim is not warranted, hence the correct label is Ambiguous.

scenario: An NBA team introduces an in-game tablet-based shot-selection assistant that recommends taking more corner 3s and fewer mid-range pull-ups. The assistant is rolled out mid-season and is used more heavily when the team is trailing late in games. The analytics department estimates the assistant's causal effect by comparing points per possession (PPP) in possessions where the assistant was used vs. not used, controlling for the current score margin and time remaining. They find that assistant use is associated with lower PPP and conclude the tool hurts offense, recommending it be abandoned.
claim: If the team forces players to use the shot-selection assistant (X) on possessions, it will reduce points per possession (Y), so the assistant should be discontinued.

variables.X: Mandated use of the in-game shot-selection assistant on a possession
variables.Y: Offensive points per possession on that possession (or the next set of possessions in the same late-game segment)
variables.Z: Game state and coaching response dynamics: trailing/clock pressure and defensive intensity that both increase assistant use and reduce scoring efficiency

annotations.causal_structure: Time-varying game state Z_t (score margin, time remaining, opponent defensive pressure) affects both X_t (assistant use) and Y_t (PPP). Also, past outcomes Y_{t-1} and past choices X_{t-1} update Z_t (teams trail more after missed shots; opponents adjust coverage after observed shot mix), creating treatment-confounder feedback where Z_t is itself affected by prior X and Y.
annotations.key_insight: Controlling for a time-varying game state that is simultaneously a confounder and is influenced by prior outcomes/treatments can bias L2 causal effect estimates; without a properly specified dynamic causal model (e.g., g-methods), the sign of the estimated effect is not identified from the described analysis.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Early possessions yield outcomes Y_{t0} that influence score margin/urgency Z_{t1}. t1: Z_{t1} increases likelihood of assistant use X_{t1} (coach uses it more when trailing). t1: Z_{t1} also directly depresses Y_{t1} via opponent defensive intensity and end-of-clock shot quality. t2: Observed shot mix under X_{t1} changes opponent adjustments, affecting Z_{t2} and subsequent Y_{t2}.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous: If assistant use were randomized within comparable game states (or identified via a valid instrument or a correct longitudinal causal method with measured Z over time), the causal effect could be estimated; under the current observational comparison with naive adjustment for score/time, the direction and magnitude of the intervention effect remain unidentified.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: We are asked to evaluate an interventional claim: what would happen to Y if we set X=1 (mandated assistant use) versus X=0. The observed association between X and Y is not sufficient because X is assigned adaptively in response to the evolving game state. Specifically, Z_t (trailing, clock pressure, opponent defensive intensity) is a backdoor confounder for the effect of X_t on Y_t because it causally influences both assistant use and scoring efficiency. However, Z_t is not a baseline confounder: it is updated by prior outcomes and prior treatments (missed shots and earlier assistant-driven shot mix change the score margin and defensive adjustments). Therefore, conditioning on Z_t in a standard regression can either (i) fail to block the relevant backdoor paths created by treatment-confounder feedback, or (ii) introduce bias by adjusting for a variable on a causal pathway from earlier X to later Y (and by opening paths through variables affected by prior treatment). Because the described analysis does not specify a correct longitudinal identification strategy (e.g., sequential ignorability with full measurement of Z history and appropriate g-computation/IPW/MSMs), we cannot deduce the sign of E[Y|do(X=1)]-E[Y|do(X=0)] from the reported negative association. Hence the conclusion that the assistant 'hurts offense' under intervention is not warranted, but neither can we assert the opposite without additional design/assumptions; the correct label is Ambiguous.

scenario: An NBA analytics intern claims that a veteran guard's late-game three-point percentage is lower in games where the coach "shortens the rotation" (plays starters heavier minutes). The intern concludes the heavy-minutes strategy causes the veteran to shoot worse late. As supporting evidence, they point to games where the coach shortened the rotation and the veteran shot poorly in the last 5 minutes. They then make a counterfactual statement: in those same games, if the coach had not shortened the rotation, the veteran would have shot better late.
claim: In the games where the coach shortened the rotation, the veteran guard would have had a higher late-game three-point percentage if the coach had not shortened the rotation.

variables.X: Coach shortens the rotation (starters play heavier minutes) in a given game
variables.Y: Veteran guard's last-5-minutes three-point percentage in that game
variables.Z: Game state pressure and opponent strength in that game (e.g., close score, elite defense, high leverage possessions), which affects both the coach's decision and shot difficulty

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y; additionally, analysts implicitly condition on high-leverage late-game situations where the veteran is on the floor (a post-treatment selection linked to both X and Y). The counterfactual compares worlds while holding fixed a selected subset of possessions that would differ under do(X).
annotations.key_insight: The counterfactual is conditioned on a post-selection event (observed late-game possessions with the veteran taking threes) that would not be the same if the rotation were different, so the comparison mixes different sets of games/possessions across worlds.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Z (close game/strong opponent) realized -> t1: coach chooses X (shorten rotation) -> t2: fatigue/shot difficulty and lineup context determine which late possessions occur -> t3: Y (late-game 3P%) observed only on the realized set of late possessions.
conditional_answers: Answer is No if the counterfactual is meant within the same observed late-game possessions (conditioning on them). It could become Ambiguous/estimable only if we redefine Y as a well-defined game-level outcome under both policies (e.g., expected late-game 3P% over all possible possessions under each policy) and measure/adjust for Z with a valid causal model.
label: No
correct_reasoning: This is an L3 counterfactual claim: it asserts Y would be higher in the same games under do(X=0) than under the factual X=1. The reasoning fails because it conditions on a post-treatment selection: the observed late-game threes (and even the existence/number of such attempts) are partly downstream of X via minute allocation, fatigue, and lineup/possession structure. Under do(X=0), the set of late-game possessions in which the veteran attempts threes would generally change (different substitution patterns, different matchups, possibly different game leverage), so 'the veteran's last-5-minutes 3P% in those games' is not being compared on the same underlying sample across worlds. Formally, the claim implicitly compares Y in the factual world given S=1 (selected late-game attempt set) to Y in the counterfactual world while holding S fixed, i.e., a cross-world conditioning on a variable affected by X. That is counterfactual conditioning/selection bias: the event we condition on (the realized late-game shot set) is not invariant to the intervention. Therefore the stated counterfactual conclusion is not justified from the observed association, and the claim is flawed.

scenario: A Tour de France cycling team implements a power-output cap. Riders are told not to exceed 400 watts on climbs to preserve energy for the final week. Analysts find that on days where riders adhered to the cap, their climb times were slower than on days they exceeded the cap. They conclude the cap makes riders slower.
claim: Enforcing the power cap (X) causes slower climb times (Y) compared to letting riders push as hard as they want.

variables.X: Adherence to power cap (riding < 400W)
variables.Y: Climb time
variables.Z: Rider Fatigue / Illness (Time-varying)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (Fatigue) influences X (Riders adhere to the cap easily when they are too tired to push hard) and Z influences Y (Fatigue makes them slow). Conversely, when Z is low (fresh), riders ignore the cap (X=0) and go fast (Y low).
annotations.key_insight: Compliance with the cap is often involuntary; tired riders fall under the cap naturally. Comparing cap-adherent days to non-adherent days conflates strategy with physical capability.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z (fatigue) varies day to day. Z affects ability to exceed X.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous. Unless we know if the rider was *holding back* (active compliance) vs. *unable to push* (passive compliance due to fatigue), we cannot judge the policy.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: The observational comparison is confounded by Z (physical capacity). Riders are more likely to record 'capped' wattage numbers when they physically cannot push harder (high Z). High Z also causes slow times. Therefore, the data mixes 'strategic capping' with 'exhaustion.' To evaluate the cap, one must compare days where the rider *could* have pushed harder but didn't (do(X)) against days where they did push harder.

scenario: An NBA analyst argues that a coach's mid-game timeout 'caused' a scoring run. In the actual game, the team was down 14, called a timeout, and then went on a 12–0 run. The analyst claims: 'If the coach had not called the timeout, the run would not have happened.' However, the coach tends to call timeouts precisely when the team is playing poorly and the opponent's momentum is high. The same underlying game state (fatigue, defensive breakdowns, opponent hot shooting) also predicts both the timeout and what would have happened next even without the timeout (mean reversion and opponent shot cooling).
claim: The timeout caused the 12–0 run; if the coach had not called the timeout, the run would not have happened.

variables.X: Calling a timeout at that moment (yes/no)
variables.Y: Subsequent scoring run in the next ~3 minutes (e.g., net points in that window)
variables.Z: Underlying game state at the moment of the timeout (opponent hot streak, defensive miscommunications, player fatigue, lineup matchups, and latent momentum/mean-reversion forces)

annotations.causal_structure: Z influences both X (coach calls timeout when Z is bad) and Y (Z also drives near-future scoring dynamics/mean reversion). The claim implicitly compares Y under X=1 vs Y under X=0 while letting Z differ across those worlds.
annotations.key_insight: The counterfactual 'no timeout' world is not identical in Z to the actual world; Z is a cross-world confounder because the same latent game state that triggered the timeout also affects what would have happened next.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Z (bad game state) realized; t0: coach chooses X=1 (timeout) because of Z; t1: Y (run in next minutes) occurs, partly because Z would have tended to revert regardless of X.
conditional_answers: If we could hold Z fixed at the same values across the X=1 and X=0 worlds (same fatigue, matchups, opponent shot quality) and randomize timeout timing, then we could estimate whether the timeout changes Y; without that, the observed run after timeouts is not evidence of causation.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is a counterfactual statement about Y(X=1) versus Y(X=0) for the same game situation, but it treats the actual post-timeout run as if it identifies Y(X=0) by simple imagination. In the data-generating story, Z causes X (timeouts are called when Z is unfavorable) and Z also causes Y (the same unfavorable state and its natural dynamics, including regression/mean reversion, affect subsequent scoring). Therefore Z is a confounder for the causal effect of X on Y. At Pearl Level 3, the key error is cross-world confounding: the analyst compares the observed Y under X=1 in a world where Z was severe enough to trigger a timeout to an implicit Y under X=0 in a different world where Z would not have been the same. Because Z is not held fixed across these worlds, the statement 'without the timeout, the run would not have happened' does not follow. The run could have occurred even under X=0 due to Z-driven reversion, so the causal conclusion is invalid.

scenario: An NBA team introduces a 'no mid-range shots' policy for its offense, instructing players to take only 3-pointers or shots at the rim. A front-office analyst estimates the policy effect by comparing points per possession (PPP) before vs. after the policy but also controls for 'average shot distance' in the regression to 'account for shot selection.' The analyst concludes the policy has no effect once shot distance is controlled.
claim: Controlling for average shot distance is inappropriate because it is a mediator caused by the no-mid-range policy; the correct estimate of the policy's total causal effect on PPP should not adjust for shot distance.

variables.X: Implementing a 'no mid-range shots' offensive policy (coach-mandated shot selection constraint)
variables.Y: Team offensive efficiency (points per possession) over subsequent games
variables.Z: Average shot distance / shot mix (share of 3PA and rim attempts), which is directly changed by the policy and transmits its effect to efficiency

annotations.causal_structure: X -> Z -> Y (policy changes shot mix/shot distance, which affects PPP). Potential baseline team quality can affect both Z and Y, but Z is also downstream of X once the policy is implemented.
annotations.key_insight: If the estimand is the total effect of the policy on PPP, adjusting for a post-treatment mediator (shot distance/shot mix) blocks the causal pathway and can bias the estimated effect toward zero or even flip its sign.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Team adopts policy X. t1: Players change shot mix/average shot distance Z. t2: Changed shot mix alters PPP Y over games following adoption.
conditional_answers: Answer if the goal is total effect: do NOT control for Z. Answer if the goal is a controlled direct effect (holding shot mix fixed): then controlling/fixing Z is relevant, but that is a different causal question than 'Does the policy improve PPP?'.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: The claim is valid because the question at Pearl Level 2 is an interventional one: compare Y under do(X=policy) versus do(X=no policy). In the causal graph, Z (average shot distance/shot mix) lies on the directed path from X to Y (X -> Z -> Y). Conditioning on Z when estimating the effect of X blocks this mediating path and therefore does not identify the total causal effect of the intervention; it instead targets something closer to a direct effect that excludes the mechanism through shot selection. Since the policy’s purpose is precisely to change shot selection, adjusting for Z removes the very channel through which X is expected to influence Y, producing an attenuated or null estimate even if the policy truly increases PPP. Therefore, to estimate the total effect of implementing the policy, one should not adjust for Z (a post-treatment mediator).

scenario: A tennis player tweaks their ankle in the second set. The coach considers retiring the player immediately versus letting them finish the match. Post-match, analysts argue about whether the player would have won if they had not retired, noting that the player retired only when the pain became severe.
claim: For this player, in the counterfactual world where they do not retire at that moment (X=play on), they would have been more likely to lose the match (Y=loss) than in the actual world where they retired (Y=recorded retirement), because playing on with a severe ankle tweak causally reduces performance.

variables.X: Decision at the retirement moment: play on instead of retiring (counterfactual intervention)
variables.Y: Match result (win vs loss; with retirement treated as not winning the match)
variables.Z: Ankle injury severity/pain level at the retirement moment (mechanism affecting both feasibility of playing and performance)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (injury severity) affects both X (whether the player can/chooses to continue) and Y (probability of winning). Conditioning the counterfactual question on the observed fact of retirement selects high-Z cases, which would bias naive comparisons between 'retired' and 'played on' worlds.
annotations.key_insight: You cannot infer the counterfactual 'would have won if they played on' by looking at outcomes among players who did play on, because the observed retirement event is itself selection on severe injury; however, within this specific case, severe injury provides a mechanistic reason that forcing X=play on would decrease performance and thus increase loss probability.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: ankle tweak occurs; t1: pain/severity Z escalates; t2: retirement decision X is made; t3: if X=play on, performance deteriorates leading to higher chance of Y=loss; if X=retire, match ends immediately as not a win.
conditional_answers: Answer if you condition on 'the player retired': you are selecting on high Z, so comparing to players who continued is invalid. Answer if you ask the individual counterfactual with Z fixed at its observed severe level: intervening to force X=play on would (via Z→performance) raise the chance of losing relative to the actual retired outcome.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: This is a Level-3 (counterfactual) claim about the same player: compare Y under the actual world (retire at t2) versus Y under the counterfactual intervention do(X=play on) at t2. The main trap is counterfactual conditioning: the fact that the player retired is not an exogenous label but a selection event driven by Z (injury severity), and Z also causally affects Y through impaired movement and shot quality. Therefore, population-level comparisons like 'players who retire would have lost anyway' are biased. However, the claim here is an individual counterfactual grounded in the observed mechanism: given the player’s severe Z at t2, forcing X=play on keeps the severe impairment in place and extends exposure to it, which causally reduces performance and increases the probability of Y=loss relative to the actual world where the match ends immediately without a win. Thus, under the stated causal structure (Z→X and Z→Y, and X affects Y through continued play under severe Z), the claim is valid.

scenario: A professional soccer club is considering an intervention: mandating that all players complete a standardized 12-minute post-match cold-water immersion (CWI) protocol after every match for the next 10 weeks. The performance staff has observational data showing that players who used CWI in the past had fewer missed training sessions the following week. However, CWI use was not randomly assigned: staff were more likely to recommend CWI to players who reported high muscle soreness and had high recent match load. The club proposes a causal estimate of the policy by comparing weeks with mandated CWI vs weeks without mandated CWI, using their historical monitoring data. They also plan to adjust for prior-week soreness and prior-week match load when estimating the effect of the mandate on missed training sessions.
claim: If the club mandates cold-water immersion after matches (X), it will causally reduce missed training sessions the next week (Y), provided we adjust for prior-week soreness and prior-week match load (Z) to block the backdoor paths.

variables.X: Mandated post-match cold-water immersion protocol (policy intervention applied to all players after each match)
variables.Y: Number of missed training sessions in the subsequent 7 days (availability/short-term injury or recovery-related absence)
variables.Z: Prior-week muscle soreness and prior-week match load (pre-intervention covariates that influence both the decision to use recovery modalities and subsequent missed sessions)

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y; X -> Y. Historically, staff recommendation (and player uptake) of CWI was influenced by prior soreness/load (Z), which also predicts missed sessions (Y). Under a mandate, X is set externally, and adjusting for pre-intervention Z blocks the backdoor path X <- Z -> Y.
annotations.key_insight: To estimate the causal effect of an intervention, you must block backdoor confounding using variables that precede the intervention; here, prior soreness/load are valid adjustment variables because they cause both treatment assignment and the outcome but are not caused by the mandate.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z measured at t0 (prior week) influences both the probability of applying/complying with recovery modalities (X at t1, post-match) and missed training sessions (Y at t2, following week). The mandate sets X at t1 irrespective of Z, but Z still predicts Y at t2 and must be adjusted for when using non-randomized historical comparisons.
conditional_answers: Answer if the adjustment set includes only pre-intervention variables (e.g., prior soreness/load) and excludes post-intervention variables (e.g., next-day soreness): then the causal claim is supported. If the analysis instead adjusts for post-match next-day soreness (a mediator) or conditions on compliance (only players who actually completed CWI), the causal claim would no longer be guaranteed.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are asked about an interventional claim: the effect of setting X (mandating CWI) on Y (missed training sessions). In the historical data, X is confounded because Z (prior-week soreness and match load) causally affects both X (staff recommend/players choose CWI more when Z is high) and Y (high Z increases risk of fatigue-related absence). This creates a backdoor path X <- Z -> Y that would bias any naive association between X and Y. However, Z is measured before the intervention and is not caused by X, so conditioning on Z is a valid backdoor adjustment. Under the causal graph Z -> X, Z -> Y, and X -> Y, adjusting for Z blocks the only backdoor path while leaving the causal path X -> Y intact. Therefore, the postulated comparison approximates the interventional quantity E[Y|do(X=1)] - E[Y|do(X=0)] (within the assumptions of no unmeasured confounding beyond Z and correct measurement), making the claim that mandating CWI causally reduces missed sessions valid in this setup.

scenario: A soccer club reviews last season and notices that matches where the head coach made an early substitution (before the 60th minute) had a lower win rate than matches with no early substitution. An analyst proposes a policy: "Stop making early subs; early subs cause losses." The club wants to treat this as an intervention rule for next season.
claim: If the coach intervenes to avoid early substitutions, the team will win more matches.

variables.X: Coach makes an early substitution (before minute 60) vs. does not
variables.Y: Match outcome (win vs. not win)
variables.Z: In-game adversity prior to minute 60 (e.g., conceding first, red card, key player injury, being tactically outmatched/low expected goals early)

annotations.causal_structure: Z worsens early match state and simultaneously triggers the coach to make an early substitution (Z -> X) and also directly reduces the chance of winning (Z -> Y). The observed association X -> Y is largely due to the coach reacting to Z, not X causing Y.
annotations.key_insight: The substitution is often a response to already-bad conditions; intervening to prevent the response does not remove the underlying adversity that drives losses.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0–t1 (first 60 minutes: conceding, red card, injury) increases likelihood of X at t1 (early sub), while Z also decreases Y at t2 (final result).
conditional_answers: Answer if the question is purely observational: Early substitutions are associated with lower win rates. Answer if the question is interventional (do(X=0)): Not enough evidence; the naive claim that do(X=0) increases wins is not justified because X is reactive to Z.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is a causal statement about an intervention: it asserts that setting X=0 (no early substitutions) will increase Y (wins). But the data pattern described is compatible with a reactive-intervention structure where Z (early adversity) causes both X and Y: Z -> X and Z -> Y. In that case, the observed P(Y|X=1) < P(Y|X=0) does not identify the causal effect P(Y|do(X=1)) vs P(Y|do(X=0)). When the coach makes an early substitution, it is typically because Z has already made the match harder to win; thus X is a symptom/response to Z rather than the root cause of losing. Intervening to prevent early substitutions (do(X=0)) would not eliminate Z, so it need not improve Y and could even worsen it by removing a corrective action. Therefore the conclusion that avoiding early substitutions will cause more wins is flawed under this causal structure, so the label is No.

scenario: An NBA team considers a policy change: mandate that every player completes a 15-minute dynamic warm-up routine immediately before entering the game. In prior seasons, players who reported doing dynamic warm-ups tended to have fewer soft-tissue injuries, but those players were also generally more disciplined and less injury-prone. The performance staff proposes evaluating the causal effect of the mandate using a randomized rollout: on randomly selected game-days, the team enforces the warm-up mandate for all active players; on other game-days, players follow the usual optional routine. The staff then compares next-day soft-tissue injury incidence between mandate days and non-mandate days.
claim: Because the warm-up mandate is randomly assigned by game-day, comparing injury rates between mandate days and non-mandate days identifies the causal effect of the mandate on next-day soft-tissue injuries (for the roster under this policy).

variables.X: Mandatory pre-entry 15-minute dynamic warm-up on a given game-day (enforced vs not enforced)
variables.Y: Next-day soft-tissue injury occurrence (e.g., hamstring/calf strain) among active players
variables.Z: Player baseline injury risk / discipline / conditioning that previously confounded observational warm-up–injury associations

annotations.causal_structure: Previously, Z -> X and Z -> Y created a backdoor path X <- Z -> Y in observational data. The randomized game-day rollout makes X independent of Z, blocking the backdoor without needing to measure Z.
annotations.key_insight: At L2, the question is about the effect of doing X (an intervention). Random assignment of X breaks the confounding link from Z, so the simple difference in outcomes estimates the causal effect under the rollout.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z (baseline risk) is set before the season (t-1). X (mandate enforced) is assigned at game-day t0. Y (soft-tissue injury) is measured at t1 (next day).
conditional_answers: Answer is valid if (i) the game-day assignment of X is truly random and enforced for all active players, (ii) injuries are measured consistently on mandate and non-mandate days, and (iii) there is no systematic interference across days that changes exposure classification (e.g., players secretly doing the routine on non-mandate days in a way correlated with injury risk).
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We want the causal estimand E[Y | do(X=1)] - E[Y | do(X=0)]. In observational data, the association E[Y | X=1] - E[Y | X=0] is biased because Z (baseline injury risk/discipline) affects both X and Y, leaving the backdoor path X <- Z -> Y open. Under the proposed design, X is assigned by random game-day rollout, so X ⟂ Z by design; equivalently, the intervention severs any arrow into X from Z. Therefore the backdoor path is blocked, and the post-intervention comparison of Y between mandate and non-mandate days identifies the causal effect of X on Y for this team under the rollout conditions (up to standard assumptions like consistent measurement and adherence). Hence the claim is valid.

scenario: A soccer club introduces an AI-driven hydration protocol during preseason: players must drink a prescribed electrolyte mix before and after every training session, enforced by staff check-ins. The club wants to know if implementing this protocol reduces soft-tissue injuries during the first half of the season. Analysts compare injury rates between the season with the protocol and the previous season, and they also consider adjusting for 'training load' (GPS distance and high-speed runs) because load strongly predicts injury.
claim: To estimate the causal effect of implementing the hydration protocol on soft-tissue injury risk, we should NOT adjust for training load if the protocol changes training load; instead, estimate the total effect of the protocol on injuries without conditioning on training load (or use mediation methods if decomposing pathways).

variables.X: Implementation of the enforced AI-driven hydration protocol (club policy: on vs off)
variables.Y: Soft-tissue injury incidence in the first half of the season (e.g., hamstring/quad/calf strains per player-month)
variables.Z: Training load during the season (GPS-based volume/intensity), which can be affected by the protocol and also affects injury risk

annotations.causal_structure: X -> Z -> Y, and X -> Y (possible direct pathway). Z is a mediator (post-policy) rather than a pre-policy confounder; conditioning on Z blocks part of the causal effect and can also open bias if Z has unmeasured causes that also affect Y.
annotations.key_insight: At Pearl L2, we ask about an intervention do(X). If Z is downstream of X, adjusting for Z changes the estimand from the total effect to a controlled direct effect and can introduce post-treatment bias; thus, 'controlling for everything predictive' is not valid for causal estimation.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: club sets hydration policy X. t1: hydration affects recovery/readiness, altering training load Z (players tolerate more/less load). t2: accumulated load influences injury occurrence Y during the half-season.
conditional_answers: Answer if the goal is the total effect of X on Y: do not adjust for Z. Answer if the goal is the direct effect of X not mediated by load: then a mediation framework is required, and simply regressing Y on X and Z is generally insufficient without additional assumptions about unmeasured causes of Z and Y.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are asked for the causal effect of an intervention, i.e., the contrast between Y under do(X=1) (hydration protocol implemented) and Y under do(X=0) (no protocol). In the stated structure, training load Z occurs after the policy is enacted and is causally influenced by X (X -> Z). Therefore Z is a mediator on at least one causal path from X to Y (X -> Z -> Y). Conditioning on Z would block this mediated path and thus would not identify the total causal effect of X on Y; it would instead target a different estimand (a controlled direct effect, holding Z fixed), which is not what the club asked for. Moreover, because Z is post-treatment, adjusting for it can induce post-treatment bias if there exist unmeasured determinants of Z that also affect Y (common in sports: coaching intensity, player fitness, tactical changes), which would create a backdoor path X -> Z <- U -> Y once we condition on Z. Hence, for estimating the total effect of implementing the hydration protocol on injuries, Z should not be adjusted for; if decomposition into mediated vs direct pathways is desired, one must use appropriate causal mediation assumptions and methods rather than naive adjustment.

scenario: A tennis player rolls an ankle in the first set. The on-court physio applies a tight ankle tape job and the player finishes the match, but later aggravates the injury and misses the next tournament. Commentators argue about the counterfactual: if the physio had not taped the ankle, would the player have avoided the later aggravation? The complication is that without taping, the player might have retired immediately, which would have changed the amount of continued load on the joint and the subsequent rehab timeline.
claim: If the physio had not taped the ankle (X=0), the player would not have aggravated the injury later (Y=0).

variables.X: Ankle taping by the physio after the initial ankle roll (treatment at t0)
variables.Y: Later injury aggravation leading to missed next tournament (outcome at t2)
variables.Z: Match continuation/playing time after the ankle roll (mediator affected by X) and underlying injury severity/pain tolerance (latent factor affecting both continuation and aggravation)

annotations.causal_structure: X influences Z (taping affects whether/how long the player continues and how they move). Z influences Y (more play on an injured ankle increases aggravation risk). Latent severity/pain tolerance also influences Z and Y, and may influence whether taping is attempted/accepted.
annotations.key_insight: The counterfactual mixes worlds by implicitly holding the match course (continued play) fixed while changing taping; but continuation is itself causally downstream of taping, so the claim cannot be evaluated without specifying what happens to Z under X=0.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: ankle roll occurs; X (taping) applied immediately after. t1: decision/ability to continue and total playing time Z realized during the match. t2: aggravation and tournament withdrawal Y realized days later.
conditional_answers: Answer if we assume the player would have continued for the same duration and intensity even without taping (i.e., fix Z to its observed value): then removing taping could plausibly reduce stability and increase aggravation risk, making the claim likely false. Answer if we assume without taping the player would have retired early (Z would drop substantially): then removing taping could reduce load and plausibly lower aggravation risk, making the claim possibly true. Without specifying Z under X=0, the counterfactual is not identified.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is a Level-3 counterfactual query about Y under the intervention do(X=0) for the same individual who was actually taped (X=1) and later aggravated (Y=1). The claim implicitly compares the actual world (X=1, Z=z1, Y=1) to a hypothetical world where X=0 while leaving unstated what happens to Z. But Z is a mediator: X -> Z -> Y. In counterfactual terms, asserting 'no taping implies no aggravation' often smuggles in a cross-world requirement like Y_{X=0, Z=z1}=0, which fixes the downstream mediator Z to its observed value from the X=1 world. That is a mediator-fixing error because the match continuation/playing time would generally change when taping is removed. Since Y depends strongly on Z (continued load) and Z itself would differ under X=0, the sign of Y_{X=0} relative to Y_{X=1} is not determined from the description. Additional information (e.g., the player’s likely retirement behavior without taping, severity, pain tolerance, and how taping changes gait/instability) is required to specify Z_{X=0} and thus identify Y_{X=0}. Therefore the claim cannot be judged true or false from the given scenario and is labeled Ambiguous.

scenario: A soccer club tests a new in-game hydration protocol: at the 60th minute, the staff mandates that any winger who has covered at least 6.8 km by that time must take a 90-second sideline hydration break (a planned stoppage during a substitution window). Analysts want the causal effect of mandating this hydration break on late-game hamstring injuries in the final 30 minutes. A naive analysis that compares players who did vs. did not take the break is misleading because the break is triggered by how hard the player has already worked, and prior workload also raises injury risk. The club instead randomizes the mandate among eligible wingers (those who meet the 6.8 km threshold) on each match: half are assigned the hydration break and half are told to continue. The club still uses the threshold for eligibility (for practical reasons), but within eligibility the assignment is randomized.
claim: Among eligible wingers (those who have covered at least 6.8 km by minute 60), mandating a 90-second hydration break at minute 60 reduces the probability of a hamstring injury in minutes 60–90, and this causal effect can be identified by comparing injury rates between randomized mandate vs. no-mandate groups within the eligible set.

variables.X: Mandated hydration break at minute 60 (assigned vs. not assigned) among eligible wingers
variables.Y: Hamstring injury occurrence during minutes 60–90 of the match
variables.Z: Pre-60-minute workload/intensity (e.g., distance covered, high-speed runs) which determines eligibility and directly affects late-game injury risk

annotations.causal_structure: Z (pre-60 workload) increases Y (late injury risk) and also influences treatment assignment in observational data via eligibility/coach decisions; by restricting to eligibility and randomizing X within that stratum, the backdoor path X <- Z -> Y is blocked within the eligible set, permitting identification of the causal effect of X on Y for eligibles.
annotations.key_insight: When treatment assignment is driven by a time-varying predictor that is itself affected by earlier play and predicts the outcome, naive comparisons are confounded; randomization (or otherwise blocking the backdoor) within the risk-set at the decision time turns the question into a valid L2 intervention effect for the eligible population.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0–t60 (workload accrued) affects both (i) eligibility/assignment mechanism for X at t60 and (ii) injury risk Y at t60–t90; X occurs at t60 and can causally affect Y at t60–t90 by reducing dehydration/fatigue accumulation after t60.
conditional_answers: Answer is valid if: (i) assignment of X is truly randomized within the eligible set and not overridden by coaches/players, (ii) injuries are measured the same way in both arms, and (iii) analysis conditions on eligibility defined strictly by pre-t60 data. If assignment is not randomized (e.g., staff selectively mandates breaks for players who look strained), the claim would become flawed due to unblocked backdoor confounding by Z and other latent fatigue indicators.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are asked an L2 question: the effect of intervening to mandate a hydration break (X) on late-game hamstring injury (Y). In observational comparisons, X is confounded because pre-60 workload (Z) both raises injury risk and makes the break more likely (via the eligibility rule and/or staff discretion), creating an open backdoor path X <- Z -> Y. However, the club’s design explicitly intervenes by randomizing X among players who are eligible, i.e., after conditioning on the risk-set defined by Z>=threshold using only pre-intervention information. Within this eligible stratum, randomization makes X independent of Z (and of other pre-t60 causes of Y), so the backdoor path is blocked and P(Y|do(X), eligible) is identified by the difference in observed injury rates between randomized arms. Therefore the claim is valid as a causal conclusion for the eligible population, because the intervention assignment mechanism severs the dependence between X and the time-varying confounder Z at the decision time.

scenario: An MMA gym prescribes a strict 'ketogenic cut' diet to all fighters 4 weeks before a fight. An internal study shows that fighters who successfully adhered to the diet until weigh-in day won 65% of their fights, while those who broke the diet won only 40%. The gym mandates the diet for everyone, claiming it causes wins.
claim: Adhering to the ketogenic diet (X) causes a higher win probability (Y).

variables.X: Prescription of Ketogenic Diet
variables.Y: Winning the fight
variables.Z: Adherence/Compliance to the diet (The variable actually measured)

annotations.causal_structure: X (Prescription) -> Z (Adherence). U (Self-discipline/Mental toughness) -> Z and U -> Y. Conditioning on Z (comparing adherers vs non-adherers) selects for U.
annotations.key_insight: Fighters who stick to a miserable diet (Z) likely possess high discipline (U). Discipline also helps them train harder and win (Y). The diet might be useless, but the 'adherer' group is full of disciplined fighters.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: X at t0. Z measured over t0-t30. Y at t31.
conditional_answers: No. The intention-to-treat (ITT) effect (comparing everyone assigned the diet vs everyone assigned a normal diet) is the only valid metric. The complier analysis is biased by the 'discipline' confounder.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is based on a comparison of Compliers vs. Non-Compliers. Compliance (Z) is a collider. It is influenced by the assignment (X) and by unobserved traits like Discipline (U). Discipline also affects Winning (Y). By conditioning on Z, we induce a correlation between X and U. The 'Adherer' group is enriched with highly disciplined fighters, so their win rate reflects their discipline, not necessarily the biological benefit of the keto diet.

scenario: An NBA team considers reducing back-to-back minutes for its star guard after a stretch of nagging hamstring tightness. The performance staff proposes an intervention: cap the player at 30 minutes on the second night of back-to-backs for the next 8 weeks. Analysts estimate the causal effect of this minutes-cap on subsequent soft-tissue injury incidence using observational game logs and medical reports, adjusting for the player's pre-cap hamstring tightness severity and recent workload. They explicitly do NOT adjust for the player's in-game peak sprint count during those capped games, because it is influenced by the minutes-cap and lies on the pathway from minutes to injury risk.
claim: If the team implements a minutes-cap (X) on back-to-back games, it will reduce the player's probability of a soft-tissue injury in the following 14 days (Y), and estimating this effect should adjust for pre-intervention injury risk/workload (Z) but not for post-cap sprint intensity, which is a mediator.

variables.X: Implementing a minutes-cap policy (e.g., max 30 minutes) on the second night of back-to-backs for the player
variables.Y: Soft-tissue injury occurrence (or injury-days missed) within the next 14 days after a back-to-back game
variables.Z: Pre-intervention injury risk and workload state (e.g., baseline hamstring tightness severity and cumulative minutes/acute:chronic workload ratio in the 2 weeks before the policy starts)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (baseline tightness/workload) affects both X (coaches choose to cap minutes when risk is high) and Y (injury). Additionally, prior workload and tightness evolve over time and influence future capping decisions; X affects in-game sprint intensity which then affects Y (mediated path).
annotations.key_insight: To answer an intervention question, block the backdoor from pre-intervention risk to both policy and injury, but do not condition on post-intervention mediators like sprint intensity; otherwise you distort the total causal effect of the minutes-cap.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (pre-policy tightness/workload) -> X at t1 (minutes-cap decision for upcoming back-to-back) -> mediator at t1 (sprint intensity during capped game) -> Y at t2 (injury within 14 days). Also, Z at t0 influences Y at t2 directly, and evolving workload/tightness between t0 and t1 can influence both X and Y.
conditional_answers: Answer is valid if Z is measured strictly before the minutes-cap policy is applied (pre-intervention) and the analysis targets the total effect of X on Y (not a direct effect).
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: This is a Pearl L2 (intervention) question: we want the effect of doing X (imposing a minutes-cap) on Y (subsequent injury). In the underlying causal graph, Z (pre-intervention tightness/workload) is a common cause of both X and Y: coaches are more likely to cap minutes when the player is already at elevated risk, and elevated risk also increases injury probability. Therefore, without adjustment, the association between X and Y is confounded by an unblocked backdoor path X <- Z -> Y (and by time-varying versions of Z that affect future X and Y). Conditioning on appropriately pre-intervention measurements of Z blocks these backdoor paths and identifies the causal effect of the intervention. By contrast, sprint intensity during the capped game is causally downstream of X and lies on the pathway X -> (sprint intensity) -> Y; adjusting for it would remove part of the effect transmitted through that mechanism and would not estimate the total causal effect of X on Y. Hence the claim is valid: adjust for pre-intervention risk/workload (Z) to address time-varying confounding, and avoid adjusting for post-intervention mediators when the estimand is the total effect.

scenario: An NBA team considers a policy change: mandate that every player completes a pregame mindfulness session (10 minutes guided breathing) to reduce turnovers. The analytics staff compares games where players actually attended the session versus games where they skipped it, and finds that attendees had fewer turnovers and higher assist-to-turnover ratios. The coach concludes the team should enforce mindfulness attendance because it causally reduces turnovers. However, attendance is not random: players are more likely to attend when they are already feeling focused and healthy, and less likely to attend when they are dealing with minor injuries, travel fatigue, or personal stress. Those same factors also directly affect turnovers.
claim: If the team mandates mindfulness attendance before games (X), turnovers will decrease (Y), because attendees historically have fewer turnovers.

variables.X: Mandated pregame mindfulness session attendance (intervention/policy to increase compliance)
variables.Y: In-game turnovers (or assist-to-turnover ratio) during that game
variables.Z: Player readiness state before the game (fatigue, minor injury status, stress, sleep/travel load) that affects both likelihood of attending and turnovers

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y, with a naive comparison of Y between X=1 (attended) and X=0 (skipped) interpreted as the causal effect of do(X).
annotations.key_insight: The observed association between mindfulness attendance and fewer turnovers is partly (or entirely) explained by pregame readiness, which both increases attendance and reduces turnovers; without blocking this backdoor path, the estimated policy effect is biased.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (readiness before arriving at arena) influences X at t0 (whether the player attends the session) and also influences Y at t1 (turnovers during the game).
conditional_answers: Answer if (i) attendance is randomized or mandated with full compliance regardless of readiness, or (ii) Z is fully measured and appropriately adjusted for (and no other unmeasured backdoors exist): then the causal effect of do(X) on Y could be estimated; otherwise the historical attendee vs non-attendee gap is not a causal effect.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim confuses an observational contrast with an interventional effect. The staff computed something like E[Y|X=1] - E[Y|X=0], but the policy question is E[Y|do(X=1)] - E[Y|do(X=0)]. Because Z (pregame readiness) causally affects both X (likelihood of attending mindfulness) and Y (turnovers), there is an unblocked backdoor path X <- Z -> Y. Therefore, conditioning only on X leaves confounding: players attend more when Z is favorable, and favorable Z also lowers Y, creating a spurious benefit attributed to X. Mandating mindfulness changes X but does not, by itself, equalize Z across games; thus the observed association cannot justify the causal conclusion that enforcing mindfulness will reduce turnovers. To support the claim, one would need random assignment/encouragement or valid adjustment for Z (and other backdoor variables) to identify the effect of do(X).

scenario: An NFL analyst studies fourth-down decision making. They find that teams that attempt to convert on 4th-and-short (rather than punting) have a significantly higher win rate than teams that punt. A commentator argues that 'aggression wins games' and every team should go for it on 4th down regardless of context. However, teams usually only go for it when they are already in favorable field position or playing against a weak defense.
claim: Going for it on 4th-and-short causes a higher probability of winning the game.

variables.X: Attempting a 4th-down conversion (Aggressive playcalling)
variables.Y: Winning the game
variables.Z: Field position and score margin (Teams go for it when they are close to the endzone or desperately chasing points; context drives both X and Y)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (favorable field position) increases the probability of X (coach decides to go for it) and independently increases the probability of Y (scoring/winning). The association is confounded by the state of the game.
annotations.key_insight: Aggressive playcalling is often a luxury of good field position or a necessity of desperation; analyzing the outcome without conditioning on the game state (Z) creates a spurious association.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (ball on opponent's 30-yard line) -> X at t0 (go for it) -> Y at t1 (win).
conditional_answers: Ambiguous. If we compare 4th-down attempts vs punts holding field position, score, and time constant, the 'aggression' advantage often shrinks or disappears.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: At L1, we observe an association between X and Y. However, the decision X is heavily influenced by Z (field position and game context). Z is a common cause: good field position makes converting easier (increasing X) and winning easier (increasing Y). Therefore, the raw positive association cannot be interpreted as a universal causal rule that 'aggression causes winning' without adjusting for Z.

scenario: An NBA team pilots a new “high-intensity defensive scheme” (more full-court pressure, more aggressive closeouts). Coaches decide in-game whether to deploy it based on how the last few possessions went and who looks fatigued. The analytics department evaluates the scheme by comparing points allowed per possession in stretches when the scheme was used versus not used, then recommends using it more because the team allows fewer points during scheme-on stretches.
claim: If the team intervenes to use the high-intensity defensive scheme more often, it will causally reduce points allowed per possession.

variables.X: Deploying the high-intensity defensive scheme on a given possession/segment (scheme-on vs scheme-off)
variables.Y: Points allowed per possession (defensive efficiency) during the subsequent possessions/segment
variables.Z: Time-varying game state and player condition that affects both scheme choice and defense outcomes (e.g., recent opponent scoring run, current lineup matchups, foul trouble, fatigue, and prior defensive stops/allowed points)

annotations.causal_structure: Z_t (recent possessions, opponent momentum, lineup/fatigue) influences X_t (scheme deployed now) and also directly influences Y_t (points allowed next). Additionally, past outcomes Y_{t-1} feed into Z_t and into X_t (coaches react to what just happened), creating treatment-confounder feedback over time.
annotations.key_insight: Because coaches adaptively choose the scheme in response to evolving game conditions that also affect defense, the observed association between scheme-on and fewer points can be driven by time-varying confounding and feedback; a naive comparison does not identify the effect of intervening to increase scheme usage.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t-1: prior defensive outcome (Y_{t-1}) and game context update fatigue/matchups (Z_t). t: coaches choose scheme (X_t) based on Z_t and recent outcomes. t+1: points allowed realized (Y_t), which then updates the next context Z_{t+1} and future scheme decisions X_{t+1}.
conditional_answers: If X were randomized at each segment (or assigned by an exogenous rule independent of Z_t), then the observed difference in Y could be interpreted causally. If one correctly models and adjusts for the full time-varying confounding affected by prior outcomes (e.g., via marginal structural models / g-formula with appropriate history), a causal effect might be estimable; without that, the claim is not justified.
label: No
