correct_reasoning: The claim is a Level-2 (interventional) statement about do(X): it asserts that increasing scheme usage would reduce points allowed. However, the evaluation compares Y between observed scheme-on and scheme-off stretches, which estimates an associational contrast P(Y|X) rather than the interventional contrast P(Y|do(X)). The key obstruction is time-varying confounding with feedback: the coaches set X_t using Z_t (fatigue, lineup matchups, opponent run, foul trouble, and the immediately preceding defensive outcomes), and Z_t also affects Y_t. Moreover, prior outcomes Y_{t-1} influence future treatment assignment through Z_t (reactive coaching), so the confounder is itself partially a function of past outcomes and past treatments. This means the backdoor path X_t <- Z_t -> Y_t is open, and naive adjustment can also fail because parts of Z_t are treatment-affected history; conditioning incorrectly can induce bias (e.g., blocking causal pathways or creating collider structures in the longitudinal graph). Therefore, the observed lower points allowed during scheme-on stretches can arise because the scheme is deployed when conditions are already favorable for defense (or withheld when the defense is compromised), not because the scheme itself causes improvement. Without randomization or a valid longitudinal identification strategy that accounts for treatment-confounder feedback, the data do not support the causal conclusion, so the claim is flawed.

scenario: An NBA team is considering an in-game coaching policy: whenever the opponent goes on a 6–0 run, the coach immediately calls a timeout. Analysts compare games with many 'run-triggered timeouts' to games with few and notice that teams calling more timeouts after runs often still lose. A staff member argues that timeouts are ineffective and should be reduced. The head analyst instead proposes estimating the causal effect of a *policy intervention*: force the coach to always call a timeout immediately after any 6–0 run (versus never calling a timeout for runs), using play-by-play data and a model that accounts for the game state that triggers timeouts.
claim: If the team intervenes to always call a timeout immediately after an opponent 6–0 run (X), the probability of losing the game (Y) will decrease, because the observed association between calling run-triggered timeouts and losing is driven by reactive intervention to worsening game states (Z).

variables.X: Timeout policy intervention: automatically call a timeout immediately after any opponent 6–0 run (vs. not calling a timeout for runs).
variables.Y: Game outcome: probability of the team losing (or negative final point differential).
variables.Z: Worsening game state that triggers timeouts: current score margin, opponent hot-shooting streak, lineup mismatch, fatigue, foul trouble, remaining time/possessions.

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y, with X -> Y. The coach calls a timeout (X) in reaction to a bad/declining game state (Z), and that same Z also increases the chance of losing (Y). Naive comparisons confound the effect of X with Z.
annotations.key_insight: Because timeouts are triggered by deteriorating conditions, the raw correlation between timeouts and losing is not the causal effect; the causal question requires an intervention on the timeout policy while holding the triggering game state distribution comparable (i.e., block the backdoor path through Z).
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (opponent run + unfavorable lineup/fatigue) increases the chance the coach calls timeout X at t0 and also increases losing Y at t2; X at t0 can causally affect Y at t2 by stopping the run and enabling adjustments.
conditional_answers: Answer if (i) timeouts are primarily called in response to negative momentum/game-state deterioration rather than randomly, and (ii) the analysis targets the effect of the *policy* 'call timeout after a 6–0 run' by adjusting for/conditioning on pre-timeout game state variables Z (or using a design like within-game matched segments / g-formula with time-varying state).
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: At Pearl Level 2 we ask an interventional question: what happens to Y under do(X=always call timeout after a 6–0 run) versus do(X=never call timeout for runs). The observed association P(Y|X) is not equal to P(Y|do(X)) because X is chosen reactively. Specifically, the worsening game state Z (score margin, fatigue, foul trouble, lineup mismatch, opponent shooting) causally increases the probability of calling a timeout (Z -> X) and also causally increases the probability of losing (Z -> Y). This creates an open backdoor path X <- Z -> Y, making timeouts look harmful in observational comparisons even if they help. Under an intervention that sets the timeout policy, X is no longer a downstream response to Z; to estimate the causal effect we must block the backdoor by adjusting for pre-timeout Z (or using an equivalent identification strategy for time-varying state). Once Z is controlled, the remaining effect corresponds to X -> Y (timeouts enabling rest and tactical adjustment), so it is valid that implementing the run-triggered timeout policy can reduce losing probability even when the naive correlation suggests otherwise.

scenario: An NBA team considers a new in-game substitution policy: whenever a starter’s wearable shows 'high fatigue' (a threshold on recent high-intensity movement), the coach immediately subs the player out for a 2-minute rest. Analysts compare games where the policy was used frequently vs rarely and find that teams using it more often have lower fourth-quarter net rating. A causal analyst proposes estimating the effect of implementing the policy by adjusting for in-game fatigue level at each stoppage and prior score margin, using play-by-play and tracking data to emulate a target trial of 'sub now' vs 'keep in' decisions.
claim: If we model the decision to sub (X) as an intervention at each stoppage and adjust for time-varying fatigue (Z) and prior score margin (also part of Z) that affect both the substitution decision and later performance, then the estimated effect of the substitution policy on fourth-quarter net rating (Y) can identify the causal impact of implementing the policy, even though naive comparisons suggest it is harmful.

variables.X: Coach executes a fatigue-triggered substitution at a given stoppage (sub now vs keep player in) / implementation intensity of the substitution policy across the game
variables.Y: Team fourth-quarter net rating (points per 100 possessions in Q4) or win probability added in the last 6 minutes
variables.Z: Time-varying confounders: current player fatigue state from wearables and tracking; recent workload (minutes played, sprint count); current score margin and game context (pace, foul trouble) that influence both substitution decisions and later team performance

annotations.causal_structure: Z_t (fatigue/workload and score context) affects X_t (substitution decision) and Y (later Q4 performance); past X_{t-1} affects future Z_t (rest reduces fatigue), creating treatment-confounder feedback. Proper g-methods (e.g., marginal structural models) are needed to estimate the causal effect of intervening on X over time.
annotations.key_insight: Because fatigue and game context both drive substitutions and also drive later performance—and are themselves affected by earlier substitutions—naive adjustment or naive comparisons are biased. But with correct time-indexing and appropriate methods that account for treatment-confounder feedback, the causal effect of the substitution policy is identifiable from observational play-by-play under standard assumptions.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: At each stoppage t: Z_t (fatigue, score margin) is observed; coach chooses X_t (sub vs keep) at t0; this affects immediate rest and rotation, changing Z_{t+1} (fatigue and lineup quality) at t1; Y is realized in Q4 at t2. Earlier X_{t-1} also changes Z_t, so Z_t is both a confounder for X_t->Y and a mediator of X_{t-1}->Y.
conditional_answers: Answer is Yes if: (i) all relevant time-varying confounders Z_t (fatigue, workload, score context, foul trouble proxies) are measured before each decision point; (ii) positivity holds (both sub and keep decisions occur across the range of Z_t); (iii) consistency/SUTVA is reasonable at the decision-unit level (the defined intervention corresponds to the observed action); and (iv) a correct g-method (e.g., inverse-probability-of-treatment weighting for a marginal structural model or sequential g-computation) is used rather than conditioning on post-decision variables like 'minutes played after the stoppage'.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: This is an L2 question because it asks about the effect of an intervention: forcing (or implementing) a substitution rule X rather than merely observing association. The naive comparison 'more fatigue-triggered subs -> worse Q4 net rating' is not causally interpretable because Z_t (fatigue and game context) is a time-varying common cause of both X_t and Y: coaches sub more precisely when fatigue is high or the game state is adverse, and those same conditions predict worse late-game performance. Moreover, there is treatment–confounder feedback: earlier substitutions X_{t-1} change later fatigue Z_t (rest reduces fatigue), so Z_t is simultaneously (a) a confounder for the current decision X_t -> Y and (b) a mediator of earlier decisions X_{t-1} -> Y. Therefore, standard regression that 'controls for fatigue' can block parts of the causal pathway and induce bias. However, if we emulate a sequential decision process and use g-methods that appropriately adjust for the full history of pre-decision confounders (the backdoor paths from Z_t to both X_t and Y) without conditioning on post-intervention variables, then the backdoor criterion is satisfied at each decision point and the interventional distribution P(Y | do(policy on X)) is identifiable. Under the stated measurement and positivity assumptions, the claim that this approach can recover the causal impact of implementing the substitution policy is valid.

scenario: A tennis analyst reviews match logs and notices that when a top player receives an on-court medical timeout (MTO), they often end up losing the match. The analyst then makes a counterfactual claim about what would have happened in the same match without the MTO, arguing from the observed association between MTOs and losses.
claim: If the player had not taken the medical timeout (X=0), they would have been more likely to win the match (Y=Win) in that same match.

variables.X: Taking an on-court medical timeout (MTO) during the match (yes/no)
variables.Y: Match outcome (win/loss)
variables.Z: Underlying injury severity / acute physical limitation at the time the MTO is requested (latent or partially observed)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (injury severity) increases the probability of X (taking an MTO) and also decreases Y (chance of winning). The counterfactual query conditions on the realized match trajectory in which the player both (i) became injured enough to request an MTO and (ii) continued playing to finish the match, which selects on post-injury survival/continuation.
annotations.key_insight: The counterfactual 'same match, but no MTO' improperly holds fixed a selected world where the player was injured enough to request an MTO and still finished the match; conditioning on that survival/continuation event biases the comparison between worlds with and without X.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Player starts match with baseline health. t1: Acute issue worsens (Z rises) during play. t2: Player requests MTO (X=1) conditional on Z and continuation. t3: Player either finishes match or retires (selection on continuation). t4: Final outcome recorded (Y).
conditional_answers: Answer if (a) we could randomize MTO availability/usage independent of injury severity Z, and (b) define Y to include retirement as a loss and avoid conditioning on finishing: then an interventional effect of forcing X=0 could be estimable; otherwise the counterfactual claim is not justified from the observed data.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is a Level-3 counterfactual statement about the same match: it asserts Y_{X=0} > Y_{X=1} for the player in the realized world where X=1 occurred. But X is not an exogenous switch; it is a response to Z (injury severity), and Z also directly affects Y. Moreover, the analyst implicitly conditions on a post-injury selection event: we only observe completed matches in which the player both became injured enough to consider treatment and still continued to a recorded outcome (i.e., did not retire before the outcome is defined). This is counterfactual conditioning on survival/continuation, which is affected by Z and potentially by X (an MTO can enable continuation). Therefore, comparing the realized world (injured, took MTO, finished) to a hypothetical world where the player is held in the same realized match state but with X set to 0 is ill-posed: without the MTO the player might have retired earlier, changed effort, or altered subsequent points, so the conditioning event differs across worlds. Because the counterfactual is evaluated within a selected stratum that is not invariant under the intervention on X, the observed association between MTO and losing cannot support the conclusion that withholding the MTO would have increased win probability. The correct conclusion is that the data conflate injury-driven selection and treatment usage, so the counterfactual claim is not causally warranted.

scenario: A soccer club introduces a new high-intensity pressing scheme mid-season. The coaching staff compares matches where the team executed the scheme (high pressing intensity) versus matches where they did not (lower intensity), and finds that high pressing is associated with fewer goals conceded. They propose mandating the scheme in all matches to reduce goals conceded.
claim: Mandating the high-intensity pressing scheme (X) will causally reduce goals conceded (Y).

variables.X: Implementing/mandating a high-intensity pressing scheme (e.g., high PPDA pressure, high press triggers) in a match
variables.Y: Goals conceded in the match (or expected goals against, xGA)
variables.Z: Opponent strength and match state (e.g., facing weaker opponents and/or leading early), which influences both the likelihood of using high press and the goals conceded

annotations.causal_structure: Z (opponent strength/match state) affects X (pressing intensity choice) and Y (goals conceded). Additionally, early match events (part of Z) are affected by prior X and then feed back to future X and Y within the same match/season, creating time-varying confounding.
annotations.key_insight: Pressing intensity is often chosen reactively based on evolving match state and opponent quality; naive comparisons of matches (or periods) with high vs low press do not identify the effect of forcing the press because Z both drives the decision and predicts defensive outcomes.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Pre-match opponent strength influences planned press intensity. t1: Early goal or red card changes match state (Z) and triggers adjustments in press intensity (X). t2: Adjusted press intensity affects chance creation against (Y) and also alters future match state (Z) via fatigue and transitions.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous: If pressing intensity were randomized (or assigned by an external rule) independent of opponent strength and evolving match state, the claim could be evaluated and might be true. If pressing is chosen more often when already leading or versus weaker opponents, the observed association likely overstates the causal benefit.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: At Pearl Level 2 we must evaluate the interventional claim do(X=high press) -> Y, not merely the association between X and Y in observed matches. Here, Z (opponent strength and match state) is a time-varying confounder: it causally affects the coach's decision to press (X) and also causally affects goals conceded (Y). Moreover, match state evolves during the match and is itself partially downstream of earlier pressing decisions, creating feedback where past X changes Z, and Z then changes future X and future Y. Because Z is not fully blocked by a valid adjustment set that respects time order (and because naive adjustment for post-treatment components of Z can induce bias), the observational comparison of high-press matches/periods to low-press matches/periods does not identify the causal effect of mandating the press. Therefore, with the information given, we cannot conclude the intervention will reduce goals conceded; the claim may be true or false depending on how pressing would be assigned under intervention and how Z is handled (e.g., via proper longitudinal methods like g-methods).

scenario: A soccer club introduces a new “high-intensity pressing” training block during preseason. The performance analyst evaluates the program by comparing match results only among players who fully completed the block (attended >90% of sessions) versus players who did not complete it. The analyst reports that the program caused better match performance because the completers had higher average distance covered and a higher win rate in matches they started.
claim: Implementing the high-intensity pressing training block causes better match performance, since players who completed the block had higher distance covered and higher win rates than those who did not complete it.

variables.X: Assignment to the new high-intensity pressing training block (club implements it as the intended training intervention)
variables.Y: Match performance (e.g., win rate in matches started, distance covered per 90, pressing actions per 90)
variables.Z: Training completion/compliance status (whether the player attended >90% of sessions), which is influenced by both baseline fitness/motivation and early injury/fatigue

annotations.causal_structure: X affects Z (the intervention influences who can/does comply). Baseline fitness/motivation and early injury/fatigue also affect Z and directly affect Y. Conditioning on Z opens a non-causal path between X and Y via Z.
annotations.key_insight: Comparing outcomes only among compliers is not the same as estimating the causal effect of assigning the training; compliance is a collider affected by the intervention and by factors that also affect performance.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Players have baseline fitness/motivation and latent injury risk. t1: Club assigns the pressing block (X). t2: Some players comply/complete (Z) depending on baseline traits and early fatigue/injury. t3: Match performance (Y) is realized.
conditional_answers: Answer if the question is 'Does completing the block predict better performance among those who completed it?': Yes, it may predict. Answer if the question is 'Does assigning the block improve performance for the squad (intention-to-treat)?': Cannot be concluded from the complier-only comparison.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it infers an intervention effect of X on Y from a comparison that conditions on Z (compliance/completion). In the causal graph, X -> Z, while unobserved baseline fitness/motivation and early injury/fatigue -> Z and also -> Y. Thus Z is a collider on the path X -> Z <- (baseline factors) -> Y. By restricting analysis to Z=1 (compliers), the analyst opens this backdoor path, inducing an association between X and the baseline factors, which then transmits to Y. Therefore the observed performance advantage among completers can be produced even if the pressing block assignment has no causal effect on match performance. To estimate the causal effect at Pearl Level 2, one should analyze assignment (intention-to-treat) without conditioning on compliance, or use appropriate causal methods (e.g., randomized assignment with IV/CACE under assumptions) rather than a complier-only comparison.

scenario: An NBA team’s analytics group reviews a playoff series where their star guard played 44+ minutes in Games 1–3 and then suffered a hamstring strain late in Game 3, missing most of Game 4. Fans argue the coach “caused the injury” by overplaying him. The coach counters that the player would have been injured anyway because he was already carrying a tight hamstring, and the extra minutes were necessary to win earlier games. A counterfactual question is posed: in the closest world where the coach capped him at 34 minutes in Game 3, would he have avoided the hamstring strain and been available for Game 4?
claim: If the coach had limited the star guard to 34 minutes in Game 3 (X), he would not have strained his hamstring and would have played effectively in Game 4 (Y).

variables.X: Counterfactual coaching decision: cap the star guard at 34 minutes in Game 3 instead of playing 44+ minutes
variables.Y: Counterfactual outcome: no hamstring strain by end of Game 3 and effective availability/performance in Game 4
variables.Z: Unobserved, time-evolving tissue vulnerability and pain tolerance (micro-damage accumulation, neuromuscular fatigue, and player self-reporting accuracy) that both affects minutes played and injury risk

annotations.causal_structure: Z (latent vulnerability) influences both X (minutes/coach willingness to extend run) and Y (injury and next-game availability). Additionally, conditioning the counterfactual on the observed fact that an injury occurred in the actual world (Y=injury) implicitly selects worlds where Z was high, which distorts the comparison between do(X=34) and do(X=44+).
annotations.key_insight: The counterfactual is being evaluated conditional on an outcome-defined subset (the realized world where injury happened), but the relevant counterfactual distribution requires comparing worlds without conditioning on post-outcome information that is itself informative about latent vulnerability.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: pre-Game 3 latent micro-damage/vulnerability Z. t1: coach observes imperfect signals (player says he feels 'ok', game context) and sets minutes X. t2: within-Game 3 exertion/fatigue accumulates (partly downstream of X and Z). t3: hamstring strain realized (component of Y). t4: Game 4 availability/performance realized (component of Y).
conditional_answers: Ambiguous unless we specify (i) what information the coach used when choosing minutes (signals about Z), (ii) the causal effect of minutes on injury holding fixed pre-game Z (a well-defined intervention do(X)), and (iii) whether the counterfactual is meant unconditionally or conditional on the observed injury in the actual world. If we instead ask the unconditional causal effect of do(X=34) vs do(X=44+) on injury risk averaged over the pre-Game 3 population distribution of Z, it may be estimable with rich tracking/medical data and a valid identification strategy; but the specific statement 'given that he actually got injured, he would have been fine under X=34' requires cross-world assumptions about Z that are not identified from usual data.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is an L3 counterfactual claim about an individual player: it asserts Y_{X=34}=no-injury/effective-G4 in the actual case where we observed X=44+ and injury. The reasoning trap is counterfactual conditioning on an outcome-defined realized world. Observing that the player was injured provides information that the latent vulnerability Z was likely high in the actual world. But the claim implicitly compares the actual world (where Z is inferred high because injury occurred) to a hypothetical world under do(X=34) while keeping 'everything else the same'—which informally attempts to hold fixed the very latent factors that are only partially revealed by the injury. Formally, the quantity of interest resembles P(Y_{34}=0 | X=44+, Y=1) or a statement about Y_{34} for the specific unit given Y=1. This conditions on a post-treatment outcome (Y) that is downstream of both Z and X, selecting a subset of worlds/units with high Z and potentially inducing selection bias in the counterfactual comparison. Without a specified structural causal model linking Z, X, and Y (including how Z would evolve under different minutes and what the coach would have done given different signals), the counterfactual is not identified: multiple causal models can fit the observed facts yet disagree on whether Y_{34} would be 0 or 1. Therefore the claim cannot be labeled true or false from the given information; it remains ambiguous because it hinges on unobserved Z and cross-world assumptions about how the player’s vulnerability and exertion trajectory would have unfolded under the alternative minutes cap.

scenario: A tennis federation reviews a star player who withdrew mid-match at a Grand Slam. The player had been on a new, aggressive serving program for 6 weeks. In the actual world, the player withdrew with shoulder pain and therefore logged fewer total serves and fewer high-velocity serves in that match. A commentator claims the new program caused the withdrawal because the player’s shoulder was overloaded. The federation asks a counterfactual question: 'If the player had not done the new serving program, would they still have withdrawn in that match?' Analysts attempt to answer using only matches where players did not withdraw (because those are the only matches with complete serve-tracking and post-match MRI data).
claim: If the player had not adopted the new aggressive serving program (X=0), they would not have withdrawn mid-match (Y=0), because among matches with complete tracking (i.e., non-withdrawals), players on the program show fewer withdrawals.

variables.X: Adoption of a new aggressive serving program in the 6 weeks before the match (yes/no)
variables.Y: Withdrawal mid-match due to shoulder pain (yes/no)
variables.Z: Latent shoulder fragility / pre-existing micro-tears and pain tolerance that both increase likelihood of adopting/being assigned the program (via coaches trying to 'fix' serve) and increase withdrawal risk; plus match completeness (having full tracking/MRI) as a post-outcome selection variable

annotations.causal_structure: Z (latent fragility) affects X (program adoption) and Y (withdrawal). Y also determines S (data completeness: full tracking/MRI available), and analysts condition on S=1 (non-withdrawals) when estimating the counterfactual Y_{X=0}. This creates counterfactual conditioning on a post-outcome selection variable and entangles identification of 'would have withdrawn' with the fact that withdrawal censors the data.
annotations.key_insight: The counterfactual 'would the player have withdrawn without the program' cannot be identified from data restricted to non-withdrawals because conditioning on survival/completion (S=1) selects on the outcome and changes the cross-world comparison needed for L3 questions.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: latent shoulder fragility and prior pain (Z) exists. t1: coaching/medical staff decide on aggressive serving program (X). t2: match begins; serving load accumulates. t3: shoulder pain escalates; withdrawal occurs (Y). t4: only if Y=0 do full serve-tracking and post-match MRI/physio assessments enter the dataset (S=1).
conditional_answers: Answer if (i) we had pre-match imaging and pain scores for all players regardless of withdrawal, (ii) random or quasi-random assignment of the serving program, and (iii) complete serve-load measurement even when a player withdraws (or a principled model for censoring): then we could estimate the causal effect of X on Y and answer the counterfactual more credibly. Answer if we instead define the estimand as 'withdrawal before match end' and ensure outcome ascertainment is complete for everyone; otherwise the counterfactual remains sensitive to unverifiable assumptions about missingness and latent fragility.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: The claim asserts a specific counterfactual for this player: whether Y would have been 0 under X=0. At Pearl Level 3, that requires reasoning about Y_{X=0} for the same unit, which is not identified by a mere association among observed non-withdrawals. The analysts condition on S=1 (complete tracking/MRI), but S is a post-outcome selection variable largely determined by Y (withdrawals censor data). Conditioning on S=1 induces selection bias: it restricts attention to worlds (and players) where Y=0, which is exactly the event whose counterfactual probability is being queried. Moreover, Z (latent fragility) is an unobserved common cause of both X and Y, so even without selection the comparison of X groups is confounded; with selection, the problem becomes a counterfactual conditioning trap because the needed cross-world link between (Y under X=1) and (Y under X=0) is distorted by outcome-dependent observation. Therefore the direction and magnitude of the causal effect of the serving program on withdrawal—and thus whether this player would have withdrawn without it—cannot be concluded from the described data without strong, untestable assumptions (e.g., ignorability given measured Z proxies and a correct model for censoring). Hence the claim is not decidably true or false from the information given.

scenario: In the NFL, coaches often call a timeout right before the opposing kicker attempts a game-winning field goal (known as 'icing the kicker'). An analyst compares kicks where the timeout was called vs. not called. They find kickers miss *more* often when 'iced'. The analyst concludes the tactic works. However, coaches only 'ice' the kicker in high-pressure, last-second situations, whereas non-iced kicks include many routine 2nd-quarter kicks.
claim: Calling a timeout before a kick (X) causes the kicker to miss (Y).

variables.X: Calling a timeout before the kick ('Icing')
variables.Y: Missed Field Goal
variables.Z: Game Pressure / Leverage (Last second vs. mid-game)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (High Pressure) causes X (Coach calls timeout) and Z causes Y (Kicker chokes/misses). X is not randomly assigned.
annotations.key_insight: The intervention (icing) is applied selectively during high-stress moments. High stress makes kicking harder. The comparison group (non-iced kicks) includes low-stress kicks.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z (last second) -> X (timeout). Z -> Y (miss).
conditional_answers: Ambiguous. To determine if icing works, one must compare iced vs. non-iced kicks *only* within high-leverage situations. Studies suggest the effect is negligible or nonexistent once Z is controlled.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: The claim implies do(X) -> Y. However, X is confounded by Z (Game Pressure). Coaches do not ice kickers in the 1st quarter. They ice them at the end of the game when pressure is highest. Pressure (Z) increases the miss rate (Y). Therefore, the observed relationship is confounded. Without adjusting for Z, the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: An NBA team considers a policy change: mandate that all players complete a 12-minute dynamic warm-up immediately before entering the game (including after halftime and after long bench stints). The performance staff evaluates the causal effect of this policy on in-game soft-tissue injuries using player-game data. A naive analyst proposes estimating the effect by comparing injury rates between games where players complied with the warm-up and games where they did not, restricting analysis to 'compliant' player-games only.
claim: If the team intervenes to mandate the 12-minute dynamic warm-up (X), it will reduce in-game soft-tissue injuries (Y), based on the observed lower injury rate among compliant player-games.

variables.X: Mandated 12-minute dynamic warm-up protocol before game entry (team policy intervention)
variables.Y: In-game soft-tissue injury occurrence (e.g., hamstring/groin strain) during that game
variables.Z: Compliance status with the warm-up (a post-intervention variable influenced by fatigue/coach usage/availability and linked to injury risk)

annotations.causal_structure: X affects Z (policy increases compliance). Unobserved factors U (e.g., acute fatigue, time pressure from late substitutions, minor tightness, coach urgency) affect both Z (skipping/shortening warm-up) and Y (injury risk). Conditioning on Z (analyzing only compliers) induces selection bias; the causal effect of X on Y must be evaluated without post-treatment selection (or via appropriate causal estimands like ITT).
annotations.key_insight: To answer an intervention question, you cannot estimate the policy effect by restricting to a post-policy subgroup (compliers), because compliance is itself affected by the intervention and by risk factors for injury. Use an intention-to-treat comparison (policy-on vs policy-off) or methods that account for noncompliance without conditioning on it.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Team implements warm-up mandate (X). t1: On each game entry, players either comply or not (Z), influenced by acute fatigue/time pressure U. t2: Injury occurs or not during play (Y).
conditional_answers: Answer if the team compares all eligible player-games under policy-on vs policy-off (intention-to-treat): the causal claim that the mandate reduces injuries is supported (Yes), assuming no other concurrent injury-prevention changes and stable reporting. Answer if the team instead compares only compliers vs non-compliers within the policy period: the conclusion would be biased and could flip (would become No/Ambiguous).
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: This is a Level-2 (interventional) question about the effect of implementing a warm-up mandate (X) on injury risk (Y). The key trap is post-intervention selection: compliance (Z) occurs after X and is causally affected by X, so conditioning on Z does not generally identify the causal effect of X on Y. However, the claim as stated is about the policy intervention itself (do(X)=1 vs do(X)=0). The correct estimand is the intention-to-treat effect: compare injury rates under the mandate versus no mandate across all eligible player-games, without restricting to compliers. Under the causal structure, X increases the probability of compliance, and compliance is a mechanism through which injuries can be reduced. Provided there are no unblocked backdoor paths between X and Y at the policy level (e.g., no simultaneous changes in minutes management or medical staffing that coincide with the mandate), the interventional contrast do(X)=1 vs do(X)=0 captures the policy’s causal effect. Therefore, the causal conclusion that mandating the warm-up reduces injuries is valid when evaluated as an intervention effect (not as a per-protocol 'complier-only' association), so the label is Yes.

scenario: A professional soccer club evaluates a new coaching policy: after any match where the team concedes 2+ goals, the head coach mandates an extra high-intensity conditioning session the next day. Analysts compare subsequent-match defensive performance between weeks where the extra session was mandated versus weeks where it was not, and find that weeks with the extra session are followed by fewer goals conceded in the next match. The club concludes the policy causally improves defense and decides to mandate it permanently.
claim: Mandating an extra high-intensity conditioning session after conceding 2+ goals causes the team to concede fewer goals in the next match.

variables.X: Mandated extra high-intensity conditioning session the day after a match (policy on/off)
variables.Y: Goals conceded in the next match (defensive performance)
variables.Z: Opponent strength and match context that triggered the mandate (e.g., facing top-tier attacks, red cards, injuries, congested schedule), which both increases goals conceded in the trigger match and influences next-match goals conceded

annotations.causal_structure: Time-varying process: prior defensive outcomes and match context influence whether X is assigned; the same evolving context also affects future Y. Past Y (or its drivers) -> X, and shared evolving factors Z_t -> X and Z_t -> Y.
annotations.key_insight: Because the extra session is assigned reactively based on recent defensive failure and changing match context, naive comparisons mix the effect of the policy with the effect of the underlying time-varying difficulty/injuries/fatigue that drive both assignment and future defense.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Team plays Match k with context Z_t0 (opponent strength, red cards, fatigue) influencing goals conceded in Match k. t1: Observing 2+ conceded triggers X (extra session) assigned at t1. t2: Next match defensive outcome Y at Match k+1 is influenced by updated context Z_t2 (lineup health, fatigue from congestion, opponent strength) and potentially by X; but Z evolves partly from earlier Z and match outcomes.
conditional_answers: Answer would change if (i) X were randomized independent of recent defensive outcomes and match context, or (ii) the analysis correctly adjusted for the full time-varying history that drives both assignment and future defense (e.g., using marginal structural models with appropriate weights) including opponent strength, injuries, fatigue, red cards, and schedule congestion.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because the observed association after 'mandating X' does not identify the causal effect of an intervention do(X) when treatment assignment is time-varying and depends on prior outcomes and evolving context. Here, X is not assigned exogenously: it is triggered by conceding 2+ goals, which is itself a downstream indicator of latent and observed match context Z (opponent quality, lineup disruptions, fatigue, in-game events). Those same factors Z also affect the next-match goals conceded Y. Thus there is an open backdoor path X <- (prior defensive outcome / match context history) <- Z -> Y, and additionally Z evolves over time (Z_t0 -> Z_t2), so simple adjustment with static covariates or ignoring history fails to block confounding. The reduction in next-match goals conceded could reflect regression to more typical opponents, recovery of injured defenders, less congested scheduling, or reversion after an unusually bad match—factors that both increase the chance X is assigned and independently improve (or worsen) Y. Therefore the comparison of mandated-versus-not weeks does not estimate the interventional effect of mandating the extra session, so the causal conclusion 'X causes lower Y' is not warranted.

scenario: In competitive volleyball, coaches often substitute their setter when the team loses 3 consecutive points. Data shows that after such substitutions, the team still loses the set 80% of the time. The board concludes the substitution policy is ineffective and disrupts the team.
claim: Substituting the setter (X) causes the team to lose the set (Y).

variables.X: Substituting the setter
variables.Y: Losing the set
variables.Z: Negative Momentum / Opponent Dominance (The team is already being outplayed)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (Opponent is dominating) triggers X (Coach tries a sub) and Z causes Y (Loss). The intervention is reactive to a negative trajectory.
annotations.key_insight: The substitution is a 'Hail Mary' attempt to stop a loss that is already in progress. The high loss rate reflects the situation that triggered the sub, not the effect of the sub itself.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z (0-3 run) at t0 -> X (sub) at t1 -> Y (loss) at t2.
conditional_answers: No. It is likely that without the sub, the loss rate would have been equal or higher (e.g. 90%). The sub might have improved the odds slightly, even if the absolute outcome was still a loss.
label: No
correct_reasoning: This is a Reactive Intervention (L2). The coach intervenes (X) because the probability of Y is already high due to Z (momentum/performance gap). Comparing P(Y|X) to P(Y|no X) is biased because 'no X' usually implies the team was playing well enough not to need a sub. The intervention did not cause the loss; the bad performance that triggered the intervention did.

scenario: A soccer club’s analyst reports that players who log more high-intensity sprint distance per match tend to have higher post-match hamstring soreness ratings. A coach concludes that sprint distance causes soreness and proposes reducing sprinting demands in training and matches to prevent soreness.
claim: The observed positive association between high-intensity sprint distance and hamstring soreness does not by itself establish that increasing sprint distance causes more soreness, because fitter or more competitively deployed players may both sprint more and be more likely to report soreness due to heavier workloads and match roles.

variables.X: High-intensity sprint distance recorded in a match (e.g., meters above a speed threshold)
variables.Y: Post-match hamstring soreness rating (self-report or physio scale within 24 hours)
variables.Z: Underlying workload/role intensity (e.g., being a starting winger in a high-press system, total minutes played, and cumulative recent load) that influences both sprint distance and soreness

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y, with an observed association X <-> Y induced by the common cause Z
annotations.key_insight: In observational match data, sprint distance is partly a proxy for role and accumulated load; without measuring/adjusting for that common cause, the X–Y association is not a causal effect of sprinting itself.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t-7 to t0 (recent cumulative load and tactical role) increases X at t0 (match sprint distance) and independently increases Y at t0+1 (next-day soreness); thus X and Y correlate even if X has no direct causal effect on Y.
conditional_answers: Answer if asked whether sprinting should be reduced: Not from this association alone; you would need either randomization (e.g., experimentally altered sprint exposure) or credible adjustment for Z (minutes, role, pressing intensity, prior load, baseline hamstring status) to estimate the causal effect of X on Y.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: At Pearl L1 we are restricted to associational statements. The coach’s original causal leap (X causes Y) is not licensed by the reported correlation because there exists a plausible omitted common cause Z. Specifically, Z (role intensity and accumulated workload) increases X (players in demanding roles and with more minutes will sprint more) and also increases Y (those same players experience more muscle fatigue and soreness). In a DAG, Z opens a backdoor path X <- Z -> Y, which creates an association between X and Y even if the direct causal arrow X -> Y were weak or absent. Therefore, the correct L1 conclusion is the claim: the association alone does not identify causation, and the correlation is explainable by confounding through Z.

scenario: A soccer club’s star striker finishes a match with mild hamstring tightness. The medical staff has a policy: if the post-match tightness score is above a threshold, they prescribe an added recovery day (no sprinting) before the next match; otherwise the player trains normally. In this particular week, the striker reports high tightness and is given the added recovery day, then plays the next match and does not suffer a hamstring strain. A fan argues: “The added recovery day prevented a strain; if he had trained normally, he would have strained.” The club wants to know whether that counterfactual statement is true for this specific week.
claim: For this specific week, if the striker had not been given the added recovery day, he would have suffered a hamstring strain in the next match.

variables.X: Added recovery day prescribed by staff (no sprinting) between matches
variables.Y: Hamstring strain occurring in the next match (yes/no)
variables.Z: Underlying hamstring vulnerability that week (micro-tear/fatigue state) that influences both the tightness report and true injury risk

annotations.causal_structure: Z increases tightness report and baseline injury risk Y. High reported tightness triggers X. X reduces injury risk by preventing overload. In the actual world, X occurs and preempts the injury pathway that would have produced Y under no recovery; the absence of Y is therefore not evidence that Z was harmless.
annotations.key_insight: At L3 we ask a unit-level counterfactual: whether Y would have occurred in the same week for the same player if X were different. Here X can prevent (preempt) the injury mechanism, so observing no injury under X does not mean the player was safe; it can be precisely because X acted early.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Z (micro-damage/fatigue) exists after the prior match. t1: tightness is reported/assessed; policy assigns X based on this. t2: training load differs due to X. t3: next match occurs and Y (strain) may or may not occur.
conditional_answers: Answer is Yes if (i) Z was sufficiently high that, holding all else in that week fixed, normal training would have crossed the tissue-failure threshold producing Y, and (ii) the added recovery day reduced load enough to keep the tissue below that threshold. Answer would become Ambiguous if X were assigned for reasons unrelated to true vulnerability (e.g., rotation/rest for tactical reasons) or if multiple other unmodeled interventions changed simultaneously.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We are evaluating a counterfactual of necessity for this specific instance: whether Y_{X=0}=1 given that we observed X=1 and Y=0. The causal model posits an early-acting prevention pathway where X intervenes between the latent vulnerability Z and the injury outcome Y by reducing subsequent load. Because Z can be high in the actual world while Y is still 0 (due to X), the absence of injury does not imply the striker was uninjurable; it is compatible with a world in which, had X been removed while keeping the same Z and week-level conditions, the overload mechanism would have proceeded and produced Y. This is an Early Preemption structure: X occurs before the injury mechanism can manifest, blocking the otherwise sufficient pathway from Z to Y. Under the stated assumptions (Z high enough and X strong enough to avert threshold crossing), the claim that the added recovery day prevented a strain for this week is causally valid, so the label is Yes.

scenario: A soccer club considers a new in-game coaching policy: at the 60th minute, if the team is not leading, the coach makes an “attacking triple-sub” (three offensive substitutions within five minutes). Analysts compare matches where the triple-sub happened vs. matches where it did not, and observe that the triple-sub matches have a higher probability of conceding a late goal and a lower probability of winning. The front office asks whether they should ban the triple-sub policy.
claim: Banning the 60th-minute attacking triple-sub would increase the team’s win probability because the triple-sub causes more late goals conceded and fewer wins.

variables.X: Implementing the 60th-minute attacking triple-sub policy (yes/no) in a match
variables.Y: Match outcome after minute 60 (e.g., win probability or goal differential at full time)
variables.Z: Minute-60 match state and trajectory (scoreline, opponent strength, red cards, fatigue, expected-goals trend up to minute 60) that drives both the decision to triple-sub and the likelihood of winning/conceding late

annotations.causal_structure: Z (minute-60 state/trajectory) affects X (triple-sub decision) and also affects Y (final outcome). Additionally, earlier match events influence both Z and Y, making Z a time-varying confounder that evolves with the game.
annotations.key_insight: The triple-sub is typically triggered by deteriorating match conditions (trailing, fatigue, opponent dominance). Those same conditions predict poor late outcomes, so naive comparisons of X vs. not-X mix the effect of the intervention with the effect of the evolving match state that prompted it.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0 (kickoff to 60') produces evolving match state Z at t1 (minute 60). At t1 the coach chooses X based on Z. From t1 to t2 (full time), both Z and X influence Y.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous: If the triple-sub were randomly assigned (or assigned by an exogenous rule unrelated to Z) then the observed association could be interpreted causally; if it is primarily chosen in worse match states Z, the association likely overstates harm (or could even mask benefit).
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: We are being asked an L2 question about the effect of an intervention: do(X=ban/avoid the triple-sub) on Y (winning/late goals). The observed data compare matches with X=1 vs X=0, but X is not assigned independently; it is chosen reactively based on the evolving match state Z at minute 60. Z is a time-varying confounder: it is a common cause of X (coach is more likely to triple-sub when trailing, fatigued, or being outplayed) and Y (those same states make conceding late and losing more likely). Therefore, P(Y|X) is not equal to P(Y|do(X)) unless we correctly block the backdoor path X <- Z -> Y with adequate measurement and modeling of Z as it evolves. However, even conditioning on a coarse Z (e.g., just scoreline) may be insufficient because unmeasured components of Z (true fatigue, tactical mismatch, opponent adjustments, red-card risk, xG momentum) can remain and keep the backdoor path partially open. Without a credible identification strategy (randomization, a valid instrument such as an exogenous substitution constraint, a well-specified g-method / marginal structural model using rich time-stamped covariates, or a natural experiment), we cannot determine whether the triple-sub is harmful, beneficial, or neutral. Hence the claim that banning the triple-sub would increase win probability is not justified from the association alone, and the correct label is Ambiguous rather than No, because the direction and magnitude of the causal effect remain unidentified with the information given.

scenario: A tennis coach reviews a season where a star player missed several tournaments due to a wrist injury. The coach argues that the player should have switched to a lighter racquet earlier in the season. In support, the coach notes that in the actual season, the player switched to a lighter racquet only after the injury, and after the switch the player’s pain reports decreased and match availability improved. The coach then makes a counterfactual claim: 'If the player had used the lighter racquet from the start, the player would still have suffered the same wrist injury (because the wrist was already fragile), but would have recovered faster and missed fewer tournaments.'
claim: If the player had switched to a lighter racquet from the start of the season, the player would still have suffered the same wrist injury, but would have recovered faster and missed fewer tournaments.

variables.X: Using a lighter racquet from the start of the season (equipment intervention)
variables.Y: Number of tournaments missed during the season (availability/participation outcome)
variables.Z: Wrist injury severity and recovery trajectory (mediating health process affected by X)

annotations.causal_structure: X affects Z (load on the wrist and inflammation), and Z affects Y (missed tournaments). The claim implicitly holds the injury occurrence/severity constant while changing X, even though X would also change Z and thus downstream Y.
annotations.key_insight: You cannot evaluate the effect of an intervention while simultaneously 'fixing' a mediator that lies on the causal pathway from that intervention to the outcome; this mixes incompatible (cross-world) assumptions.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: X (racquet choice) influences cumulative wrist load; t1: Z (injury severity/inflammation) evolves; t2: Y (tournaments missed) is realized based on Z and medical decisions.
conditional_answers: Answer if you intervene on X but allow Z to change naturally: the effect on Y depends on how much X reduces wrist load and thus changes Z. Answer if you (incorrectly) hold Z fixed to its actual-season value while changing X: you are asking an incoherent counterfactual because Z is downstream of X.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it asserts a counterfactual effect of X on Y while stipulating that the wrist injury (Z) would be 'the same' as in the actual world. In the causal model, X -> Z -> Y: racquet choice changes mechanical load and thus changes the injury severity and recovery trajectory Z, which in turn drives missed tournaments Y. Therefore, the counterfactual world where X is changed generally implies a different Z, not the same Z as observed. Holding Z fixed to its factual value while intervening on X is a mediator-fixing (cross-world) error: it combines Z from the factual world with X from the counterfactual world, which is not a coherent single world under the assumed causal structure. A valid counterfactual must either (i) change X and let Z evolve according to the model to infer Y, or (ii) ask a controlled direct effect question explicitly defined as changing X while intervening to set Z, which is not what the coach justified. Hence the stated conclusion does not follow causally.

scenario: A professional soccer club considers an in-season intervention: mandating that all starters use a new GPS-based training-load app that enforces a weekly 'red-zone' cap (automatic reduced drills once a player exceeds the cap). The sports science department presents a mid-season analysis: among players who were put on the app, the rate of soft-tissue injuries over the next 6 weeks is higher than among players not put on the app. Coaches conclude the app is causing injuries and want to stop using it. However, the rollout was not randomized: the head physio prioritized the app for players flagged as 'high risk' based on recent fatigue markers and minor niggles, and the physio also adjusted other recovery modalities (e.g., massage, rest days) in response to the same flags. Additionally, when a player reports soreness, coaches often immediately reduce minutes in matches, which changes subsequent training exposure and injury risk.
claim: Mandating the training-load app (X) increases soft-tissue injury risk (Y), so stopping the app will reduce injuries.

variables.X: Intervention: mandatory adoption of the GPS-based training-load app with enforced weekly red-zone caps
variables.Y: Outcome: soft-tissue injury occurrence within the next 6 weeks (e.g., hamstring strain, calf strain)
variables.Z: Time-varying confounding mechanism: evolving latent injury risk/fatigue status (proxied by fatigue biomarkers, soreness reports, recent minutes played) that influences both app assignment and future injury, and is itself affected by prior training loads and prior near-injuries

annotations.causal_structure: Dynamic treatment assignment: prior fatigue/near-injury risk Z_t affects whether X_t is imposed and also affects injury Y_{t+1}; prior exposure/training load (partly altered by earlier X_{t-1}) affects Z_t, creating treatment-confounder feedback. Additional co-interventions (recovery changes) are triggered by Z_t and correlate with X_t.
annotations.key_insight: Because Z changes over time and is influenced by earlier training decisions (and possibly earlier app use), naive comparisons or standard regression adjustment can produce biased estimates of the causal effect of X on Y; without a clearly specified intervention protocol and appropriate longitudinal causal methods, the direction and magnitude of the effect are not identifiable from the described evidence.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: baseline fatigue/biomarkers and recent minutes define Z0; t1: physio mandates app for high-risk players (X1) and adjusts recovery; t2: training load and match minutes change, updating fatigue status Z1; t3: injury Y observed over subsequent weeks; Z continues to evolve and influences further app enforcement and minutes.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous: If X were randomly assigned (or assigned via a known protocol independent of potential outcomes given measured history) and co-interventions were held constant, we could estimate whether the app causally increases or decreases injuries; if instead X is preferentially assigned to high-risk players and Z is incompletely measured, the observed higher injury rate under X could be entirely due to time-varying confounding by indication rather than harm from the app.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is a Level-2 (interventional) question: we want the effect of imposing the app policy X on subsequent injury Y, i.e., compare Y under do(X=1) versus do(X=0). The observed association P(Y|X) is not equal to the interventional quantity P(Y|do(X)) because treatment assignment is endogenous over time. Specifically, the evolving fatigue/latent injury risk Z_t both (i) increases the probability the physio mandates/enforces the app (X_t) and (ii) increases future injury risk (Y_{t+1}), creating an unblocked backdoor path X_t <- Z_t -> Y_{t+1}. Moreover, Z_t is itself affected by earlier training decisions and possibly earlier app enforcement (X_{t-1} -> training load -> Z_t), so Z_t is a time-varying confounder affected by prior treatment. Therefore, naive adjustment (or stratifying on contemporaneous Z_t) can induce bias because it conditions on a variable on the causal pathway from earlier X to later Y while also acting as a confounder for later X. Given the described rollout (risk-prioritized adoption, concurrent recovery changes, and minutes reductions responding to soreness), the data do not identify the causal effect of X without additional assumptions (e.g., sequential ignorability with rich measured history) and appropriate longitudinal methods (e.g., g-methods). Hence the claim that stopping the app will reduce injuries is not justified, but neither is the opposite; the sign of the true causal effect remains undetermined from the provided information, so the correct label is Ambiguous.

scenario: An NBA team introduces a new wearable-based “fatigue management” policy. When a player’s rolling 3-game workload score exceeds a threshold, the staff mandates an extra rest day and limits minutes in the next game. Midseason, an analyst compares games where players were put on the rest/limit protocol versus games where they were not, and finds that protocol games have lower win probability and worse player efficiency ratings. The analyst proposes to stop using the protocol because it “hurts performance.” Coaches counter that the protocol is meant to prevent late-season injuries and that it’s triggered precisely when players are already fatigued.
claim: Mandating the wearable-triggered rest/minutes-limit protocol causes worse next-game performance, so the team should stop the protocol to improve wins.

variables.X: Implementing the wearable-triggered rest/minutes-limit protocol for a player before/for a given game (extra rest day and/or reduced minutes)
variables.Y: Next-game performance (team win probability and player efficiency rating in that game)
variables.Z: Player fatigue/injury-risk state and recent workload trend that both triggers the protocol and independently reduces performance

annotations.causal_structure: Z(t-1) (fatigue/workload) affects X(t) (rest/limit decision) and directly affects Y(t) (next-game performance); additionally Y(t-1) can affect Z(t-1) (hard minutes in close games increase fatigue), creating time-varying confounding where past outcomes influence future treatment assignment via fatigue.
annotations.key_insight: Because the protocol is triggered by evolving fatigue that is itself affected by prior games, naive comparisons of treated vs untreated games mix the effect of the protocol with the effect of underlying fatigue; without a strategy that handles time-varying confounding, the causal effect of intervening on rest is not identified.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Y at t-1 (previous game intensity/close-game minutes) increases Z at t-1 (fatigue); Z at t-1 triggers X at t (rest/minutes limit); Z at t-1 also decreases Y at t (next-game performance).
conditional_answers: Ambiguous: If the analysis properly adjusts for time-varying confounding (e.g., using marginal structural models with inverse probability weights based on observed workload/fatigue history) and still finds a negative causal effect of X on Y, then the claim could be valid. If the observed association disappears or reverses after appropriate adjustment (or under a randomized rest policy), then the claim is flawed. If key drivers of Z (true fatigue, nagging injuries, unrecorded practice load, travel stress) are unmeasured, the direction and magnitude remain uncertain.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is a Level-2 (interventional) question about the effect of setting X (mandating rest/minutes limits) on Y (next-game performance). The observed comparison between protocol games and non-protocol games is not an estimate of P(Y|do(X)) because X is assigned based on an evolving state Z (fatigue/workload) that both (i) causes the staff to apply the protocol and (ii) directly worsens next-game performance. Moreover, Z is time-varying and is itself affected by prior outcomes/contexts (e.g., previous close games produce high minutes, which increases fatigue), so conditioning only on contemporaneous covariates or doing a simple regression can leave an unblocked backdoor path through the treatment history and Z-history. Therefore, from the described evidence alone, we cannot determine whether intervening to remove the protocol would improve performance (the negative association could be entirely due to fatigued players being selected into treatment), nor can we conclude the protocol is beneficial without a design that identifies the causal effect. The correct conclusion is that the claim is not identifiable from the naive comparison; additional assumptions, better measurement of Z over time, or an identification strategy for time-varying confounding is required.

scenario: A soccer club evaluates whether its new high-intensity pressing training program improved match results. Mid-season, the head coach mandates the program for all starters. Analysts compare matches where the team logged higher average pressing intensity (measured by high-speed runs and pressures per 90) to matches with lower intensity, and they run a regression controlling for the opponent's expected goals (xG) and the team's in-match fatigue index (derived from GPS load). They conclude the training caused better results because higher pressing matches are associated with more wins after adjustment.
claim: Mandating the high-intensity pressing training program (X) caused the team to win more matches (Y), because after controlling for fatigue (Z) the effect remains positive.

variables.X: Intervention: mandated high-intensity pressing training program for starters (club policy implemented mid-season)
variables.Y: Outcome: match result / win probability in subsequent matches
variables.Z: Mediator/mechanism: in-match fatigue index (GPS load / exertion), which is affected by the training and also affects match results

annotations.causal_structure: X affects Z (pressing training increases exertion and fatigue); Z affects Y (fatigue lowers late-game performance and win probability); X may also affect Y through other pathways (tactical coordination, opponent disruption). Conditioning on Z blocks part of X's causal effect and can distort the estimated total effect of X on Y.
annotations.key_insight: Fatigue is downstream of the training intervention; adjusting for it answers a different causal question (a controlled direct effect) and can bias the estimate of the total policy impact.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: club mandates pressing training (X). t1: training changes players' exertion and fatigue profile during matches (Z). t2: fatigue influences late-match execution and results (Y).
conditional_answers: If the estimand is the total effect of mandating pressing training on winning, then controlling for fatigue is inappropriate. If instead the estimand is the direct effect of training holding fatigue fixed at a set level (a controlled direct effect), then controlling for fatigue could be aligned with that narrower question, but it still requires additional assumptions (e.g., no unmeasured mediator-outcome confounding).
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it treats Z (fatigue) as a confounder to be adjusted for when estimating the causal effect of the intervention X on outcome Y. Under the stated causal structure, Z is caused by X (X -> Z) and also causally affects Y (Z -> Y). Therefore Z lies on a causal pathway from X to Y and is a mediator. Conditioning on a mediator blocks part of the causal effect of X on Y, so the regression coefficient after adjusting for Z does not identify the total causal effect of the policy intervention do(X) on match wins. Moreover, because Z is post-intervention, adjusting for it can introduce bias if there exist unmeasured common causes of Z and Y (e.g., match intensity, injuries, rotation decisions) that become active once conditioning occurs. Thus, the analysis cannot support the conclusion that mandating pressing training increased wins; at best it estimates a different quantity (a direct effect not through fatigue) under additional unverified assumptions.

scenario: An NBA team reviews a playoff series where their star guard played through a mild ankle sprain. The medical staff gave him a pregame painkilling injection and taped the ankle. He ended up scoring 38 points, but in the fourth quarter he landed awkwardly and suffered a high-ankle sprain that sidelined him for the rest of the series. A debate erupts: did the injection 'cause' the severe injury, or would it have happened anyway given the minutes load and defensive pressure? Analysts propose a counterfactual: 'If he had not received the injection, would he have avoided the severe sprain?' The only data available are game video, minutes, and the fact that he played because he felt able to after the injection.
claim: If the star guard had not received the painkilling injection (X), he would not have suffered the high-ankle sprain later in the game (Y).

variables.X: Receiving a pregame painkilling injection (and associated numbing) to enable playing through an ankle sprain
variables.Y: Suffering a high-ankle sprain during the game (severe injury event)
variables.Z: Latent 'playability/participation' state: the joint's true stability plus willingness/ability to play heavy minutes (a mediator of X and a selection variable that depends on symptoms and risk tolerance)

annotations.causal_structure: X affects Z (symptom masking increases participation/usage). Z affects Y (more minutes, more explosive cuts, more exposure to contact/awkward landings). Unobserved ankle instability and coaching necessity also affect Z and Y. The counterfactual question is implicitly conditioned on Z=played heavy minutes, but Z is itself affected by X, creating a cross-world selection problem when asking about Y under do(X=0) while holding 'he played the same way' fixed.
annotations.key_insight: The claim mixes two counterfactual worlds: it asks about Y under no injection while implicitly keeping the post-treatment participation path (Z) that occurred only because of the injection. Conditioning on a post-treatment selection/participation variable makes the counterfactual not identifiable without extra assumptions about how playing time and movement would change under X=0.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: baseline mild ankle sprain and joint instability exist. t1: injection given (X). t2: due to reduced pain, he plays heavy minutes and attacks the rim more (Z). t3: awkward landing/contact occurs; severe high-ankle sprain happens (Y).
conditional_answers: Answer if (i) under X=0 he would still have played the same minutes and movement profile (Z unchanged), and (ii) the injection only affects injury risk through Z (no direct biomechanical effect): then the injection would not change Y given fixed Z, so the claim would be false. Answer if instead (i) under X=0 he would have self-limited and played fewer explosive cuts (Z would decrease), and (ii) exposure is a major driver of Y: then the injection could increase Y via increased exposure, making the claim potentially true. Without knowing how Z would counterfactually change and whether there is a direct physiological effect of numbing on mechanics, the claim cannot be settled.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is a Level-3 question because it asks a counterfactual: Y_{X=0} for the same player/game. The observed world includes both X=1 and the downstream participation/usage state Z that followed from X. The claim implicitly asserts Y_{X=0}=0 because Y_{X=1}=1, but that inference is invalid because it conditions on a post-treatment selection variable: we only observe the severe injury in the world where he both received the injection and then played heavy minutes (Z=high). To evaluate the claim we would need the counterfactual distribution of Z under X=0 (would he have played, and how), and whether X has any direct effect on Y beyond Z (e.g., altered proprioception/landing mechanics). Because Z is affected by X and also driven by latent ankle instability and coaching necessity that also affect Y, comparing the 'played-through' scenario to a hypothetical 'no injection' scenario while holding participation fixed mixes incompatible (cross-world) conditions. Therefore the truth of the claim is not identifiable from the described information; it could be true if X increases exposure via Z or false if the injury was primarily driven by underlying instability and a stochastic landing event that would have occurred regardless. Hence the correct label is Ambiguous.

scenario: An NBA team introduces a new 'load management' policy: any player reporting soreness on the daily wellness app is automatically held out of back-to-back games. Midseason, the team notices that players who are held out under the policy have a higher rate of soft-tissue injuries in the following month than players who are not held out. A staff member concludes the policy is causing injuries and proposes ending it.
claim: Holding players out of back-to-back games (load management) increases next-month soft-tissue injury risk.

variables.X: Intervention: holding a player out of back-to-back games due to the new load-management rule
variables.Y: Outcome: soft-tissue injury occurrence in the following month
variables.Z: Time-varying confounder: evolving underlying tissue fatigue/soreness status (and related training load) that both triggers being held out and predicts near-future injury

annotations.causal_structure: Z(t) (fatigue/soreness) influences X(t) (held out) and also influences Y(t+1) (injury). Additionally, past fatigue and micro-injuries can affect both future fatigue Z(t+1) and future treatment assignment X(t+1), creating a time-varying confounding path that is not blocked by naive comparisons.
annotations.key_insight: Because the decision to hold out is a reactive intervention driven by changing fatigue/soreness, the observed association between being held out and later injury can reflect who gets held out (high-risk players) rather than the causal effect of the holdout itself.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (accumulated fatigue/micro-damage) -> X at t0 (held out next back-to-back) and Z at t0 -> Y at t1 (injury next month). Also Y at t1 can influence future Z at t2 and future X at t2 via rehab and altered minutes.
conditional_answers: If players are randomly assigned to be held out independent of their current fatigue/soreness (or if fatigue is perfectly measured and appropriately handled with a valid causal method for time-varying confounding, e.g., marginal structural models), then we could estimate whether X causally changes Y. If, instead, holdouts are triggered by unmeasured or imperfectly measured fatigue, then the higher injury rate among held-out players can arise even if the policy is protective.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: This is an L2 question about the effect of an intervention do(X)=1 (holding a player out) on Y (future injury). The observed comparison P(Y|X=1) vs P(Y|X=0) is not, by itself, an estimate of P(Y|do(X=1)) vs P(Y|do(X=0)) because treatment assignment is confounded by a time-varying state Z (fatigue/soreness) that both causes the decision to hold out and causes injury risk. The backdoor path X <- Z -> Y remains open unless Z is measured and correctly adjusted for across time; moreover, Z is dynamic and affected by prior workload and possibly prior injuries, so naive adjustment can fail if Z is itself influenced by earlier treatment or performance processes. Therefore the data pattern (held-out players later get injured more) does not logically identify the sign of the causal effect: it could mean the policy is harmful, or it could mean the policy is applied to higher-risk players and is partially protective but not enough to offset their baseline risk. With only the described observational comparison, the causal claim cannot be validated or refuted, so the correct label is Ambiguous.

scenario: A soccer club evaluates whether its new high-press training program improved match results. Analysts compare games where the team executed a high press (as coded by tracking data) versus games where they did not, and they adjust for 'time spent pressing' to isolate the direct effect of the program. They find that after adjustment, the high-press training appears to have no benefit (or even a slight negative effect) on points earned.
claim: Because points earned are unchanged (or worse) after controlling for time spent pressing, implementing the high-press training program does not causally improve match results.

variables.X: Implementing the high-press training program (team adopts the new pressing drills and tactical scheme)
variables.Y: Match outcome (e.g., points earned per match / win probability)
variables.Z: In-match pressing intensity or time spent pressing (a downstream tactical behavior influenced by the training program)

annotations.causal_structure: X -> Z -> Y, with possible additional direct path X -> Y (e.g., improved coordination or fitness). Conditioning on Z blocks the mediated pathway and can also induce bias if Z is affected by other match factors.
annotations.key_insight: Z is a mediator caused by X; adjusting for Z answers a different question (direct effect) and can erase the total causal effect of X on Y.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: X at preseason (t0) changes pressing behavior Z during matches (t1), which influences match outcomes Y (t2).
conditional_answers: If the goal is the total effect of adopting the high-press program on match outcomes, do not condition on pressing intensity Z. If the goal is specifically the direct effect not through pressing (a narrower estimand), then conditioning on Z may be relevant but still requires strong assumptions about other causes of Z.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it treats an adjusted association as the causal effect of an intervention. In the assumed causal graph, implementing the training program (X) is designed to change pressing behavior (Z), and pressing behavior is one mechanism through which X affects match outcomes (Y). Conditioning on Z is therefore post-treatment adjustment: it blocks the causal path X -> Z -> Y and removes (part of) the very effect we want when asking whether adopting the program helps overall. Thus, the estimated effect after controlling for Z is not the total causal effect of X on Y; it is closer to a direct effect that excludes the mediated pathway. Consequently, observing 'no benefit after controlling for Z' does not imply that intervening to implement the program fails to improve results; it may simply reflect overcontrol of a mediator (and potentially additional bias if other match conditions also influence Z).

scenario: A soccer club considers a new in-game hydration protocol: at minute 30, the staff triggers an extra “micro-break” (ball-out-of-play pause plus quick sideline fluids) for players whose GPS shows high high-intensity running in the first 25 minutes. Analysts want to estimate the causal effect of implementing the protocol across matches on second-half cramp incidence. However, the training load in the preceding week influences both early-match running intensity and cramp risk, and coaches also adjust the micro-break decision based on early-match signs of fatigue. The club proposes a model that estimates the intervention effect while controlling for the previous week’s training load and baseline fitness, but explicitly does not control for early-match running intensity because it is affected by the protocol decision rule and lies on the pathway to cramps.
claim: If the club intervenes to implement the micro-break hydration protocol and adjusts for prior-week training load (and baseline fitness), the estimated effect on second-half cramp incidence identifies the causal effect of the protocol, because prior-week training load is an unblocked backdoor confounder that must be blocked, while early-match running intensity should not be adjusted for since it is downstream of the protocol decision rule and part of the causal mechanism.

variables.X: Intervention: Implement the minute-30 micro-break hydration protocol (club policy applied across matches) versus standard play (no added micro-break hydration).
variables.Y: Outcome: Second-half cramp incidence rate (e.g., proportion of players experiencing cramps after halftime).
variables.Z: Confounder: Prior-week training load (e.g., acute workload/ACWR or total high-speed distance in training), which affects both likelihood/need of micro-break hydration and cramp risk.

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y; X -> (early-match running intensity / fatigue signs) -> Y. Coaches use early fatigue signs to trigger the protocol, but the policy is evaluated as an intervention that sets X at the match level; blocking Z closes the backdoor path X <- Z -> Y. Adjusting for early-match running intensity would block part of the causal effect (mediator) and can induce bias if it is also influenced by unmeasured factors.
annotations.key_insight: For L2 identification, you must block true pre-treatment confounding (Z) to estimate do(X), but you must not adjust for post-treatment mediators that transmit the effect of X to Y.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z measured at t-7d (prior-week load) influences X decision at t0 (match protocol implementation) and influences Y at t1 (second-half cramps). X at t0 affects early-match intensity/fatigue at t0+25m, which affects Y at t1.
conditional_answers: Answer if (i) Z is measured before the match and is not affected by X, (ii) the intervention truly sets X independent of match-specific fatigue signals (i.e., policy is enforced rather than selectively applied), and (iii) no additional unmeasured common causes of X and Y remain after adjusting for Z and baseline fitness: then the claim holds and the causal effect of do(X) on Y is identifiable via backdoor adjustment on Z.
