If instead X is still selectively applied based on in-match fatigue (a post-baseline factor) without proper longitudinal methods, additional time-varying confounding could remain and the claim would no longer be guaranteed.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: We want the causal estimand E[Y | do(X=1)] - E[Y | do(X=0)]. In the observational regime, X is not randomized because prior-week training load Z influences both the likelihood that the protocol is implemented (X) and the probability of cramps (Y), creating the backdoor path X <- Z -> Y. This path is open unless we condition on Z (and any other pre-treatment common causes), so failing to adjust for Z yields confounding bias. Under the stated conditions, Z is pre-treatment and not affected by X, so conditioning on Z satisfies the backdoor criterion by blocking X <- Z -> Y while not blocking any causal paths from X to Y. Early-match running intensity/fatigue is downstream of X (part of the mechanism X -> mediator -> Y). Adjusting for it would remove part of the causal effect (overcontrol) and could also introduce bias if the mediator is influenced by other unmeasured factors. Therefore, adjusting for Z (and other pre-treatment covariates like baseline fitness) and not adjusting for the mediator correctly targets the interventional quantity do(X), making the claim valid.

scenario: A soccer club considers a new coaching policy: after any match where the team’s high press looks disorganized, the head coach orders an extra high-intensity pressing drill in the next training session. The analyst compares matches following 'extra drill weeks' vs 'normal weeks' and sees worse defensive outcomes after extra-drill weeks. The coach instead runs a small pilot in which, for a randomly chosen subset of weeks (regardless of how the last match looked), the team is assigned the extra pressing drill, and then compares subsequent match defense.
claim: In the randomized pilot, assigning the extra high-intensity pressing drill causes the team to concede fewer goals in the next match, even though observationally extra-drill weeks looked worse because they were usually scheduled after poor defensive performances.

variables.X: Intervention: assignment of an extra high-intensity pressing drill in the next training week (vs normal training load)
variables.Y: Outcome: goals conceded (or expected goals against) in the subsequent match
variables.Z: Time-varying confounder: prior-match defensive disorganization/fatigue that both triggers the coach to add the drill and also predicts conceding more goals next match

annotations.causal_structure: Z (prior-match defensive issues) influences X (coach assigns extra drill) and also influences Y (next-match goals conceded). Estimating the causal effect of X on Y requires breaking the Z->X backdoor path via random assignment or proper adjustment.
annotations.key_insight: The coach’s decision is reactive to recent performance, so naive comparisons mix the effect of the drill with the effect of the underlying defensive problem that prompted the drill.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: prior match reveals defensive disorganization/fatigue (Z). t1: coach assigns extra pressing drill (X). t2: next match goals conceded / xGA (Y). Z persists from t0 into t2, affecting Y directly and via readiness.
conditional_answers: Answer if you only observe club logs (non-random): extra-drill weeks may look worse due to Z->X and Z->Y confounding. Answer if you randomize assignment of extra drills (or perfectly adjust for Z): you can identify the causal effect of X on Y, which in this scenario is beneficial (fewer goals conceded).
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: This is a Level-2 (interventional) claim because it asserts what happens under an intervention do(X=extra drill) versus do(X=normal). In routine operations, X is not exogenous: the coach assigns extra drills in response to Z (recent defensive disorganization/fatigue), and Z also increases Y (conceding goals) in the next match. Thus the observational association P(Y|X) is biased by an unblocked backdoor path X<-Z->Y, and can even have the wrong sign. In the randomized pilot, X is assigned independently of Z, which blocks the backdoor path by design (X ⟂ Z). Therefore the contrast in outcomes between assigned extra-drill weeks and assigned normal weeks identifies the causal effect E[Y|do(X=extra)] - E[Y|do(X=normal)]. Given the pilot shows fewer goals conceded under assignment, the causal conclusion that the extra pressing drill reduces Y is valid despite the misleading observational correlation.

scenario: A soccer club pilots an AI-driven substitution policy mid-season. The model recommends earlier substitutions for players whose live GPS load and heart-rate patterns resemble prior fatigue-related injury episodes. Coaches adopt the policy for some matches but not others: they are more likely to follow it in high-stakes games (derbies, relegation six-pointers) and when the bench has strong replacement options. The analytics staff evaluates the policy by comparing matches where the coach 'followed the AI recommendation' vs matches where they did not, and reports that following the recommendation reduces late-match goals conceded and reduces hamstring injuries over the next 14 days.
claim: If the club forces coaches to follow the AI recommendation (do(X)=1) in all matches, the team will concede fewer late goals and suffer fewer hamstring injuries than if it does not (do(X)=0).

variables.X: Intervention: forcing adherence to the AI substitution recommendation (earlier subs when the model flags fatigue risk)
variables.Y: Outcome: (i) late-match goals conceded (75'+) and (ii) hamstring injury incidence within 14 days after the match
variables.Z: Time-varying confounding mechanism: evolving match context and player state that simultaneously affects adherence and outcomes (e.g., current scoreline, opponent strength, tactical urgency, player fatigue trajectory, bench depth, and prior-minute load), some of which is influenced by earlier substitution decisions

annotations.causal_structure: Dynamic treatment regime: pre-match factors (opponent strength, bench quality) and within-match evolving state (scoreline, tactical urgency, fatigue/load) affect both X (whether the coach adheres to the AI sub advice at time t) and Y (late goals and subsequent injury). Additionally, earlier adherence decisions change the subsequent match state (fatigue distribution, scoreline/tactics), which then affects later adherence and Y, creating treatment-confounder feedback.
annotations.key_insight: Because Z changes over time and is partly affected by earlier X, naive comparisons of adherence vs non-adherence (or standard regression adjusting for observed Z) can be biased; identifying the causal effect of forcing adherence requires a longitudinal causal model (e.g., g-formula / marginal structural models) and assumptions that may not hold with unmeasured tactical intent.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: pre-match opponent strength/bench depth -> influences baseline risk and likelihood of following AI. t1 (60-70'): evolving scoreline, pressing intensity, player load -> influences adherence decision X_t1. t2: adherence changes who plays minutes and tactical shape -> alters subsequent fatigue/scoreline (Z_t2). t3 (75-90'): late goals conceded realized; t4 (next 14 days): hamstring injury realized, influenced by accumulated load and substitutions.
conditional_answers: Answer if (a) all time-varying confounders Z are fully measured at each decision point, (b) there is no unmeasured coach intent/tactical hidden variable affecting both adherence and outcomes, (c) positivity holds (the club sometimes adheres and sometimes does not at every relevant Z history), and (d) the effect of forcing adherence is well-defined as a specific substitution protocol: then the causal effect of do(X)=1 could in principle be identified using marginal structural models or the g-formula. If any of these fail—especially unmeasured tactical urgency or hidden injury information—then the direction and magnitude of the effect remain uncertain.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: The claim is a Level-2 (interventional) statement about the effect of forcing adherence to the AI substitution rule, i.e., comparing Y under do(X)=1 versus do(X)=0. However, the observed association between adherence and outcomes is generated in a longitudinal setting with time-varying confounding: match context and player state Z_t both influence the coach's adherence decision and directly affect late goals and injury risk. Crucially, Z_t is not purely pre-treatment: earlier adherence decisions (earlier substitutions) change subsequent fatigue distribution, tactical shape, and even scoreline dynamics, which then feed back into later adherence decisions and into Y. This treatment–confounder feedback means that (i) a naive comparison of adherent vs non-adherent matches is not an unbiased estimate of the do-effect (unblocked backdoor paths through Z histories), and (ii) even 'adjusting for Z' with standard regression can induce bias because parts of Z are mediators of earlier X while also confounding later X. Therefore, without a fully specified longitudinal causal model and strong identification assumptions (sequential exchangeability/no unmeasured time-varying confounders, positivity, and a well-defined intervention), the data described do not suffice to conclude that forcing adherence will causally reduce late goals or injuries. The correct conclusion is that the causal effect is not identified from the stated evaluation design, so the claim remains ambiguous.

scenario: An NBA team pilots a new pre-game “high-intensity warmup” routine for two weeks. Coaches later report that players who did the routine had higher in-game shooting percentages than players who did not. The staff concludes the routine causally improves shooting and decides to mandate it for everyone.
claim: Mandating the high-intensity warmup routine (X) will increase players' in-game shooting percentage (Y).

variables.X: High-intensity warmup routine implemented before the game (mandated vs not used)
variables.Y: In-game shooting percentage for that game
variables.Z: Player health/fatigue status and minor injury management that influences both whether the routine is used and shooting performance

annotations.causal_structure: Z (fatigue/health) affects X (coaches skip/modify routine for tired or banged-up players) and also affects Y (shooting%). Z also evolves over time and is influenced by prior games/prior performance, which in turn affects future assignment to X.
annotations.key_insight: Warmup assignment is reactive to changing player condition; the observed association mixes the effect of the warmup with the effect of being healthy/rested.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Prior game load/performance influences t1 fatigue/health Z; t1 Z influences whether X is assigned pre-game; t2 shooting% Y is realized; t2 outcomes feed back into subsequent t3 load decisions that further change Z.
conditional_answers: If the routine were randomly assigned (or assigned by a rule independent of fatigue/health) and compliance were measured, then estimating the causal effect of X on Y would be more credible; under the current reactive assignment, the association is not causal.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because the comparison is not an interventionally valid estimate of the effect of X on Y. Assignment to the warmup (X) is confounded by player condition Z: coaches are more likely to allow the routine when a player is feeling good and to skip/scale it down when a player is fatigued or managing a minor injury. Z causally affects Y (healthy/rested players shoot better), so there is an open backdoor path X  Z  Y. Moreover, Z is time-varying: prior game load and prior performance affect current Z, which then affects current X and Y, and later outcomes can influence future load decisions that further shift Z. Therefore, the observed higher shooting% among those who did the routine can be explained by differences in Z rather than by the warmup itself. Without blocking the backdoor (e.g., via randomization or an appropriate time-varying adjustment strategy), we cannot conclude that mandating X would increase Y.

scenario: A baseball blog notices that starting pitchers who are pulled from the game early (fewer than 80 pitches) lose more often than pitchers who stay in for 100+ pitches. The blog advises managers to 'show faith' and leave starters in longer to improve win rates.
claim: Leaving a starting pitcher in for 100+ pitches causes the team to win more often.

variables.X: Pitcher duration (staying in for >100 pitches)
variables.Y: Winning the game
variables.Z: Pitcher performance/effectiveness on the day (giving up runs/hits)

annotations.causal_structure: Z (giving up runs) causes the manager to remove the pitcher (low X) and causes the team to lose (low Y). Conversely, if Z is good (no runs allowed), the manager leaves the pitcher in (high X) and the team wins (high Y).
annotations.key_insight: Pitch count is a survivor metric; pitchers only accrue high pitch counts if they are pitching well enough to not be pulled. The causation flows from Performance -> Duration, not Duration -> Performance.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z (performance) is realized innings 1-5. If Z is bad, X is truncated at t5. If Z is good, X extends to t9.
conditional_answers: No. Forcing a struggling pitcher to stay in (intervening on X) would likely increase runs allowed, not decrease them.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim gets the causal arrow backwards. High pitch counts (X) do not cause wins; rather, pitching well (Z) causes both the manager to allow a high pitch count (X) and the team to win (Y). This is a classic case of reverse causation via performance-based selection (survivorship bias).

scenario: A professional soccer club evaluates a new high-intensity interval training (HIIT) conditioning program introduced mid-season. The performance analyst compares players who 'fully adopted' the HIIT plan (completed at least 90% of prescribed sessions) versus players who did not, and finds the adopters improved their match running distance and had fewer soft-tissue injuries over the next 8 weeks. The analyst concludes the HIIT program causally improved fitness and reduced injuries, and recommends mandating it for the whole squad.
claim: Mandating the HIIT program (X) will cause higher match running distance and fewer soft-tissue injuries (Y) because players who complied with HIIT performed better and got injured less.

variables.X: Mandated HIIT conditioning program (intervention assignment)
variables.Y: Subsequent performance and health: match running distance and soft-tissue injury incidence over the next 8 weeks
variables.Z: Compliance/availability status driven by latent factors (e.g., baseline fitness, existing niggles, motivation, and coach/medical restrictions) that both affect ability to complete HIIT and affect future performance/injury risk

annotations.causal_structure: X influences compliance C; Z (baseline fitness/latent injury risk/motivation/medical restrictions) also influences C; Z also directly influences Y. Comparing outcomes within the compliant group conditions on collider C, inducing spurious association between X and Z and biasing the estimated effect of X on Y.
annotations.key_insight: Compliance is post-intervention and is jointly caused by treatment assignment and player health/fitness constraints; conditioning on it opens a non-causal path that makes the program look better than it would under a mandate.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Club introduces/assigns HIIT (X). t1: Players comply or not (C) based on Z and X. t2: Over weeks 1-8, performance and injuries are realized (Y), also affected by Z.
conditional_answers: Answer is 'No' if the analysis conditions on compliance (e.g., only includes players who completed ≥90% sessions) or otherwise uses a per-protocol comparison without valid adjustment/IV methods; the effect of a mandate should be estimated by intention-to-treat or with a valid causal strategy that handles noncompliance.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it infers the causal effect of an intervention (mandating HIIT, X) from an analysis that conditions on compliance, which is a post-intervention variable. Let C denote 'fully adopted HIIT'. C is caused by X (being assigned/mandated increases the chance of adopting) and also by Z (baseline fitness, existing niggles, motivation, and medical restrictions determine whether a player can safely complete HIIT). Z also causally affects Y (fitter, less-injured, more-motivated players both run more and get injured less). When the analyst restricts to C=1 (or adjusts for C), they condition on a collider on the path X -> C <- Z, which opens a non-causal association between X and Z. This induces bias: within the compliant group, assignment/mandate status becomes statistically related to Z, and since Z affects Y, the comparison of Y across X is confounded even if X were otherwise randomized. Therefore, the observed advantage among compliers cannot be interpreted as the causal effect of mandating HIIT on performance/injuries. A valid L2 estimand would require intention-to-treat (effect of assignment/mandate regardless of compliance) or a design that addresses noncompliance (e.g., a valid instrument with exclusion and monotonicity), rather than conditioning on C.

scenario: A soccer club is deciding whether to mandate a new post-match recovery protocol. Historically, players who used the recovery protocol had fewer soft-tissue injuries later in the season, but the medical staff notes that they typically assign the protocol more strictly to players who had heavy minutes in the prior match. The club runs a pilot: for a month, the head coach mandates the recovery protocol for all players who played at least 30 minutes, regardless of perceived fatigue, and compares subsequent 14-day soft-tissue injury incidence to what would have happened under usual discretionary assignment.
claim: Mandating the recovery protocol for all players with ≥30 minutes will reduce 14-day soft-tissue injury incidence compared with the usual discretionary assignment, because the historical association was partly confounded by workload and the pilot blocks that backdoor path.

variables.X: Intervention: Mandated post-match recovery protocol (ice bath + compression + guided mobility) for all players who played ≥30 minutes
variables.Y: Outcome: Soft-tissue injury incidence within the next 14 days (e.g., hamstring/groin strain)
variables.Z: Confounder: Match workload/fatigue (minutes played, high-speed running distance) that influences both assignment to recovery and injury risk

annotations.causal_structure: Z -> X and Z -> Y; X -> Y. In observational data, Z opens a backdoor path X <- Z -> Y; the mandate sets X exogenously for the eligibility group, blocking the backdoor influence of Z on X.
annotations.key_insight: The observational correlation between recovery use and injuries is biased because workload drives both recovery assignment and injury risk; a mandate (do(X)) removes the Z -> X link, enabling a causal comparison for the targeted group.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (match workload) affects injury risk Y at t1 (next 14 days) and, under usual practice, affects recovery assignment X at t0+ (immediately post-match). The mandate replaces the usual Z->X decision rule during the pilot window.
conditional_answers: Answer is Yes if the mandate is enforced (no discretionary exceptions) and injury recording is comparable pre/post; if compliance is partial or only some players are analyzed post-mandate, the conclusion would require additional assumptions about selection/compliance.
label: Yes
correct_reasoning: Under usual practice, workload Z is a common cause of both receiving recovery X and subsequent injury Y, so the observed association between X and Y is confounded through the open backdoor path X <- Z -> Y. The policy question is interventional: compare Y under do(X=mandated) versus Y under the status quo assignment mechanism. In the pilot, X is assigned by a rule based on minutes-threshold eligibility rather than discretionary medical judgment tied to Z, which severs (or substantially weakens) the causal link Z -> X within the eligible group. With the backdoor path blocked by design, differences in Y between mandated and usual assignment can be attributed to X (up to standard implementation assumptions like consistent outcome measurement and stable environment). Therefore the claim that mandating recovery reduces 14-day soft-tissue injuries is a valid causal conclusion in this setup.

scenario: A soccer club evaluates a new high-intensity pressing program introduced mid-season. Coaches compare players who 'fully adopted' the program (measured by meeting GPS running-distance and high-speed-sprint targets in training) to those who did not. They find that full adopters have fewer soft-tissue injuries over the next 8 weeks and conclude the program prevents injuries. The analysis is restricted to players who met the targets (compliers) and excludes players who were modified or held out by medical staff during the rollout.
claim: Implementing the high-intensity pressing program (X) causally reduces soft-tissue injury risk (Y) because, among players who complied with the program, injuries were lower than among non-compliers.

variables.X: Intervention: mandate a new high-intensity pressing training program with specific GPS workload targets
variables.Y: Outcome: soft-tissue injury incidence in the subsequent 8 weeks (e.g., hamstring/groin strains causing missed matches)
variables.Z: Post-intervention selection/compliance mechanism: being able/allowed to meet the workload targets (compliance), which is influenced by latent injury risk, current soreness, prior load, and medical restrictions

annotations.causal_structure: X affects compliance Z (players are asked to hit targets). Latent injury susceptibility and early symptoms also affect Z (medical staff restrict high-risk players; sore players self-limit). Those same latent factors also affect Y (future injuries). Conditioning on Z (analyzing only compliers) opens a non-causal path between X and Y via the common effects structure, biasing the estimated effect of X on Y.
annotations.key_insight: Compliance is post-treatment and partly determined by the same factors that predict injury; restricting to compliers creates collider bias and can make an ineffective (or harmful) program look protective.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: t0: Program X is introduced and targets are set. t0→t1: Players/medical staff decide who can meet targets (Z) based on soreness, prior workload, and perceived fragility. t1→t2: Injuries Y occur during matches/training. The analysis conditions on Z measured after t0.
conditional_answers: If the club instead estimated an intention-to-treat effect (assigned-to-program regardless of compliance) or used a valid design/instrument that identifies a complier average causal effect without conditioning on post-treatment compliance, the causal claim might be testable; as stated (conditioning on compliance), the conclusion is not justified.
label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is flawed because it infers an interventional effect of X on Y using a comparison that conditions on Z, where Z is compliance measured after the intervention is introduced. In the causal graph, X → Z and U → Z and U → Y, where U denotes latent injury risk/early symptoms/prior load that both (i) reduce the ability/permission to comply and (ii) increase subsequent injury incidence. By restricting the analysis to Z=1 (compliers), we condition on a collider (Z) that is caused by both X and U. Conditioning on this post-treatment collider opens a spurious association between X and U within the selected set, creating an unblocked backdoor path X → Z ← U → Y in the conditioned data. Therefore, even if X has no protective effect (or is harmful), the selected group of compliers can appear safer because high-risk players are disproportionately filtered out of Z=1 by medical restrictions or self-limiting behavior. The observed lower injury rate among compliers is thus not an unbiased estimate of P(Y | do(X)) and cannot support the causal conclusion that implementing the program reduces injuries.

scenario: A 'Best of 5' tennis match is in the first set. At 4:00 PM, Player A sprains his ankle. The match is abandoned immediately. At 4:15 PM (15 minutes later), a massive thunderstorm floods the court, which would have forced the cancellation of play for the rest of the day regardless of the score.
claim: If Player A had not sprained his ankle, the match would have been completed that day.

variables.X: Player A's Ankle Sprain (4:00 PM)
variables.Y: Match Outcome (Completed vs. Abandoned)
variables.Z: Thunderstorm (4:15 PM)
variables.D: Minimum Duration to complete a Best of 5 match (Fact: > 15 minutes)

annotations.causal_structure: X (Sprain) causes Y=Abandoned at t=0. Z (Storm) causes Y=Abandoned at t=15. Because the minimum time to complete the match (D) is greater than the time until Z, the match cannot be completed in the counterfactual world where X is removed.
annotations.key_insight: The claim fails because the 'Backup Cause' (Z) arrives sooner than the 'Success Condition' (Match Completion). Removing the injury allows the match to continue, but only for 15 minutes.
annotations.author: Ray Du

label: No
correct_reasoning: The claim is false. We are evaluating the counterfactual scenario where the sprain (X) does not occur. While this removes the immediate cause of abandonment at 4:00 PM, we must look at the timeline. The match was in the first set of a Best-of-5 series, meaning it required at least 4560 more minutes to reach a natural conclusion (D). However, the storm (Z) occurred only 15 minutes later. In the counterfactual world, the players continue playing until 4:15 PM, at which point the storm stops the match. Thus, the outcome remains 'Match Abandoned,' just for a different reason.

scenario: A soccer analytics blog analyzes 5 seasons of match logs from a top European league. They find that teams that make a substitution before the 60th minute have a higher probability of winning than teams that wait longer. The blog suggests the pattern reveals a coaching edge: early subs 'create momentum' and directly increase win probability.
claim: Making a substitution before the 60th minute increases the chance of winning the match.

variables.X: Early substitution indicator (at least one substitution made before minute 60)
variables.Y: Match outcome (win vs not win)
variables.Z: Match state and team context at the time the substitution becomes possible (e.g., current scoreline, red cards, injury shocks, pre-match team strength, opponent strength)

annotations.causal_structure: Z influences both X (coaches substitute earlier when match state/context demands it or enables it) and Y (the same match state/context also predicts final result); X and Y therefore exhibit an association even though the pathway may not be causal.
annotations.key_insight: At Pearl L1 we may assert an association statement if it is purely observational; the 'trap' is mistaking a confounded association for a causal effect. The correct label can be Yes because the claim is explicitly associative, not interventional.
annotations.author: Ray Du

label: No
correct_reasoning: The Momentum effect is an artifact of Confounding. The blog observes that early substitutions (X) correlate with wins (Y) but ignores the common cause: the Match State (Z). When we control for the scoreline and team strength (Z) rather than the action (X), the perceived advantage might disappear. The substitution is a luxury afforded by a winning position, not the driver of it.

scenario: A soccer club deploys an AI-driven training-load policy: if a player’s daily fatigue score exceeds a threshold, the staff automatically reduces that player’s next-day minutes in training and may rest them on matchday. Midseason, analysts compare players who triggered the policy (minutes reduced/rested) versus those who did not, and find that the triggered group has a higher subsequent soft-tissue injury rate over the next 4 weeks. The performance director asks whether enforcing the AI rest policy is causing more injuries and should be discontinued.
claim: Implementing the AI rest policy (reducing training/match minutes when fatigue is high) increases soft-tissue injury risk in the following month.

variables.X: AI-triggered load reduction/rest decision (e.g., reduced next-day training minutes or match rest)
variables.Y: Soft-tissue injury incidence within the next 4 weeks
variables.Z: Latent injury susceptibility and evolving fatigue/health state that both raises the fatigue score and affects injury risk; also influences coaches’ rest decisions

annotations.causal_structure: Z(t) (time-varying fatigue/incipient injury) affects X(t) (rest/load reduction) and also affects future Y(t+1) (injury). Additionally, past micro-injuries and prior load affect current Z(t), and past X(t-1) changes current Z(t) by altering recovery, creating treatment-confounder feedback over time.
annotations.key_insight: Because fatigue/incipient injury both drives the intervention and is itself influenced by prior interventions, naive comparisons (or standard regression adjusting for contemporaneous fatigue) can yield misleading signs; identifying the causal effect requires a longitudinal causal model (e.g., g-methods) and clear intervention definition.
annotations.author: Ray Du

hidden_timestamp: Z at t0 (accumulated fatigue / micro-damage) increases probability of X at t0 (rest). Z at t0 also increases probability of Y during t1..t4 (injury). Meanwhile, X at t0 changes Z at t1 (recovery), and Z at t1 influences X at t1, continuing the loop.
conditional_answers: Ambiguous: If the fatigue score fully captures Z and the policy is applied deterministically with no unmeasured time-varying confounding, then g-computation/IPW could show the policy is protective (claim would be No). If substantial unmeasured incipient injury remains in Z (not captured by the score) or the policy changes exposure patterns (e.g., rested players return with acute:chronic spikes), the observed association could reflect either harm or benefit depending on the true dynamics.
label: Ambiguous
correct_reasoning: We are asked an interventional question: what would Y be under do(X=rest) versus do(X=no rest) for the same players over time. The observed comparison is not a valid estimate of this causal effect because X is assigned in response to a time-varying health state Z that also predicts Y (an unblocked backdoor path X <- Z -> Y at each decision point). Moreover, Z is affected by earlier rest decisions (X affects recovery and thus future Z), so Z is simultaneously a confounder for later X and a mediator of earlier X, creating time-varying confounding with treatment-confounder feedback. In such settings, (i) unadjusted comparisons are biased by confounding by indication (players rested are precisely those already at higher baseline risk), and (ii) standard adjustment for contemporaneous fatigue can introduce additional bias by blocking part of the causal pathway from earlier X to later Y while still leaving residual confounding if Z is imperfectly measured. Therefore, the sign of the observed association (higher injuries among those rested) does not identify whether the policy truly increases injuries; it could be harmful (e.g., deconditioning and return-to-play spikes) or beneficial but overwhelmed by higher underlying risk in the treated group. Without a specified longitudinal causal model, measurement quality for Z, and an identification strategy (e.g., marginal structural models with stabilized weights, sequential randomization assumptions, or a randomized rollout), the causal claim cannot be validated or rejected, hence Ambiguous.
